Oracle recommends, from a security perspective, that the cache is disabled, so the browser does not store sensitive data and always requests pages if the URL changes. Otherwise, it may even be possible to go back in the browser history after a log out and see cached content of the former session. Disabling the browser cache prevents subtle back button issues with pages that use partial page refresh, such as interactive reports.

If this attribute is set to Disabled, Application Express sends the HTTP header cache-control: no-store which instructs the Browser to not cache the page contents on disk or in memory. If it is set to Application Default, the value at runtime is taken from the application's Browser Cache attribute.

Note: This feature requires modern browsers that support the HTTP header response variable cache-control.

330.name: ICON_VIEW_IMAGE_ATTRIBUTES
330.helpText: Enter the image attributes used for the HTML IMG tag.

331.name: ICON_VIEW_HTML_ALT_TEXT
331.helpText: Enter the HTML ALT text for the image.

332.name: ICON_VIEW_HTML_TITLE_TEXT
332.helpText: Enter the HTML TITLE tag for the image.

333.name: ICON_VIEW_CUSTOM_LINK
333.helpText: Enter the column link for the Icon View. Use #COLUMN_NAME# substitution strings for column names as required.

334.name: DETAIL_VIEW_ENABLED
334.helpText: Specify whether the Detail View is enabled. Selecting Yes adds a View Details icon to the Search bar for interactive reports, or to the interactive grid View button, enabling users to access this view.

335.name: DETAIL_VIEW_BEFORE_ROWS
335.helpText: Enter the HTML to be displayed before report rows.

336.name: DETAIL_VIEW_FOR_EACH_ROW
336.helpText: Enter the body for report rows in the Detail View. Use #COLUMN_NAME# substitution strings for column names and column labels.

337.name: DETAIL_VIEW_AFTER_ROWS
337.helpText: Enter the HTML to be displayed after report rows.

338.name: SHOW_FILTER
338.helpText: Specify whether end users can define filters on this report.

339.name: SHOW_SELECT_COLUMNS
339.helpText: Specify whether end users can use Select Columns in the Actions menu to change the columns displayed in this report. User can select (or show), deselect (or hide) and reorder multiple columns using this option.

340.name: SHOW_ROWS_PER_PAGE
340.helpText: Specify whether end users can change the number of rows displayed for this report.

341.name: SHOW_SORT
341.helpText: Specify whether end users can define sort columns for this report.

342.name: SHOW_CONTROL_BREAK
342.helpText: Specify whether end users can define control breaks for this report.

343.name: SHOW_HIGHLIGHT
343.helpText: Specify whether end users can define highlights for this report.

344.name: SHOW_COMPUTATION
344.helpText: Specify whether end users can define computational columns for this report.

345.name: SHOW_AGGREGATE
345.helpText: Specify whether end users can define aggregates for this report.

346.name: SHOW_CHART
346.helpText: Specify whether end users can define charts for this report.

347.name: SHOW_NOTIFY
347.helpText: Specify whether end users can define subscription settings for this report.

348.name: SHOW_GROUP_BY
348.helpText: Specify whether end,users can define group by break-downs for this report.

349.name: SHOW_PIVOT
349.helpText: Specify whether end users can define pivot break-downs for this report.

350.name: SHOW_FLASHBACK
350.helpText:
Specify whether end users can utilize flashback queries for this report.

Flashback queries utilize the Oracle Flashback Technology and Database Point-in-Time Recovery to view data as it existed at a previous point in time. Users can only query this data, but can not rewind any data changes. How far back in time they can successfully perform a flashback query is determined by when the redo log files were last switched within the Oracle database, as this technology utilizes the RMAN backup.

351.name: SHOW_RESET
351.helpText:
Specify whether end users can reset their reports from the Actions menu.

Reseting the report reverts all customizations made by the user, or specified by the calling URL, and displays the Primary Report.

352.name: SHOW_DOWNLOAD
352.helpText: Specify whether end users can download the report to one of the download formats specified.

353.name: SHOW_HELP
353.helpText:
Specify whether end users can invoke the built-in help modal dialog for interactive reports.

The help dialog only outlines those options available to the current user.

354.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_SAVE_REPORTS
354.helpText:
Specify whether end users can save their current report definition as a Private report.

Private reports are displayed in a select list of available reports in the Search Bar, and are only displayed to the user who saved the report, providing they are authenticated. The option on the Actions menu is only available to authenticated users.

355.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_SAVE_PUBLIC_REPORT
355.helpText:
Specify whether end users can save their current report definition as a Public report.

Public reports are displayed in a select list of available reports in the Search Bar, and are displayed to everyone. The option on the Actions menu is only available to authenticated users and is further restricted if you also populate the Save Public Report Authorization.

357.name: SHOW_FINDER_DROP_DOWN
357.helpText:
Specify whether the Finder drop down is included at the beginning of the Search field within the search bar.
The Finder drop down is a list of columns that enables users to limit their search to a specific column.

358.name: SHOW_DISPLAY_ROW_COUNT
358.helpText: Specify whether a separate drop down row selector is included within the search bar. You should not select both this attribute and Rows Per Page.

360.name: SHOW_SEARCH_TEXTBOX
360.helpText: Specify whether the search field is included within the search bar.

361.name: SHOW_ACTIONS_MENU
361.helpText: Specify whether the Actions menu is included within the Search Bar.

362.name: SHOW_REPORTS_SELECT_LIST
362.helpText:
Specify whether the Reports select list displays in the search bar.

The Reports select list only displays if a report, other than the primary report, is accessible to the user.

363.name: LINK_TARGET
363.helpText:
Click the Target to invoke a modal dialog. You can enter a custom target to be called when the Link Column is clicked.

Select the appropriate type in Link Builder - Target based on your requirements:

Page in this application
Enter the following:
  • Page - enter the page number or page alias to navigate to. You can also select the page number from the select list.
  • Set Items: Name - enter or select page items (P3_ID), application items (LAST_PAGE) or interactive report filters (IR_EMPNO) to be set into session state.
  • Set Items: Value - enter or select a report column (#ID#), enter an application or page item (&P2_EMPNO.), or enter a static value (2).
  • Clear Cache - enter a comma-delimited list of page numbers (2,3), items (P3_EMPNO,LAST_PAGE), and report settings to be cleared. To reset pagination for a report enter RP. To clear or reset interactive report settings enter CIR or RIR.
  • Reset Pagination - select Yes to reset pagination, back to the first set of records, for reports on the target page. This has the same affect as passing RP in Clear Cache.
  • Advanced: Request - enter the request to be used.
Page in a different application
Enter the same attributes as listed for Page in this application, with the addition that you need to enter the application ID or application alias for Application.
URL
Enter the URL

364.name: IR_SAVED_VISIBILITY
364.helpText: View the saved report category, which dictates where this report displays within the Reports select List. This attribute is view only and cannot be updated.

lovValues.helpText: Report saved by developers, that is displayed by default.
Subsequent report layouts saved by developers, that end users can select.
Report layouts saved by end users, that all other end users can select.
Report layouts saved by end users, that only the end user who saved it can select.

365.name: IR_SAVED_REPORT_ALIAS
365.helpText: Enter an alias for this saved report. Use this alias to define a more meaningful URL link to this specific saved report. This link can be used to link directly from elsewhere in the application.

366.name: LINK_EXAMPLE
366.helpText:
View the URL link for this saved report. This attribute is view only and cannot be updated.

This attribute enables you to quickly copy the displayed URL. This URL can be used to link directly to this particular saved report from anywhere else in the application.

367.name: RUN_PROCESS
367.helpText: Select the frequency that this process is executed.

lovValues.d: Once Per Session or When Reset

368.name: SUCCESS_MESSAGE
368.helpText: Enter the text to be displayed in the "Notification" area (defined as part of the page template), when this process completes successfully.

369.name: PROCESS_ERROR_DISPLAY_LOCATION
369.helpText: Select where this process error message displays, when the process fails to complete successfully.

lovValues.helpText: The process error message is displayed in the "Notification" area (defined as part of the page template)
The Process error message is displayed on the error page.

370.name: PROCESS_REGION
370.helpText: Select the region to associate with this process.

371.name: DA_EVENT
371.helpText: Select the appropriate dynamic action event from the available list.

372.name: IR_COLUMN_FILTER_LOV_SQL
372.examples:
To return the department name:
select dname from dept order by 1
372.helpText:
Enter a SQL query which needs to return one column. If the query returns multiple columns, only the first column is used in the list of values.

Entering a SQL query can improve performance in some reports, or be used to limit the values displayed.

373.name: LOV_TYPE
373.helpText: Select the list of values type.

lovValues.helpText: The list of values is based on a predefined list of values, defined in Shared Components.
The Dynamic list of values is based on the SQL Query you enter.
The Static list of values is based on the text value you enter.

lovValues.d: PL/SQL Function Body returning SQL Query
lovValues.helpText: The Dynamic list of values is based on the SQL Query returned by the entered PL/SQL Function Body you enter.

374.name: LOV_STATIC_VALUES
374.helpText: Enter the values for this static list of values.

375.name: TZ_DEPENDENT
375.helpText: Indicates whether or not this column is timezone aware.

376.name: PAGE_PROC_WS_PARM_ITEM
376.helpText: Enter the page or application item used as the source for this parameter. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items.

377.name: PAGE_PROC_WS_PARM_SOURCE
377.helpText: Select the source for the parameter from the available list.

lovValues.helpText: Set to the value held in session state for the Item selected.
Set to the text entered into Static Value.
Set to the value returned from the PL/SQL Function Body entered.

379.name: PAGE_PROC_WS_PARM_VALUE
379.helpText: Enter the value for this parameter.

38.name: BUILD_OPTION
38.examples:
1. You are developing an application that will have many installations. Additionally, each installation may choose to enable or disable certain application functionality. With Build Options, you can develop one application and when installed, build options can be configured to include or exclude associated application functionality. You may also use the API to expose this feature within the application. This allows privileged end-users to selectively enable or disable application functionality.

2. You are developing functionality which is not yet complete, so you do not wish to expose to end-users. Using Build Options enables you to disable this functionality from the application when it is built into the test and production environments. The benefit of this approach is that the application can still be deployed without including incomplete functionality.

3. You are removing functionality you think is not needed by the application, but are unsure this is a safe operation. In this case, you can use Build Options to essentially "comment out" specific functionality. If on deployment, the removed functionality was deemed to be necessary, it can be re-instated. If this functionality was deemed to be unnecessary, then it can be safely removed from the application.
38.helpText:
Select a build option for this component.

Build Options allow application components and functionality to be conditionally enabled or disabled when the application is installed, or at runtime via API (APEX_UTIL.SET_BUILD_OPTION_STATUS).
Build Options can set this component to be Included or Excluded in the runtime application:

Included - Enabled and are part of the application.

Excluded - Disabled and are not a part of the application.

380.name: CHART_TITLE
380.helpText: Enter a title to display at the top of the chart.  For gantt charts, this value is only used to define the accessible chart title.

381.name: CHANGED_BY
381.helpText: Displays the user credentials of the developer who last updated this attribute.

382.name: CHANGED_ON
382.helpText: Displays when this attribute was last updated.

383.name: ALLOW_USERS_TO_PIVOT
383.helpText: Specify whether end user can define a pivot break-down within this report.

384.name: SOURCE_LIST
384.helpText: Select the source for this list.

385.name: SOURCE_BREADCRUMB
385.helpText: Select the breadcrumb list associated with this page.

386.name: LIST_TEMPLATE
386.helpText:
Select a template to define the appearance and layout of this list.

List templates are defined in the application theme. When a list region is created, the template is automatically set to the default list template defined in the current theme.

Universal Theme provides the following list templates:

Badge List
Cards
Links List
Media List
Menu Bar
Menu Popup
Navigation Bar
Side Navigation Menu
Tabs
Top Navigation Menu
Wizard Progress
See Also: Universal Theme Sample Application

387.name: BREADCRUMB_TEMPLATE
387.helpText: Select the breadcrumb template utilized with this breadcrumb.

389.name: LOV_NAME
389.helpText: Enter the name of this list of values.

39.name: INLINE_ERROR_NOTIFICATION_TEXT
39.helpText: Enter the error message displayed when an error occurs on this page. The error message is substituted for #NOTIFICATION_MESSAGE# in the page template.

390.name: HAS_GENERIC_COLUMNS
390.helpText:
Select whether column definitions are derived from the SQL query.
Doing this requires Application Express to parse the query.
If you do not want the query parsed at this time, use generic column names, which produces placeholder column definitions.

391.name: GENERIC_COLUMN_COUNT
391.helpText:
Enter the maximum number of generic report columns. Reports that use generic column names are parsed at runtime only, so the number of columns is not known when editing the report.

The maximum number of report columns should match the expected number of report columns. If the actual number is smaller, the report renders with the actual number of columns. However, if the actual number is higher than the maximum, then an error message shows at runtime.

392.name: PAGE_PROC_WS_PARM_FUNCTION
392.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL function body that returns a value used as the source for this parameter.

394.name: PAGE_PROC_WS_PARM_ITEMS
394.helpText:
Enter one or more page or application item used as the destination for this parameter. For multiple items, separate each item name with a comma.

You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items. If you pick from the list and there is already text entered, then a comma is placed at the end of the existing text, followed by the item name returned from the list.

395.name: COMPUTE_SUM
395.helpText:
For this column, specify whether the sum is computed and displays at the end of the report.
When used with break columns, the total sum and the sum on each break displays.

396.name: COLUMN_WIDTH
396.helpText:
Enter the column width in pixels.
Use this attribute when displaying reports in a browser.
Note that setting the column width must be supported by the selected report template.

397.name: USE_AS_ROW_HEADER
397.helpText:
Specify whether this column also display in the Row Header. Including the column value can greatly improve accessibility for form fields rendered in a report. When specified, this causes the Row Header to be used together with the Column Header to render the labels for the form fields in the report, using this '<Column Header> : <Row Header>' format.

For example, suppose you have a report on the EMP table and you define the ENAME column as the Row Header. For a row where ENAME is 'JONES,' the label for the Salary field in that row would be "Salary : JONES". This approach enables a screen reader user to be able to navigate by the Form fields in the report and still maintain an understanding of which form fields relate to which row.

398.name: CLASSIC_REPORT_COLUMN_TYPE
398.helpText: Select the basis for this report column.

lovValues.helpText: Displays the column value.

lovValues.d: Plain Text (based on List of Values)
lovValues.helpText: Displays the value returned from the list of values specified.
Displays the column as a link.
Displays the column as an image.
Displays the column as a link to download the file.
Displays the column as a percentage graph. The value retrieved must be between 0 and 100.
Does not display the column, but it is referenceable.

399.name: DATE_PICKER_FORMAT_MASK
399.helpText: Select the format mask to apply to the date picker for this column.

4.name: COMMENTS
4.helpText: Enter any developer comments or notes here. These comments only display within App Builder and never display when running the application.

40.name: HELP_TEXT
40.helpText:
Use this attribute to enter help text for the current page. Page level help supports shortcuts using the following syntax:

"SHORTCUT_NAME"

Page help text is not displayed by default. However, you can readily develop a help system that exposes this text.

400.name: RADIO_COLUMNS
400.helpText: Enter the number of columns to display for this radio group column.

402.name: SIMPLE_CHECKBOX_VALUES
402.helpText:
For the Simple Checkbox display type, enter either one value or two comma separated values. The first value is submitted if the checkbox is selected. The second value, if defined, is submitted if the checkbox is deselected.', p_examples => q'~
Submit Yes when selected and No when deselected
Yes,No

403.name: FORMATTING_CSS_CLASSES
403.examples:
Setting this attribute to fielddatabold results in the following HTML being generated
<span class="fielddatabold">Sample Data</span>
403.helpText:
Enter CSS classes to apply to this column's value. You can type in the CSS class or pick from the list of available items.

This class is included by default on all Application Express pages and has the definition of '.fielddatabold{font-size: 10pt; font-weight: bold; color: #000000;}'.

404.name: CSS_STYLE
404.examples:
Setting this attribute to color:#FF0000; changes the text color of the column to red and generates the following HTML
<span style="color:#FF0000">Sample Data</span>
404.helpText: Enter CSS styles to apply to this column's value. You can type in the CSS style or pick from the list of available items.

405.name: HIGHLIGHT_WORDS
405.helpText: Enter text strings to be highlighted in a report column. For multiple highlighted words, use a comma delimited list. You can also reference page or application items using &ITEM. syntax. For example, you can highlight strings entered into a search field.

406.name: COLUMN_SORT_SEQUENCE
406.helpText:
Select the sort sequence for this column.
Each column should have a unique sequence to correctly order the report output.

407.name: COLUMN_SORT_DIRECTION
407.helpText: Specify whether this column is sorted in Descending order. If not specified, the column is sorted in Ascending order (the default).

408.name: DISABLE_SORT_COLUMN
408.helpText: Specify whether this column can be used by the end user to sort the report.

409.name: INCLUDE_IN_EXPORT_PRINT
409.helpText: Specify whether this column is included when the report is exported to CSV or printed.

41.name: ERROR_HANDLING_FUNCTION
41.helpText:
Enter the name of the PL/SQL function called when an error occurs within the application. You can use this function to act on various error codes including those emanating from the Oracle database, and log such errors in a custom table you define if necessary. The function can include logic to modify the error message and display location, transforming Oracle database errors into user friendly messages. For example, you can capture a unique key violation on DEMO_CUSTOMERS and replace the ORA-00001 message with this text: Customer Name must be unique. Installing the Sample Database Application, from Packaged Applications, creates the SAMPLE_PKG package, which includes the demo_error_handling function. This sample error handling function includes extensive comments to make it easy for you to utilize as the basis for defining your own function.

The function name entered can reference a package function or stand alone function in the database. For example: 

log_apex_error

When referencing a database PL/SQL package or stand alone function, you can use the #OWNER# substitution string to reference the parsing schema of the current application. For example: 

#OWNER#.log_apex_error

If an error handling function is specified on a page then it is utilized, instead of this application level setting, for that page.

Error Handling Functions must implement the following interface: 

function <name of function> (
    p_error in apex_error.t_error )
    return apex_error.t_error_result

See the API Reference manual for a description of the package apex_error.

410.name: PRINT_COLUMN_WIDTH
410.helpText: Enter the column width used to size this column when the report is printed.

411.name: REPORT_TEMPLATE
411.helpText:
Select a report template to define the appearance and layout of this classic report.

Report templates are defined in the application theme. When a classic report is created, the template is automatically set to the default report template defined in the current theme.

Many themes contain classic report templates for displaying data in a table, key value pairs, search results, cards, and so forth. Note that some report templates, such as cards and search results, are "row based" and expect your SQL query to return a particular set of column aliases that are substituted in the template.
Universal Theme provides the following report templates:

Alerts
Displays any number of horizontal alerts or notifications on your page.
Badge List
Displays key value pairs in a dashboard-like user interface.
Cards
Displays report data in cards, or small blocks and is useful for presenting a variety of information. Cards can be heavily customized via Template Options.
Comments
Displays comments and other messages.
Search Results
Displays search-engine style search results
Standard
This is the default report template for displaying data in a table and can be heavily customized via Template Options.
Timeline
Displays a timeline of actions. It is well suited for home pages, change logs, and other areas where an activity feed of recent actions is needed.
Value Attribute Pairs - Column
Displays key-value pairs for column-based queries. It uses the column header as the label for each item.
Value Attribute Pairs - Row
Displays key-value pairs for row-based queries. It uses the first column for labels, and second column for values.
See Also: Universal Theme Sample Application

412.name: PCT_GRAPH_BACKGROUD_COLOR
412.examples:
Examples of major HTML color codes include -
  •   Black   #000000 RGB(0,0,0)
  •   Red   #FF0000 RGB(255,0,0)
  •   Yellow   #FFFF00 RGB(255,255,0)
  •   Lime   #00FF00 RGB(0,255,0)
  •   Green   #008000 RGB(0,128,0)
  •   Aqua   #00FFFF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Blue   #0000FF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Navy   #000080 RGB(0,0,128)
  •   White   #FFFFFF RGB(255,255,255)
412.helpText:
Enter the color used for the background of this graph.

The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names. Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

413.name: PCT_GRAPH_FOREGROUND_COLOR
413.examples:
Examples of major HTML color codes include -
  •   Black   #000000 RGB(0,0,0)
  •   Red   #FF0000 RGB(255,0,0)
  •   Yellow   #FFFF00 RGB(255,255,0)
  •   Lime   #00FF00 RGB(0,255,0)
  •   Green   #008000 RGB(0,128,0)
  •   Aqua   #00FFFF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Blue   #0000FF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Navy   #000080 RGB(0,0,128)
  •   White   #FFFFFF RGB(255,255,255)
413.helpText:
Enter the color used for the foreground of this graph.

The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names. Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

414.name: PCT_GRAPH_BAR_WIDTH
414.helpText: Enter the width in pixels for this bar chart.

415.name: BLOB_TABLE_OWNER
415.helpText: Select the schema that owns the table which stores the BLOB content you want to display.

416.name: BLOB_TABLE
416.helpText:
Enter the table name which stores the BLOB content you want to display.
You can type in the table name or pick from the list of available tables.

417.name: BLOB_CONTENT_COLUMN
417.helpText: Select the BLOB column from the table which stores the BLOB content you want to display. The image is unlikely to display if you select a column with the wrong data type.

418.name: BLOB_PK_COLUMN1
418.helpText: Select the first primary key column from the table which stores the BLOB content you want to display. If the primary key of this table has more than two columns, you must select the ROWID column. The image is unlikely to display if you select a column with the wrong data type.

419.name: BLOB_PK_COLUMN2
419.helpText: Only select the second primary key column if the primary key for your table has two columns. If you select ROWID for the first primary key column, you should not populate this column. The image is unlikely to display if you select a column with the wrong data type.

42.name: PAGE_TRANSITION
42.helpText:
Specify the transition used when navigating to a new page or when the page is getting submitted.

Older browsers, that do not support 3D transforms, are not able to utilize most of the transitions. By default, devices that lack 3D support (such as Android 2.x) fallback to fade for all transition types. See jQuery Mobile documentation for additional details.

420.name: BLOB_MIME_TYPE_COLUMN
420.helpText: Select the mime type column from the table which stores the BLOB content you want to display. The image is unlikely to display if you select a column with the wrong data type.

421.name: BLOB_FILENAME_COLUMN
421.helpText: Enter the filename column from the table which stores the BLOB content you want to display. The image is unlikely to display if you select a column with the wrong data type.

422.name: BLOB_CHARSET_COLUMN
422.helpText: Select the character set column from the table which stores the BLOB content you want to display. The image is unlikely to display if you select a column with the wrong data type.

423.name: BLOB_LAST_UPDATED_COLUMN
423.helpText: Select the last updated column from the table which stores the BLOB content you want to display. If you already have an UPDATED column with an associated trigger to maintain the date, you could use this column instead of defining a new column specifically for when the image was last updated. However, if columns other than the BLOB content are updated regularly, then image caching is adversely affected. The image is unlikely to display if you select a column with the wrong data type.

424.name: CONTENT_DISPOSITION
424.helpText: Select the content disposition from the avialable list.

425.name: DOWNLOAD_TEXT
425.helpText: Enter the text to use for the download link on the page. End users use this link to download the BLOB content.

427.name: HEADINGS_TYPE
427.helpText: Select how headings are defined for your report.

lovValues.helpText: Generates headings based on a query of the column names.
Generates headings, which are converted to initial capitalization, based on a query of the column names.
Enables you to enter your own headings. The headings are initially defaulted, based on a query of column names.
Creates headings based on a PL/SQL Function returning a colon delimited list of names.
The report is displayed without report headings.

428.name: HEADING_TYPE_PLSQL_FUNCTION_BODY
428.examples:
Provide the headings for a report based on the DEPT table
return 'Deptno:DName:Loc';
428.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL function to return a string of column headings delimited by colons.

429.name: TEMPLATE_TYPE
429.helpText: Select the template type for this report.

lovValues.helpText: Report templates available in the corresponding theme, based on the current theme for this page's user interface.

Predefined report templates which are not associated directly with any themes. Because there is no correlation between these predefined templates and your current theme, your report layout remains the same even if you change the application theme.

43.name: POPUP_TRANSITION
43.helpText:
Specify the transition used when a popup is opened.

Older browsers, that do not support 3D transforms, are not able to utilize most of the transitions. By default, devices that lack 3D support (such as Android 2.x) fallback to fade for all transition types. See jQuery Mobile documentation for additional details.

430.name: REPORT_PREDEFINED_TEMPLATE
430.helpText: Select a predefined report templates to control the display of this report.

lovValues.helpText: Creates a standard HTML table.
Shows each column in a separate row.
Exports the report as a CSV file.
Exports the report as an XML file.

431.name: CLASSIC_REPORT_PAGINATION_TYPE
431.helpText:
Select the pagination type to utilize in this report. Generally only a subset of the results are currently displayed in the report. Pagination provides the user with information about the number of rows and the current position within the result set. Pagination also defines the style of links or buttons that are used to navigate to the next or previous page.

Pagination can be shown above or below the report (or both) and can be positioned on the left or right.

You can also use a simplified pagination style to improve performance, such as Row Ranges X to Y (with next and previous links). Using paginiation types of the form "X to Y of Z", require the Application Express engine to perform two queries to return the results. One query retrieves the current records to be displayed and another query gets the total record count to display in the pagination control. For reports based on exceedingly large data sets or with very CPU intensive queries, such as numerous non-optimal table joins or exepnsive conditions, this additonal query can add some processing time, which can lead to the report taking longer to render.

lovValues.d: Row Ranges X to Y (no pagination)
Row Ranges X to Y of Z (no pagination)
Row Ranges X to Y of Z (with pagination)
Row Ranges 1-15 16-30 in select list (with pagination)
Row Ranges X to Y (with next and previous links)

432.name: PARTIAL_PAGE_REFRESH
432.helpText:
Specify whether to use Partial Page Refresh (PPR) to update the report display.

If the end user performs an action, such as a pagination request or selection of a new sort column, the current report rows must be refreshed. Setting this attribute to Yes, refreshes just the report region. Setting this attribute to No, refreshes the entire page.

433.name: NUMBER_OF_ROWS_TYPE
433.helpText: Select how the number of rows for this report are entered.

434.name: NUMBER_OF_ROWS
434.helpText: Enter the number of report rows to display per report page.

435.name: NUMBER_OF_ROWS_ITEM
435.helpText: Select the item whose value specifies the number of report rows to display per report page.

436.name: STRIP_HTML
436.helpText:
Specify whether or not to remove HTML tags from the original column values. This is particularly important for columns that utilize HTML expressions, are used in column links, or are exported to CSV files.

If you select values from the database that already contain HTML tags, then those tags can cause conflicts with the HTML generated for your HTML expressions or URL generated for column links. When exporting such values, the existing HTML tags are included as plain text in the generated CSV file. When this option is enabled, only the actual data portion of your column value is used.

437.name: SORT_NULLS
437.helpText: For report columns that enable column heading sorting, select how you want records with null values to be sorted in relation to records with not null values

lovValues.helpText: Records with a null value are displayed before any columns with not-null values.
Records with a not-null values are displayed before any columns with a null value.

438.name: WHEN_MORE_DATA_FOUND_MESSAGE
438.helpText:
Enter the text message that displays when more report rows exist. Use this approach as an alternative to pagination, especially if a report generally only has a discrete record set. If the report query returns additional rows, this message can be used to alert the end user to the anomoly, rather than simply displaying slightly different pagination controls. Your text message can readily incorporate a "Call to action" so end users are given guidance on how to respond to this unusual query result and can include page or URL links.

The following pagination substitution strings can be utilized in your message:

#ROWS_FETCHED#
The number of rows displayed (page size)
#TOTAL_ROWS#
The "Z" in "rows X - Y of Z"
#FIRST_ROW_FETCHED#
The "X" in "rows X - Y of Z"
#LAST_ROW_FETCHED#
The "Y" in "rows X - Y of Z"
#ROW_RANGES"
Shows: Row(s) 1-15 16-30 30-32
#ROW_RANGES_IN_SELECT_LIST
Same as row ranges but in a select list
#INTERNET_PAGINATION#
Page Sets: 1 2 3 4 5 6

439.name: CSV_EXPORT_ENABLED
439.helpText: Specify whether end users can download the report contents to a CSV file. To enable CSV Downloads, you must use a report template with a #CSV_LINK# substitution string and set this option to YES.

44.name: MEDIA_TYPE
44.helpText:
Enter the Internet media type. An Internet media type is a two part identifier for file formats on the Internet. A media type is composed of at least two parts: a type, a subtype, and one or more optional parameters. This media type is used in the Content-Type HTTP header when rendering the page.

The page-level Media type overrides the application-level media type. If both the page-level and application-level values for media type are NULL, the media type text/html is used.

440.name: DOWNLOAD_LINK_TEXT
440.helpText: Enter the text for the link to invoke the CSV download.

441.name: REPORT_SUM_LABEL
441.helpText: Enter the text that displays adjacent to report sum values.

442.name: BREAK_COLUMNS
442.helpText: Select how many report columns are incorporated into the break formatting. The columns must be consecutive columns, starting from the first column displayed in the report.

443.name: BREAK_COLUMN_STYLE
443.helpText: Select how breaks affect the display formatting of the report.

lovValues.helpText: The report displays as several subreports with repeating headings for each break.
The breaks display in a single report without repeating the headings for each break.

444.name: BREAK_REPEAT_HEADING_FORMAT
444.helpText: Enter the text for the repeating headings displayed for report breaks. You can utilize #COLUMN_VALUE# substitutions.

445.name: BREAK_COLUMN_TEXT_FORMAT
445.helpText: Enter the text that displays on report breaks. Utilize #SUM_COLUMN_HEADER# substitutions.

446.name: BREAK_BEFORE_ROW
446.helpText: Enter the text that displays before break columns when displaying a break row.

447.name: BREAK_GENERIC_COLUMN
447.helpText: Enter the text for the break column when displaying a report break. You can utilize #COLUMN_VALUE# substitutions.

448.name: BREAK_AFTER_ROW
448.helpText: Enter the text that displays after break columns when displaying a break row.

449.name: EXTERNAL_PROCESSING_ENABLED
449.helpText: Specify whether external post processing is enabled for this report.

45.name: CSS_FILE_URLS
45.examples:
Standard file reference
/mycss/main.css
Standard file reference which loads the minified file main.min.css from /mycss/minified/ for regular page views and main.css from /mycss/ in debug mode or when running the application from App Builder.
/mycss/#MIN_DIRECTORY#main#MIN#.css
Conditional media query
[media="only screen and (max-device-width: 480px)"]/mycss/smartphone.css
File reference using a query string in the URL referencing the application version, such that when the application is upgraded (and the version is incremented), the browser is instructed to always load the new file and ignore any previously cached files.
/mycss/main.css?version=#APP_VERSION#
45.helpText:
Enter Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) file URLs loaded on this page. Each URL must be written on a new line. If you provide a minified version of your file you can use the substitution string #MIN# to include .min or #MIN_DIRECTORY# to include minified/ in your file URL for a regular page view and an empty string if the page is viewed in debug mode or when running the application from App Builder. You also have access to the substitution string #APP_VERSION# if you want to include the application's version in the file URL.

File URLs you enter here replace the #PAGE_CSS# substitution string in the page template.

Note: You do not need to include opening or closing link tags. Just include the file URL.

450.name: EXTERNAL_PROCESSING_URL
450.helpText: Enter the URL to a server for post processing of this report.

451.name: EXTERNAL_PROCESSING_LINK_TEXT
451.helpText: Enter the text for the link which end users click to invoke the external processing engine.

452.name: TAB_FORM_COLUMN_TYPE
452.helpText:
Select the basis for this Tabular Form column.

The selection determines whether this column is updateable within the Tabular Form. Updates can only be performed if a multiple row update is defined, or a PL/SQL process is implemented to process updated data.

lovValues.helpText: Includes a checkbox at the beginning of each row.
Displays the column value.
Displays the column value, and saves in the value in session state. This column can be utilized in page processing.

lovValues.d: Plain Text (based on List of Values)
lovValues.helpText: Displays the value returned from the list of values specified.
Displays the column as a link.
Displays the column as an image.
Displays the column as a link to download the file.
Displays the column as a percentage graph. The value retrieved must be between 0 and 100.
Enter a value into a text field.
Enter a value into a text area field.
Select a value from the list of values specified.
Select a value from the popup. The display value from the list of values is shown.
Select a value from the popup. The return value from the list of values is shown.
Select a single radio group from the list of values specified.
Check or uncheck a single checkbox.
Enter the date, or utilize the date picker to select the date.
Enter the date, or utilize the date picker to select the date.
Does not display the column, but it is referenceable.
Does not display the column, but it is referenceable. This column can be utilized in page processing.

457.name: UI_DEFAULT_REF_TABLE_OWNER
457.helpText:
Select the schema that owns the reference table.
This attribute is used to compare references to columns across applications using User Interface Defaults.
This reference is maintained manually, after being initialized by a wizard, whenever possible.

458.name: UI_DEFAULT_REF_TABLE
458.helpText:
Select the table or view that this column references.
This attribute is used to compare references to columns across applications using User Interface Defaults.
This reference is maintained manually, after being initialized by a wizard, whenever possible.

459.name: UI_DEFAULT_REF_COLUMN
459.helpText:
Select the column name that this report column references.
This attribute is used to compare references to columns across applications using User Interface Defaults.
This reference is maintained manually, after being initialized by a wizard, whenever possible.

46.name: INLINE_CSS
46.examples:
Sets the CSS class display_only to bold
.display_only {
  font-weight: bold;
}
46.helpText:
Enter Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) code used on this page. If the same CSS is required on multiple pages, consider putting the code into an external file to avoid duplication and to leverage browser caching of static files.

Code you enter here replaces the #PAGE_CSS# substitution string in the page template.

Note: You do not need to include opening or closing style tags. Just include the cascading style sheet code.

460.name: COLUMN_DEFAULT_TYPE
460.helpText: Select a default column value type.

461.name: DEFAULT_VALUE_ITEM
461.helpText: Enter the page or application item which holds the default value.

462.name: PK_SOURCE_TYPE
462.helpText: Select the source type for the primary key.

463.name: PK_SOURCE_PLSQL_EXPRESSION
463.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL expression that provides a value for the primary key.

464.name: PK_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_NAME
464.helpText: Enter a name for the primary key.

465.name: BRANCH_ACCEPT_REQUEST
465.helpText: Enter the request to be included within the branch link.

468.name: MAP_SERIES_TYPE
468.helpText: Select the map series type. A chart combining different types of series on the same data plot can also be created.

469.name: MAP_SERIES_SOURCE_TYPE
469.helpText: Select the query source type for the chart series.

lovValues.d: PL/SQL Function Body returning SQL Query

47.name: DIALOG_WIDTH
47.helpText:
Enter the width of the dialog, in pixels or a percentage. The substitution string #DIALOG_WIDTH# in the dialog initialization code of the page template is replaced with the value entered in this item.

For a page using a Desktop user interface, the value is set in pixels, such as 500. However, for a page using the jQuery Mobile Smartphone user interface, the value is set in percent, such as 80%.

470.name: MAP_SOURCE_QUERY
470.helpText: Enter the SQL Query for the chart series.

471.name: MAP_SOURCE_FUNC_RETURNING_SQL
471.prompt: PL/SQL Function Body returning SQL Query
471.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL function body that returns an SQL Query for the chart series.

472.name: SERIES_LINK_TYPE
472.helpText:
Select the chart series link type. The action link is applied to each item of the chart series and is activated by clicking an item of the chart series.
The action link can navigate to another page within the application or a provided URL.

lovValues.helpText: Any value set in the LINK column of the chart series query is overwritten by the Action Link settings, and used to set the action on the chart series items.
Any value set in the LINK column of the chart series query is used to set the action on the chart series items.

473.name: CHART_TYPE
473.helpText: Select a chart type. The chart type indicate the style in which this chart is rendered.

475.name: PROJECT_GANTT_SERIES_SOURCE_TYPE
475.helpText: Select the query source type for the chart series.

lovValues.d: PL/SQL Function Body returning SQL Query

476.name: PROJECT_GANTT_SOURCE_QUERY
476.examples:
select 'f?p=&APP_ID.:2:' || :APP_SESSION || '::::P2_ID:' || id as link,
       task_name      as name,
       task_id        as id,
       parent_task_id as parent_id,
       start_date     as actual_start,
       end_date       as actual_end,
       status_number  as progress
  from tasks
 order by task_id
476.helpText: Enter the SQL Query for the chart series.

477.name: PROJECT_GANTT_SOURCE_FUNC_RETURNING_SQL
477.prompt: PL/SQL Function Body returning SQL Query
477.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL function body that returns an SQL Query for the chart series.

478.name: RESOURCE_GANTT_SERIES_SOURCE_TYPE
478.helpText: Select the query source type for the chart series.

lovValues.d: PL/SQL Function Body returning SQL Query

479.name: RESOURCE_GANTT_SOURCE_QUERY

49.name: DIALOG_ATTRIBUTES
49.helpText:
Dialog support in Application Express varies depending on the user interface of the page. A subset of dialog attributes are declaratively supported: height, width, and maximum width. To define any additional attributes for the dialog, enter the name/value pairings in a comma separated list.

The substitution string #DIALOG_ATTRIBUTES# in the dialog initialization code defined at page template level, is replaced by any value(s) entered in this item.

For pages using Desktop user interface, the jQuery UI dialog widget is utilized. For pages using jQuery Mobile Smartphone user interface, the jQuery Mobile dialog widget is utilized.

For example, a dialog page using a Desktop user interface could have the following attributes defined: resizable:true, draggable:true

For further information on the attributes available, refer to the jQuery UI dialog widget documentation and jQuery Mobile dialog widget documentation.

4960.name: VALIDATION_TYPE
4960.helpText:
Select the type of equality to be tested for this validation. Depending on your selection, one or more additional attributes are required to fully define this validation.

If the validation passes the equality test, or evaluates to TRUE, then the validation error message does not display. Validation error messages display when the validation fails the equality test, or evaluates to FALSE, or a non-empty text string is returned.

A validation failure does not stop subsequent validations from being evaluated, therefore, each subsequent validation may raise an additional validation error message. If you want to stop subsequent validations from executing then you need to add additional logic into the first failed validation, such as setting a page item to a specific value, and then enhancing the conditional logic on subsequent validations as needed. Subsequent processes and branches are not executed if one or more validations fail evaluation.

lovValues.helpText:
Passes if the SQL query returns one or more rows.
Fails if the SQL query returns no rows.

Passes if the SQL query returns no rows.
Fails if the SQL query returns one or more rows.

Passes if the SQL expression evaluates to TRUE.
Fails if the SQL expression evaluates to FALSE.

Passes if the PL/SQL expression evaluates to TRUE.
Fails if the PL/SQL expression evaluates to FALSE.

Passes if the PL/SQL expression executes without generating an error.
Fails if the PL/SQL expression generates an error when it executes.

Passes if the PL/SQL Function body returns TRUE.
Fails if the PL/SQL Function body returns FALSE.
Note: The result returned from the function must be a boolean.

Passes if the PL/SQL Function body returns an empty string.
Fails if the PL/SQL Function body returns a non-empty string. The returned string displays as the error message for the validation.
Note: The result returned from the function must be a text string.

Passes if the Item value is not empty.
Fails if the Item value is empty.

lovValues.d: Item is NOT NULL or zero
lovValues.helpText:
Passes if the Item value is not empty and is not the number zero.
Fails if the Item value is empty or is the number zero.

Passes if the Item value is not the number zero.
Fails if the Item value is the number zero.

Passes if the Item value has no spaces.
Fails if the Item value contains spaces.

Passes if the Item value is alphanumeric, containing only letters and numbers and no special characters.
Fails if the Item value includes special characters.

Passes if the Item value is numeric.
Fails if the Item value contains non-numeric characters, including spaces, other than leading spaces.

Passes if the Item value is a valid date.
Fails if the Item value is not a valid date.

Passes if the Item value is a valid timestamp.
Fails if the Item value is not a valid timestamp.

Passes if the Item value is equal to the text you enter into the Value attribute.
Fails if the Item value is not equal to the text you enter into the Value attribute.

Passes if the Item value is not equal to the text you enter into the Value attribute.
Fails if the Item value is equal to the text you enter into the Value attribute.

Passes if the Item value is completely contained in the text you enter into the Value attribute.
Fails if the Item value is not completely contained in the text you enter into the Value attribute.

lovValues.d: Item is NOT contained in Value
lovValues.helpText:
Passes if the Item value is not completely contained in the text you enter into the Value attribute.
Fails if the Item value is completely contained in the text you enter into the Value attribute.

lovValues.d: Item contains only characters specified in Value
lovValues.helpText:
Passes if the Item value contains only characters found in the text you enter into the Value attribute.
Fails if the Item value contains any characters that are not in the text you enter into the Value attribute.

lovValues.d: Item contains at least one of the characters in Value
lovValues.helpText:
Passes if the Item value includes at least one character from the the text you enter into the Value attribute.
Fails if the Item value does not include any characters from the text you enter into the Value attribute.

lovValues.d: Item does NOT contain any of the characters in Value
lovValues.helpText:
Passes if the Item value does not include any characters from the text you enter into the Value attribute.
Fails if the Item value includes at least one character from the text you enter into the Value attribute.

Passes if the Item value matches the regular expression you enter into the Value attribute. Fails if the Item value does not match the regular expression you enter into the Value attribute.
Note: Regular expressions enable you to search for patterns in string data by using standardized syntax conventions, rather than just a straight character comparisons.

4961.name: VAL_SQL_STATEMENT
4961.examples:
For Rows Returned, to pass the validation, and not raise an error message, when the employee is in department 30:
select 1
  from emp
 where empno  = :P2_EMPNO
   and deptno = 30
For No Rows Returned 
select 1
  from emp
 where empno  = :P2_EMPNO
   and deptno <> 40
4961.helpText: Enter a SQL query to define this validation.

4962.name: VAL_SQL_EXPRESSION
4962.examples:
To pass the validation, and not raise an error message, when the employee is a manager or the department is located in Chicago:
:P2_JOB = 'MANAGER' or
exists ( select 1
           from dept
          where deptno = :P2_DEPTNO
            and loc    = 'CHICAGO' )
4962.helpText:
Enter a SQL expression to define this validation.
Use SQL Expression to enter complex "where" conditions

4963.name: VAL_PLSQL_EXPRESSION
4963.examples:
To pass the validation, and not raise an error message, when the employee is in department 30 or is a manager:
( :P2_DEPTNO = 30 or :P2_JOB = 'MANAGER' )
4963.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL expression to define the validation.

4964.name: VAL_PLSQL_FUNCTION_BODY_BOOLEAN
4964.examples:
To pass the validation, and not raise an error message, when the employee is in department 30:
begin
    if :P2_DEPTNO = 30 then
        return true;
    else
        return false;
    end if;
end;
4964.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL function body that returns a BOOLEAN value as the basis for this validation.

4965.name: VAL_PLSQL_FUNCTION_BODY_VARCHAR2
4965.prompt: PL/SQL Function Body Returning Error Text
4965.examples:
To pass the validation, and not raise the sepcified error message, when the employee is in department 30:
begin
    if :P2_DEPTNO <> 30 then
        return 'Employee is in Department ' || :P2_DEPTNO || ' and not Department 30';
    end if;
    return null;
end;
4965.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL function body that returns the error message text as the basis for this validation.

4966.name: VAL_PLSQL
4966.examples:
To pass the validation, and not raise the sepcified error, when the employee is in department 30:
begin
    if :P2_DEPTNO <> 30 then
        raise_application_error( -20000, 'Employee is in Department ' || :P2_DEPTNO || ' and not Department 30' );
    end if;
end;
4966.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL expression that raises an error as the basis for this validation.

4967.name: VAL_ITEM
4967.helpText: Enter a page or application item used in this validation. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items.

4968.name: VAL_VALUE
4968.helpText: Enter the value used to compare against the value of the item column specified for this validation.

4969.name: VAL_REGULAR_EXPRESSION
4969.helpText: Enter the regular expression used to match the item specified for this validation.

Fails if the Column value includes at least one character from the text you enter into the Value attribute.

Passes if the Column value matches the regular expression you enter into the Value attribute. Fails if the Column value does not match the regular expression you enter into the Value attribute.
Note: Regular expressions enable you to search for patterns in string data by using standardized syntax conventions, rather than just a straight character comparisons.

4981.name: REGION_VAL_SQL_STATEMENT
4981.examples:
For Rows Returned, to pass the validation, and not raise an error message, when the employee is in department 30:
select 1
  from emp
 where empno  = :P2_EMPNO
   and deptno = 30
For No Rows Returned 
select 1
  from emp
 where empno  = :P2_EMPNO
   and deptno <> 40
4981.helpText: Enter a SQL query to define this validation.

4982.name: REGION_VAL_SQL_EXPRESSION
4982.examples:
To pass the validation, and not raise an error message, when the employee is a manager or the department is located in Chicago:
:P2_JOB = 'MANAGER' or
exists ( select 1
           from dept
          where deptno = :P2_DEPTNO
            and loc    = 'CHICAGO' )
4982.helpText:
Enter a SQL expression to define this validation.
Use SQL Expression to enter complex "where" conditions

4983.name: REGION_VAL_PLSQL_EXPRESSION
4983.examples:
To pass the validation, and not raise an error message, when the employee is in department 30 or is a manager:
( :P2_DEPTNO = 30 or :P2_JOB = 'MANAGER' )
4983.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL expression to define the validation.

4984.name: REGION_VAL_PLSQL_FUNCTION_BODY_BOOLEAN
4984.examples:
To pass the validation, and not raise an error message, when the employee is in department 30:
begin
    if :P2_DEPTNO = 30 then
        return true;
    else
        return false;
    end if;
end;
4984.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL function body that returns a BOOLEAN value as the basis for this validation.

4985.name: REGION_VAL_PLSQL_FUNCTION_BODY_VARCHAR2
4985.prompt: PL/SQL Function Body Returning Error Text
4985.examples:
To pass the validation, and not raise the sepcified error message, when the employee is in department 30:
begin
    if :P2_DEPTNO <> 30 then
        return 'Employee is in Department ' || :P2_DEPTNO || ' and not Department 30';
    end if;
    return null;
end;
4985.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL function body that returns the error message text as the basis for this validation.

4986.name: REGION_VAL_PLSQL
4986.examples:
To pass the validation, and not raise the sepcified error, when the employee is in department 30:
begin
    if :P2_DEPTNO <> 30 then
        raise_application_error( -20000, 'Employee is in Department ' || :P2_DEPTNO || ' and not Department 30' );
    end if;
end;
4986.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL expression that raises an error as the basis for this validation.

  •   Yellow   #FFFF00 RGB(255,255,0)

  •   Green   #008000 RGB(0,128,0)
  •   Aqua   #00FFFF RGB(0,255,255)

  •   White   #FFFFFF RGB(255,255,255)
504.helpText:
Enter the color used to display the font for the specified attribute.

The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names. Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

5151.name: LINK_CONDITION_SQL_STATEMENT
5151.examples:
To return successfully as one or more rows exist when checking if the employee is in department 30:
select 1
  from emp
 where empno  = :P2_EMPNO
   and deptno = 30
To return successfully as no rows exist when checking if the employee is in department 40:
select 1
  from emp
 where empno  = :P2_EMPNO
   and deptno = 40
5151.helpText: Enter a SQL query for this condition.

5152.name: LINK_CONDITION_SQL_EXPRESSION
5152.examples:
To return successfully when the employee is a manager and their department is located in Chicago:
:P2_JOB = 'MANAGER' and
exists ( select 1
           from dept
          where deptno = :P2_DEPTNO
            and loc    = 'CHICAGO' )
5152.helpText:
Enter a SQL Expression for this condition.
Use SQL Expression to enter complex "where" conditions.

5153.name: LINK_CONDITION_PLSQL_EXPRESSION
5153.examples:
To return successfully when the employee is in department 30 or is a manager:
( :P2_DEPTNO = 30 or :P2_JOB = 'MANAGER' )
5153.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL Expression for this condition.

5154.name: LINK_CONDITION_PLSQL_FUNCTION_BODY
5154.examples:
To return successfully when the employee is in department 30:
begin
    if :P2_DEPTNO = 30 then
        return true;
    else
        return false;
    end if;
end;
5154.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL Function Body that returns a boolean value for this condition.

532.name: AUTOMATIC_REFRESH
532.helpText: Specify whether to enable asynchronous graph updates. Enabling Automatic Refresh refreshes the graph automatically based on the Interval you provide.

533.name: AUTOMATIC_REFRESH_INTERVAL
533.helpText: Enter the interval in seconds between chart updates. Very small updates intervals, such as 2 seconds, are discouraged since they may cause serious database performance issues.

534.name: USE_CUSTOM_XML
534.helpText: Specify whether the generated chart XML is overriden by custom chart XML. If you choose to use custom XML, attributes under Display Settings, Axes Settings, Legend Settings, Font Settings and Chart Title are not used.

535.name: CUSTOM_XML
535.helpText:
Enter the custom Chart XML for this chart. Please refer to the AnyChart XML documentation for further details:

  • Flash Charting Component - XML Reference

536.name: SHOW_LEGEND
536.helpText: Select where to display a legend for your chart. You can chose to not have a legend, or choose from various locations to display the chart legend.

537.name: LEGEND_TITLE
537.helpText: Enter a title to display at the top of the chart legend.

538.name: LEGEND_ELEMENT_ORIENTATION
538.helpText: Select the orientation for the chart legend elements.

539.name: SHOW_LEGEND_BACKGROUND
539.helpText: Specify whether the legend background is visible on your chart.

54.name: COMPUTATION_SQL_STATEMENT
54.helpText: Enter a SQL query that provides a value used to populate the computation item. If the result contains multiple rows then only the value from the first row is returned.

540.name: CHART_MARGIN_TOP
540.helpText: Enter a value for the size of the blank space displayed above the chart.

541.name: CHART_MARGIN_BOTTOM
541.helpText: Enter a value for the size of the blank space displayed below the chart.

542.name: CHART_MARGIN_LEFT
542.helpText: Enter a value for the size of the blank space displayed on the left side of the chart.

543.name: CHART_MARGIN_RIGHT
543.helpText: Enter a value for the size of the blank space displayed on the right side of the chart.

544.name: CHART_WIDTH
544.helpText:
Enter the width of the chart in pixels. The width defines a fixed width for your chart region. Alternatively, to enable automatic resizing of the chart width, leave this item empty. The width is then automatically set to 100% of the region.

By default, a chart created on a page using the jQuery Mobile Smartphone user interface has no value set for width and correctly resizes to fit the device it is being rendered on.

545.name: CHART_HEIGHT
545.helpText:
Enter the height of the chart in pixels. The height defines a fixed height for your chart region. Alternatively, to enable automatic resizing of the chart height, leave this item empty. The height is then based upon the height of the browser.

By default, a chart created on a page using the jQuery Mobile Smartphone user interface has no value set for height, and correctly resizes to fit the device it is being rendered on.

546.name: COLOR_SCHEME
546.helpText: Select a pre-built color scheme for your chart. Charts with a single series use one color for each datapoint, while charts with multiple series use one color for each series. Look 7 uses the AnyChart default palette of colors, applying a different color to each datapoint in a single series. If you wish to define your own color schemes, you can select Custom and define your own set of colors in Custom Colors.

547.name: CHART_COLOR_LEVEL
547.helpText: Select the color scheme level for your chart. By default, the level is set to Series.

lovValues.helpText: Charts with a single series use one color for each datapoint, while charts with multiple series use one color for each series.
Different colors are applied to each datapoint in a single series.

548.name: HATCH_PATTERN
548.helpText: Specify whether to apply a pre-built hatch pattern for your chart. Charts with a single series use a different pattern for each datapoint.

549.name: CUSTOM_COLORS
549.examples:
Comma separated list of colors using HEX notation
#005381,#0D813D,#BB8199
Colors stored in a page item
P1_COLORS

Refer to the AnyChart Colors Table for a full list of supported colors.
549.helpText:
Enter colors separated by commas, or an item in the application that holds a comma separated list of colors. This set of custom colors is used to automatically change the defined chart colors, providing you select Custom for the Color Scheme.

The colors is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names.

Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

55.name: COMPUTATION_SQL_EXPRESSION
55.helpText: Enter a SQL Expression that produces a value used to populate the computation item.

550.name: CHART_ANIMATION
550.helpText: Select an animation to control the initial appearance of this chart.

551.name: MARKER
551.helpText:
Select the marker design to display on the chart. A marker is an object with a specified shape, size, and color used to identify values on your chart. A selected marker is applied to the chart series items and also to the series item in the chart legend.

Selecting the Default option applies a unique marker to each series of a multi-series chart. Markers can be applied to charts of type 2D Line, Scatter Marker, 2D Pie, 3D Pie, and 2D Doughnut. For Column and Bar charts, the Series Type of a chart series query must be set to Line or Marker, in order to display markers on a chart.

552.name: SERIES_STYLE
552.helpText: Select the series style for this chart. The visual appearance of the data elements on your chart is defined using certain styles.

553.name: BACKGROUND_COLOR_TYPE
553.helpText: Select a background color type for this chart.

lovValues.helpText: Makes the chart background area transparent.
Uses the specified background color for the chart.
Fades between the two specified background colors, along the specified angle.
