557.name: BACKGROUND_GRADIENT_ANGLE
557.helpText: Specify the angle in degrees for the background gradient. A value of 0 results in a horizontal gradient fading from left to right.

559.name: X_AXIS_INVERTED
559.helpText: Specify whether to display the X-Axis scale in an inverted mode.

56.name: COMPUTATION_PLSQL_EXPRESSION
56.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL expression that produces a value used to populate the computation item.

562.name: X_AXIS_PREFIX
562.helpText: Enter text to display before X-Axis values. This text prefix appears before grid labels, value labels, and hint text. For example, you can enter a currency symbol as a prefix.

563.name: X_AXIS_POSTFIX
563.helpText: Enter text to display after X-Axis values. This text postfix appears after grid labels, value labels, and hint text. For example, you can enter a percentage symbol as a postfix.

564.name: X_AXIS_MAJOR_INTERVAL
564.helpText: Enter the major scale step, used for the X-Axis labels, major tickmarks, and major grid on your chart. If not set, this value is calculated automatically. The value entered must be a positive number.

565.name: X_AXIS_MINOR_INTERVAL
565.helpText: Enter the minor scale step, used for the X-Axis labels, minor tickmarks, and  minor grid on your chart. If not set, this value is calculated automatically. The value entered must be a positive number.

566.name: X_AXIS_DECIMAL_PLACES
566.helpText: Enter the number of decimal places to use in X-Axis values.

567.name: X_AXIS_LABEL_ROTATION
567.helpText:
Enter the rotation, in degrees, for the X-Axis chart labels. Positive values rotate the labels clockwise, whereas negative values rotate the labels counterclockwise. The Font Face setting for labels does not apply to rotated text.

Note: Labels must contain only ASCII characters if they are to be rotated.

568.name: X_AXIS_TITLE
568.helpText: Enter a title for the X-Axis. This title describes the labels along the X-Axis of your chart.

569.name: CHART_GRID_TYPE
569.helpText: Select on what axes to show the chart grids. Grids can greatly improve chart readability and aid in visually comparing different values.

57.name: COMPUTATION_PLSQL_FUNCTION_BODY
57.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL function body that returns a value used to populate the computation item.

570.name: SHOW_SCROLLBARS
570.helpText: Select on which axes to include scroll bars.

571.name: Y_AXIS_TITLE
571.helpText: Enter a title for the Y-Axis. This title describes the labels along the Y-Axis of your chart.

572.name: Y_AXIS_MIN
572.helpText: Enter a value for the smallest data value you want to appear on the Y-Axis.

573.name: Y_AXIS_MAX
573.helpText: Enter a value for the highest data value you want to appear on the Y-Axis.

574.name: EXTRA_Y_AXIS_MIN
574.helpText: Enter a value for the smallest data value you want to appear on the extra Y-axis when multiple Y-axes are in use. This value is only be applied to the scale settings for the extra Y-axis.

575.name: EXTRA_Y_AXIS_MAX
575.helpText: Enter a value for the highest data value you want to appear on the extra Y-axis when multiple Y-axes are in use. This value is only be applied to the scale settings for the extra Y-axis.

576.name: Y_AXIS_PREFIX
576.helpText: Enter text to display before Y-Axis values. This text prefix appears before grid labels, value labels, and hint text. For example, you can enter a currency symbol as a prefix.

577.name: Y_AXIS_POSTFIX
577.helpText: Enter text to display after Y-Axis values. This text postfix appears after grid labels, value labels and hint text. For example, you can enter a percentage symbol as a postfix.

578.name: Y_AXIS_MAJOR_INTERVAL
578.helpText: Enter the major scale step, used for the Y-Axis labels, major tickmarks, and major grid on your chart. If not set, this value is calculated automatically. The value entered must be a positive number.

579.name: Y_AXIS_MINOR_INTERVAL
579.helpText: Enter the minor scale step, used for the Y-Axis labels, minor tickmarks and minor grid on your chart. If not set, this value is calculated automatically. The value entered must be a positive number.

58.name: COMPUTATION_ITEM_VALUE
58.helpText: Enter the item whose value is used to populate the computation item. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items.

580.name: Y_AXIS_DECIMAL_PLACES
580.helpText: Enter number of decimal places to use in Y-Axis values.

581.name: Y_AXIS_LABEL_ROTATION
581.helpText:
Enter the amount of rotation, in degrees, for the Y-Axis chart labels. Positive values rotate the labels clockwise, whereas negative values rotate the labels counter-clockwise. The Font Face setting for labels does not apply to rotated text.

Note: Labels must contain only ASCII characters if they are to be rotated.

582.name: GAUGE_START_ANGLE
582.helpText: Enter the start angle in degrees for the gauge chart. Positive values indicate clockwise start angle. Negative values indicate counterclockwise start angle. You may draw your circular gauge at any angle you want and change its shape according to the chosen angle. The shape of your gauge depends on 3 things: Start Angle, Sweep Angle, and the type Frame.

583.name: GAUGE_SWEEP_ANGLE
583.helpText: Enter the sweep angle in degrees for the gauge chart. The Sweep Angle is an actual angle of your circular gauge chart. Positive values indicate clockwise sweep angle. Negative values indicate counterclockwise sweep angle. You may draw your circular gauge at any angle you want and change its shape according to the chosen angle. The shape of your gauge depends on 3 things: Start Angle, Sweep Angle, and the type Frame.

584.name: GAUGE_MAJOR_INTERVAL
584.helpText: Enter the interval between major tickmarks on your gauge chart.  Major tickmarks are the small marks used to represent a point on an axis scale and they indicate major step of an axis scale.

585.name: GAUGE_MINOR_INTERVAL
585.helpText: Enter the interval between minor tickmarks on your gauge chart.  Minor tickmarks are the small marks used to represent a point on an axis scale and they indicate minor step of an axis scale.

586.name: VALUE_PREFIX
586.helpText: Enter text to display before value labels. This text prefix displays before value labels and hint text.  For example, you can enter a currency symbol as a prefix.

587.name: VALUE_POSTFIX
587.helpText: Enter text to display after value labels. This text prefix displays after value labels and hint text.  For example, you can enter a percentage symbol as a postfix.

588.name: VALUE_DECIMAL_PLACES
588.helpText: Enter the number of decimal places to use in value labels.

589.name: LABEL_ROTATION
589.helpText:
Enter the amount of rotation in degrees for the chart labels. Positive values rotate the labels clockwise. Negative values rotate the labels counterclockwise. The Font Face setting for labels does not apply to rotated text.

Note: Labels must contain only ASCII characters if they are to be rotated.

59.name: COMPUTATION_PREFERENCE_VALUE
59.helpText: Enter a User Preference that has a value used to populate the computation item.

590.name: GAUGE_LABEL_ALIGNMENT
590.helpText: Select the alignment of the labels on your Gauge chart.

591.name: GAUGE_POINTER
591.helpText: Select the type of pointer to apply to your Gauge chart.

592.name: GAUGE_FRAME_TYPE
592.helpText: Select the shape of the frame for your Circular gauge. A frame is required to adjust the borders of your gauge.

593.name: CHART_LABEL_POSITION
593.helpText: Select the position of the labels on your chart.

594.name: GANTT_ACTUAL_START
594.helpText: Select a marker to be used when rendering the selected task bar starting point.

595.name: GANTT_ACTUAL_END
595.helpText: Select a marker to be used when rendering the selected task bar end point.

596.name: GANTT_ACTUAL_SHAPE
596.helpText: Select a shape to be used when rendering the middle section of the selected task bar.

597.name: GANTT_PROGRESS_START
597.helpText: Select a marker to be used when rendering the selected task bar starting point.

598.name: GANTT_PROGRESS_END
598.helpText: Select a marker to be used when rendering the selected task bar end point.

599.name: GANTT_PROGRESS_SHAPE
599.helpText: Select a shape to be used when rendering the middle section of the selected task bar.

6.name: ERROR_MESSAGE
6.helpText:
Enter the text to be displayed in the event that the validation does not pass.

You can use #LABEL# as placeholder for the label of the associated page item or #COLUMN_HEADER# for the heading of the associated editable region column. The placeholders are not supported if error display location is set to On Error Page.

60.name: EXECUTION_SEQUENCE
60.helpText:
Specify the sequence for this component. The sequence determines the order of execution.

Note: If two components have the same sequence value, then they may be executed in a different order when the application is exported and imported into another environment.

600.name: GANTT_BASELINE_START
600.helpText: Select a marker to be used when rendering the selected task bar starting point.

601.name: GANTT_BASELINE_END
601.helpText: Select a marker to be used when rendering the selected task bar end point.

602.name: GANTT_BASELINE_SHAPE
602.helpText: Select a shape to be used when rendering the middle section of the selected task bar.

603.name: GANTT_SHOW_NAVIGATION_BAR
603.helpText: Specify whether the navigation bar is visible on your Gantt chart.

604.name: GANTT_SHOW_DATAGRID
604.helpText: Specify whether the datagrid is visible to the left of your Gantt chart.

605.name: GANTT_DATE_FORMAT
605.helpText: Select the date format to be used in the Gantt chart. If no value is specified, the default date format is derived from the Application Date Format. If no Application Date Format is specified, the default date format is derived from the database session at runtime. This date format is used to alter the dates displayed on a Gantt chart. This value can be a literal string containing a valid AnyChart date format mask, such as %MMMM.

606.name: GANTT_INCLUDE_ON_DATAGRID
606.helpText: Select the options to display on the Datagrid of your Gantt chart.

lovValues.helpText: Display the task ID on the Datagrid.
Display the task name on the Datagrid.
Display the Actual Start Date for the task on the Datagrid.
Ddisplay the Actual End Date for the task on the Datagrid.

607.name: GANTT_TIMELINE_HEIGHT
607.helpText: Enter the height of the lines on your Gantt chart, in degrees.

608.name: GANTT_ITEM_HEIGHT
608.helpText: Enter the height of the Bar (task or period) on the plot of your Gantt chart, in degrees.

609.name: GANTT_ITEM_PADDING
609.helpText: Enter the Top bar padding, in pixels.

61.name: COMPUTATION_POINT
61.helpText: Select at what point in page rendering or processing this computation is executed. The most typical computation point is After Submit.

lovValues.helpText: Executes when a new session is generated.
Rendering: Executes before the page renders.
Rendering: Executes after the header renders.
Rendering: Executes before regions render.
Rendering: Executes after regions render.
Rendering: Executes before footer renders.
Rendering: Executes after footer renders.
Processing: Executes after the page is submitted, but before page processing.

610.name: GANTT_START_DATE_TYPE
610.helpText: Select the type of start date to display in this Gantt chart.

611.name: GANTT_START_DATE
611.helpText:
Enter the start date value for this Gantt chart.
To focus the Timeline on the given part of the time scale, you can set what range displays at start up.
The Timeline Start Date must be a valid date prior to the Timeline End Date.

612.name: GANTT_START_DATE_ITEM
612.helpText: Select the page or application item holding the start date of the Timeline range to display at start up.

613.name: GANTT_END_DATE_TYPE
613.helpText: Select the type of end date to display in this Gantt chart.

614.name: GANTT_END_DATE
614.helpText:
Enter the end date value to focus the Timeline on the given part of the time scale.
The Timeline End Date must be a valid date after the Timeline Start Date.

615.name: GANTT_END_DATE_ITEM
615.helpText: Select the page or application item holding the end date of the Timeline range to display at start up.

616.name: SHOW_TOOLTIP
616.helpText: Specify whether to display tooltips on your chart. Tooltips display when a user hovers the mouse over the chart's data.

617.name: SHOW_VALUE
617.helpText: Specify whether to display values on your chart. Values are derived from your chart query and display next to your chart data.

618.name: SHOW_LABEL
618.helpText: Specify whether to display labels on your chart. Labels are derived from your chart query and display along a chart axis.

619.name: GROUP_BY_SERIES
619.helpText:
Specify whether to display data on your multi-series chart by grouping columns by series.
Data on a multi-series chart can be grouped in two different ways, either by column or by grouping columns by series.

62.name: EVENT
62.helpText:
Specify the event that causes the dynamic action to fire. For information about specific events, please see the relevant section in the App Builder User's Guide.

Events are categrorized into the following types:
Browser Events
Standard browser events.
Framework Events
Framework events are triggered from within the Application Express framework.
Component Events
Only available when there is a component available to your application that triggers a custom event. These events are triggered from either native components or plug-in components you have installed in your application.
Custom Event
Any custom event triggered from your application.

Note: The events displayed differ based on page's current User Interface type. If you wish to select an event that corresponds to a different type, then you have the option of selecting Show unsupported, which displays all events including those that do not correspond to the current type.

620.name: SHOW_MAJOR_TICKS
620.helpText:
Specify whether the major tick marks display on the gauge chart.
Major tick marks are the small marks used to represent major steps of an axis scale.

621.name: SHOW_MINOR_TICKS
621.helpText:
Specify if minor tick marks display on the gauge chart.
Minor tick marks are the small marks used to represent minor steps of an axis scale.

622.name: SHOW_TICK_LABELS
622.helpText: Specify whether labels display in conjunction with the tick marks.

623.name: Y_AXIS_INVERTED
623.helpText: Specify whether to display the Y-Axis scale in an inverted mode.

624.name: SCALE_INVERTED
624.helpText: Specify whether to display the scale of a Gauge chart in an inverted mode.

625.name: Y_AXIS_OVERLAY
625.helpText: Specify whether to display the Y-Axis scale in an overlay mode, where bars are shown one over another.

626.name: Y_AXIS_OVERLAY_SORTED
626.helpText: Specify whether to display the Y-Axis scale in a sorted overlay mode. In sorted overlay mode, the series is sorted and displayed with lower values in front of higher values.

627.name: SMART_AXIS_CALCULATION
627.helpText:
Specify whether to apply a smart auto calculation mode to the axis scale.
Smart mode takes into account the number of decimal digits and also avoids issues where duplicate items appear on the axis scale.

628.name: Y_AXIS_MULTIPLE
628.helpText:
Specify whether to display an extra Y-Axis on your chart.
The extra Y-Axis is positioned opposite to the existing Y-Axis on the chart.

629.name: 3D_MODE_HTML
629.helpText: Specify whether 3D mode is enabled for this chart.

63.name: CUSTOM_EVENT
63.helpText: Specify a custom JavaScript event name if the declarative events provided are not sufficient.

630.name: VALUES_ROTATION
630.helpText:
Enter the amount of rotation, in degrees, for the chart value labels. Positive values rotate the labels clockwise. Negative values rotate the labels counterclockwise. The Font Face setting for labels does not apply to rotated text.

Note: Labels must contain only ASCII characters if they are to be rotated.

631.name: CALENDAR_TEMPLATE
631.helpText: Select a template to use when the calendar is rendered.

632.name: DATE_COLUMN
632.helpText: Select the column from the table or query that contains the dates to be placed on the calendar.

633.name: DATE_FORMAT
633.helpText: Specify if you want to show time or only date values on your calendar.

634.name: CALENDAR_DATE_ITEM
634.helpText:
Select the page or application item that holds the start date of the calendar which is currently displayed to the end user.
This item is used by the Application Express engine when the end user selects to navigate to the previous or next period.

635.name: CALENDAR_END_DATE_ITEM
635.helpText:
Select the page or application item that holds the end date of the calendar which is currently displayed to the end user.
This item is used by the Application Express engine when the end user selects to navigate to the previous or next period.

636.name: CALENDAR_TYPE_ITEM
636.helpText: Select the page or application item that holds the calendar type which is currently displayed to the end user.

637.name: CALENDAR_DISPLAY_TYPE
637.helpText: Select the values displayed on the calendar.

lovValues.helpText: Uses the Display Column attribute to select the column to display in the calendar cell.
Enables you to enter a custom column format using HTML expressions and supported substitution strings.
No data is displayed in the calendar cells.

638.name: DISPLAY_COLUMN
638.helpText: Select the single column to display in the calendar cells.

639.name: PRIMARY_KEY_COLUMN
639.helpText: Select the column which holds the primary key for the table.

64.name: WHEN_TYPE
64.helpText: Select the type of page element or construct to be used to trigger the event. For examples of using a specific selection type, see Help on the associated attribute.

lovValues.helpText: Triggered by one or more page items.
Triggered by a button.
Triggered by a region.

Triggered by one or more columns.' ); -- store_property_lov_values ( p_property_id => l_property_id, p_display_value => 'DOM Object', p_return_value => 'DOM_OBJECT', p_is_deprecated => 'Y', p_help_text => q'~

Triggered by the DOM object (document, window) or the id of a DOM object (myElementID).

Note: DOM Object is deprecated and should be replaced by JavaScript Expression or jQuery Selector.
Triggered by one or more page elements returned by the jQuery Selector.
Triggered by the page elements returned by the JavaScript expression.

640.name: CALENDAR_CUSTOM_FORMAT
640.examples:
Display column values
#FIRST_NAME# #LAST_NAME#
Display an image in a calendar event.
<img src="#IMAGE_NAME#">
640.helpText: Enter custom text to display in calendar cells. You can enter HTML expressions and use #COLUMN_NAME# syntax to show column values. This display type enables you to enter multiple columns in the display.

641.name: BEGIN_AT_START_OF_INTERVAL
641.helpText:
Specify when the calendar starts. Selecting this option creates a calendar that spans an entire interval such as a month.

  • If Begin at start of interval is selected, the date is June 15th, and the display is monthly, the resulting calendar spans from June 1st to June 30th.
  • If Begin at start of interval is not selected, the date is June 15th, and the display is monthly, the resulting calendar spans from June 15th to June 30th.

642.name: START_OF_WEEK_FOR_MONTHLY_CALENDAR
642.helpText: Determines the day of the week on which the monthly calendar starts.

643.name: START_DAY_FOR_WEEKLY_CALENDAR
643.helpText: Select the first day of the week displayed on the weekly calendar. You can use this attribute in conjunction with End Day to restrict the days of the week displayed, or simply specify the first day of the week displayed.

644.name: END_DAY_FOR_WEEKLY_CALENDAR
644.helpText: Select the last day of the week displayed on the weekly calendar. You can use this attribute in conjunction with Start Day to restrict the days of the week displayed, or select the day before the Start Day value to show all seven days.

645.name: TIME_FORMAT
645.helpText: Select how to display the time format.

646.name: START_TIME
646.helpText: Enter the start hour to focus the display of the weekly and daily calendar.

647.name: END_TIME
647.helpText: Enter the end hour to focus the display of the weekly and daily calendar.

648.name: DATA_BACKGROUND_COLOR
648.examples:
Examples of major HTML color codes include -
  •   Black   #000000 RGB(0,0,0)
  •   Red   #FF0000 RGB(255,0,0)
  •   Yellow   #FFFF00 RGB(255,255,0)
  •   Lime   #00FF00 RGB(0,255,0)
  •   Green   #008000 RGB(0,128,0)
  •   Aqua   #00FFFF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Blue   #0000FF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Navy   #000080 RGB(0,0,128)
  •   White   #FFFFFF RGB(255,255,255)
648.helpText:
Enter the color used for the background of the data displayed in this calendar.

The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names. Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

649.name: DATA_TEXT_COLOR
649.examples:
Examples of major HTML color codes include -
  •   Black   #000000 RGB(0,0,0)
  •   Red   #FF0000 RGB(255,0,0)
  •   Yellow   #FFFF00 RGB(255,255,0)
  •   Lime   #00FF00 RGB(0,255,0)
  •   Green   #008000 RGB(0,128,0)
  •   Aqua   #00FFFF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Blue   #0000FF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Navy   #000080 RGB(0,0,128)
  •   White   #FFFFFF RGB(255,255,255)
649.helpText:
Enter the color used for the data in this calendar.

The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names. Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

65.name: WHEN_REGION
65.helpText:
Select the name of the region that triggers the dynamic action. For example this could be an 'Interactive Report' region, used in conjunction with an 'After Refresh' event, to define a dynamic action that fire whenever the report refreshes.

Having region trigger a dynamic action can be useful when you want to define similar behavior for multiple page items in a region. However, this is only possible for certain events that are raised by items within that region. For a list of events that support this type of definition and an example of how they could be utilized, see item Help for the Affected Elements > Selection Type of Event Scope on the Action page.

651.name: LIST_VIEW_DAYS_DISPLAY
651.helpText: Select the days to display for the List View.

lovValues.helpText: Display the calendar entries for the current month.
Display the calendar entries for the current year.
Display the calendar entries based on the number of days you enter.

652.name: LIST_VIEW_CUSTOM_DAYS
652.helpText: Enter the total number of days to display in the Agenda View.

653.name: OPEN_LINK_IN
653.helpText: Specify if the page or URL replaces the current page or opens in a dialog.

654.name: ENTRY_LINK_TARGET
654.helpText: Click Target to invoke a modal dialog. You can enter the target link the calendar calls to view the details of an existing event.

657.name: DAY_LINK_TARGET
657.helpText: Click Target to invoke a modal dialog. You can enter the target link the calendar calls when creating an event by clicking on a calendar cell outside of an existing event.

658.name: DRAG_DROP_PROCESS
658.examples:
Custom process
declare
    l_date_value        varchar2(32767) := apex_application.g_x01;
    l_primary_key_value varchar2(32767) := apex_application.g_x02;
begin
    update emp
       set hiredate = to_date(l_date_value, 'YYYYMMDD HH24MISS')
     where rowid    = l_primary_key_value;
end;
658.helpText: Define the PL/SQL process to be executed when a Calendar entry is dragged and dropped.

659.name: DRAG_AND_DROP_AUTHORIZATION_SCHEME
659.helpText:
Select an authorization scheme to limit who has rights to update existiing claendar events using drag and drop.
If specified, this authorization scheme must evaluate to TRUE in order for the drag and drop to be processed.

66.name: WHEN_BUTTON
66.helpText: Select the button to trigger the dynamic action.

660.name: DIALOG_CSS_CLASSES
660.helpText: Enter classes to add to this component. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

661.name: ZOOM_PANEL
661.helpText: Specify whether or not a zoom panel displays on this map.

662.name: NAVIGATION_PANEL
662.helpText: Specify whether or not a navigation panel displays on this map.

663.name: LEGEND_ITEM_SOURCE
663.helpText: Select the source for the map legend elements.

lovValues.helpText: Use series when the legend is required to display ranges rather than specific data for each section.
Use points to include specific data within the map legend.

664.name: UNDEFINED_MAP_SET_COLORS
664.helpText:
Specify whether to apply a color scheme to the undefined map regions.
The undefined map regions are those with no corresponding data points in a series on your map.

665.name: UNDEFINED_MAP_COLOR_SCHEME
665.helpText: Select a pre-built color scheme for your map. Maps with a single series use one color for each datapoint, while maps with multiple series use one color for each series. Look 7 uses the AnyChart default palette of colors, applying a different color to each datapoint in a single series. If you wish to define your own color schemes, you can select Custom and define your own set of colors in Custom Colors.

666.name: UNDEFINED_MAP_CUSTOM_COLORS
666.examples:
Comma separated list of colors using HEX notation
#005381,#0D813D,#BB8199
Colors stored in a page item
P1_COLORS

Refer to the AnyChart Colors Table for a full list of supported colors.
666.helpText:
Enter colors separated by commas, or an uppercase page or application item, that holds a comma separated list of colors. This set of custom colors is used to change undefined map region colors automatically, providing you selected Custom for the Color Scheme.

The colors is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names.

Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

667.name: MAP_GRID_TYPE
667.helpText: Select the type of grid and grid lines to display on your map.

lovValues.helpText: Display no grid on the map.
Display the grid without any longitude or latitude lines on the map.
Display the longitude lines on the map.
Display the latitude lines on the map.
Display the both longitude and latitude lines on the map.

668.name: MAP_PROJECTION
668.helpText: Select the map projection type. A map projection is any method used in cartography to represent the two-dimensional curved surface of the earth or other body on a plane. The term projection refers to any function defined on the earth's surface and with values on the plane, and not necessarily a geometric projection.

lovValues.helpText: A Bonne projection is a pseudoconical equal-area map projection.
Pseudocylindrical, neither conformal or equal-area.
Pseudocylindrical, neither conformal or equal-area.
The equirectangular projection is a very simple map projection. The projection maps meridians to equally spaced vertical straight lines, and parallels to equally spaced horizontal straight lines.
Fahey Modified Gall, pseudocylindrical, neither conformal or equal-area.
Hammer-Aitoff projection produces an equal area map of the entire globe, it is useful for visual representations of geographically related statistical data and distributions.

The Mercator projection is a cylindrical map projection. It became the standard map projection for nautical purposes because of its ability to represent lines of constant true bearing or true course, known as rhumb lines, as straight line segments. While the direction and shapes are accurate on a Mercator projection, it distorts the size.

Orthographic projection is a perspective (or azimuthal) projection, in which the sphere is projected onto a tangent plane or secant plane. The point of perspective for the Orthographic projection is at infinite distance.
A pseudocylindrical projection by reason of its straight parallels, along each of which the meridians are spaced evenly.
A pseudocylindrical projection, neither conformal or equal-area.

669.name: VALUE_DISPLAY_MODE
669.helpText: Select the display mode for map region values.

67.name: WHEN_ITEMS
67.helpText:
Enter page or application items to trigger the dynamic action.
For multiple items, separate each item name with a comma.
You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items.
If you pick from the list and there is already text entered, a comma is placed at the end of the existing text, followed by the item name returned from the list.

670.name: DEFINED_MAP_COLOR_SCHEME
670.helpText: Select a pre-built color scheme for this map. Maps with a single series use one color for each data point, while maps with multiple series use one color for each series. Look 7 uses the AnyChart default palette of colors, applying a different color to each data point in a single series. If you wish to define your own color schemes, you can select Custom and define your own set of colors in Custom Colors.

68.name: WHEN_DOM_OBJECT
68.helpText:
Enter either a DOM object (document, window) or the id of a DOM object (myElementID) as the element to trigger the dynamic action.

Note: DOM Object is deprecated and should be replaced by JavaScript Expression or jQuery Selector.

685.name: MAP_COLOR_LEVEL
685.helpText: Select the color scheme level for the regions of this map.

lovValues.helpText: Maps with a single series use one color for each datapoint, while maps with multiple series use one color for each series.
Different colors are applied to each datapoint in a single series.

686.name: DEFINED_MAP_CUSTOM_COLORS
686.examples:
Comma separated list of colors using HEX notation
#005381,#0D813D,#BB8199
Colors stored in a page item
P1_COLORS

Refer to the AnyChart Colors Table for a full list of supported colors.
686.helpText:
Enter colors separated by commas, or an item in the application that holds a comma separated list of colors. This set of custom colors is used to automatically change the defined map region colors, providing you select Custom for the Color Scheme.

The colors is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names.

Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

689.name: GRID_BACKGROUND_COLOR_TYPE
689.helpText: Select a background color type for this chart.

lovValues.helpText: Makes the chart background area transparent.
Uses the specified background color for the chart.
Fades between the two specified background colors, along the specified angle.

69.name: WHEN_JQUERY_SELECTOR
69.examples:
To select a page element with an DOM id of my_id
#my_id
To select all the page elements with a class of my_class
.my_class
To select all the page elements that are inputs
input
69.helpText:
Enter jQuery Selector syntax to return one or more page element to trigger the dynamic action. The jQuery library offers a very powerful selector syntax which provides a way to easily access one or more elements from a page.

Please see the official documentation available from the jQuery homepage for further information about the selector syntax.

690.helpText:
Enter the color used for the background of this chart.

The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names. Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

694.name: PLAIN_LOV_IR_COLUMN_FILTER_TYPE
694.helpText: Select how to derive the list of values for the filter on the report column drop down list.

lovValues.helpText: Disable filter on list of values.
STRING and NUMBER columns derive the list of values from distinct column values. DATE columns derive the list of values from predefined date ranges.

lovValues.d: Use Defined List of Values to Filter Exact Match
lovValues.helpText: Derive the list of values from a defined list of values SQL query to create an equal filter.

lovValues.d: Use Defined List of Values to Filter Word Contains
lovValues.helpText: Derive the list of values from a defined list of values SQL query to create a contains filter.

lovValues.d: Use Named List of Values to Filter Exact Match
lovValues.helpText: Derive the list of values from the named list of values to create an equal filter.

lovValues.d: Use Named List of Values to Filter Word Contains
lovValues.helpText: Derive the list of values from the named list of values to create a contains filter.

695.name: IR_COLUMN_FILTER_NAMED_LOV
695.helpText: Select a defined named list of values. The column filter only uses the first column of the dynamic list of values query or the display value of the static list of values to filter the report data.

696.name: PLAIN_LOV_IR_COLUMN_FILTER_LOV_SQL
696.helpText: Enter a SQL query to be used in place of a automatically generated query that selects the distinct column values. The SQL query needs to return one column. Entering a SQL query can improve performance in some reports.  This list of values displays when a user clicks on a column header.

697.name: PRINT_RESPONSE_HEADER
697.helpText:
Select what information the server sends back to the browser in response to receiving an HTTP request. The response header contains the date, size and type of file that the server is sending back to the client and also data about the server itself.

The response header can be generated by Application Express based on your custom settings or passed through from the print server. If you want to specify file name and content disposition, the response header must be based on your custom settings.

698.name: PRINT_VIEW_FILE_AS
698.helpText: Select the content-disposition for the print document. Content-disposition is an extension to the MIME protocol that instructs the browser on how the document displays. Selecting Attachment instructs the browser to save a file to disk instead of displaying it inline.

699.name: PRINT_SERVER_OVERWRITE
699.helpText:
Enter an alternative print server. A print server is typically configured centrally for all workspaces in the Application Express Administration Services application.
Configuring an alternative print server at the report level makes is easier to debug and diagnose potential printing problems and also enables for the use of specific custom built end points to perform custom XSLT transformations.

70.name: JS_CONDITION
70.helpText:
Specify a client-side condition to control whether True or False actions fire. If the condition
                                  evaluates to True, then True actions fire, if the condition evaluates to False, then False actions fire.
                                  If no condition is specified, only True actions fire.

lovValues.helpText: Checks if the value of the selected Item is equal to the Value specified.
Checks if the value of the selected Item is not equal to the Value specified.
Checks if the value of the selected Item is greater than the Value specified.
Checks if the value of the selected Item is greater than or equal to the Value specified.
Checks if the value of the selected Item is less than the Value specified.
Checks if the value of the selected Item is less than or equal to the Value specified.
Checks if the selected Item is empty.
Checks if the selected Item is not empty.
Checks if the value of the selected Item is in the List specified.
Checks if the value of the selected Item is not in the List specified.
Evaluates the JavaScript Expression specified.

729.name: ENABLE_PRINTING
729.helpText: Select whether to enable report printing. Selecting Yes enables users to download a report in a variety of formats, including PDF, Microsoft Word, Microsoft Excel and HTML.

730.name: PRINT_LINK_TEXT
730.helpText:
Enter the text for the download link. To replace the link with a different navigational component, such as a button, leave this field blank. You can set up the other component to start the printing process by using a URL with the following syntax as the target:

f?p=&APP_ID.:&SESSION.:FLOW_XMLP_OUTPUT_R[REGION_ID]

Note: Replace [REGION_ID] in the string above with your region ID.

731.name: PRINT_FILE_NAME
731.helpText: Enter a name for the downloaded document. If you leave this blank, the region name is used as the file name.

732.name: PRINT_OUTPUT_FORMAT
732.helpText: Select the report output format. You can also have the output format specified by an item.

733.name: PRINT_OUTPUT_FORMAT_ITEM
733.helpText:
Enter the page or application item that holds the format value. You can include a Select List page item for users to select the output format at runtime. Valid values are

PDF
Opens the document in a PDF Previewer
RTF
Opens the document in Microsoft Word
XLS
Opens the document in Microsoft Excel
HTM
Downloads the document as an HTML file
XML
Downloads the document as an XML file

734.name: REPORT_LAYOUT
734.helpText: Select the report layout to utilize when printing the report.

735.name: PRINT_COLUMN_WIDTH_UNITS
735.helpText: Select the units used to define the column width values.

736.name: REJOIN_EXISTING_SESSIONS
736.helpText:
Use this attribute to control if Application Express should support application URLs that do not contain session IDs. When rejoin sessions is enabled, Application Express will attempt to use the session cookie to join an existing session, when a URL does not contain a session ID.

A more restrictive instance level setting overrides this page level value.

Note: Enabling rejoin sessions exposes your application to possible security breaches, as it can enable attackers to take over existing end user sessions. To learn more, see the Rejoin Sessions sections in "Managing Application Security" in the App Builder User's Guide.

lovValues.helpText: If the URL does not contain a session ID Application Express creates a new session.

If the URL goes to a public page and does not contain a session ID Application Express attempts to utilize the existing session cookie established for that application.
For applications with both public and authenticated pages, a session ID is defined after the end user authenticates.
Application Express only joins via the cookie when the session is not yet authenticated.

If the URL does not contain a session ID Application Express attempts to utilize the existing session cookie established for that application, providing the following conditions are met:

  • Session State Protection is enabled for the application and the URL includes a valid checksum. For public bookmarks, the most restrictive item level protection must be either Unrestricted or Checksum Required - Application Level.
  • OR, the URL does not contain payload (a request parameter, clear cache or data value pairs).

This setting also requires that Embed In Frames is set to Allow from same origin or to Deny for the application.

738.name: IS_VISIBLE
738.helpText: Specify whether this column is displayed or hidden. Even if hidden, columns can always be referenced using substitution syntax, &COLUMN_NAME..

739.name: ICON_CSS_CLASSES
739.helpText:
Enter the classes for the icon you want to add to the component. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

If your theme uses Font APEX then review the Universal Theme Sample Application to view available icons and modifiers.

740.name: APPEARANCE_CSS_CLASSES
740.examples:
Add the CSS classes articlenumber and highlight to the component
articlenumber highlight
740.helpText: Enter classes to add to this component. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

741.name: TEMPLATE_OPTIONS
741.helpText:
Select template options to customize the user interface of this component.

You can also modify the template options when running the application using Live Template Options. Live Template Options enables you to customize your application in real time, allowing you to preview and apply various options. To access Live Template Options, run the application from Application Builder and click Quick Edit in the developer toolbar. Hover over a page component, such as a region, and click the wrench icon ( ) displayed in the top left corner.

742.name: TEMPLATE_OPTIONS2
742.helpText:
Select template options to customize the user interface of this component.

You can also modify the template options when running the application using Live Template Options. Live Template Options enables you to customize your application in real time, allowing you to preview and apply various options. To access Live Template Options, run the application from Application Builder and click Quick Edit in the developer toolbar. Hover over a page component, such as a region, and click the wrench icon ( ) displayed in the top left corner.

743.name: DIALOG_CHAINED
743.helpText:
Select Yes if this dialog is opened by another dialog, and should reuse the same dialog window. For example, if this dialog is part of a multiple page dialog wizard, and you wish to reuse the dialog window for each step of the wizard.

Select No if this dialog is opened by another dialog, and should be opened in a new dialog window. For example, when this dialog is modal, and you wish to open it within a parent modal dialog window.

744.name: COMPUTATION_SQL_COLON
744.helpText: Enter a SQL query that provides a value used to populate the computation item. If the result contains multiple rows then the value from each row is formed into a single colon delimited value.

745.name: BUTTON_REQUEST_SOURCE_TYPE
745.helpText: This identifies the type of expression that is contained in the request source attribute.

lovValues.helpText: Set to the text entered into Static Value.
Set to the column value entered in Database Column, that is retrieved from a built-in fetch row process.
Set to the value held in session state for the Item selected.
Set to the first value returned from the SQL Query entered.
Set to a single colon separated value, which concatenates each row value, returned from the SQL Query entered.
Set to the value that results from executing the PL/SQL Expression entered.
Set to the value returned from the PL/SQL Function Body entered.
Set to the value of the Preference entered.
Set to null.

746.name: BUTTON_REQUEST_SOURCE
746.helpText: When this button is pressed the page will be submitted and the page request will be set to this value. If this value is null and the Request Source Type is Static Value, then the Button Name will be used as the request value.

747.name: BUTTON_ELEMENT_PRE_TEXT
747.helpText:
Enter additional attributes displayed before the HTML table cell that displays each individual option in a radio group or set of check boxes. You can include HTML, JavaScript, and shortcuts.

You can reference the following substitution strings:

#CURRENT_FORM_ELEMENT#
Obtains the name of the HTML form element that this page item is associated with.
#CURRENT_ITEM_NAME#
Obtains the name of the current page item.

755.examples:
Returns a reference to the browser's window DOM object.
window
Returns a reference to the browser's document DOM object.
document
jQuery selector selects all DIV elements that have a class of 'alert', and then returns a jQuery object containing all their parents.
$( "div.alert" ).parent()

758.name: NAV_LIST_TEMPLATE_OPTIONS

759.name: LOV_FUNC_BODY_RETURNING_SQL
759.prompt: PL/SQL Function Body returning SQL Query
759.examples:
Display department name, set department number
begin
    return 'select dname as d, deptno as r from dept order by 1';
end;
759.helpText:
Enter a PL/SQL function body that returns an SQL Query to populate this list of values. Generally list of value queries are of the form:

select [displayValue],
       [returnValue]
  from ...
 where ...
 order by ...

Each column selected must have a unique name or alias. Oracle recommends using an alias on any column that includes an SQL expression.

760.name: GRID_LABEL_COLUMN_SPAN
760.helpText: Select how many layout columns the label occupies.

761.name: FIXED_HEADER
761.helpText: Specify whether you would like to fix the report's column headers to the top of the Page or top of the Region, so that the column headers remain visible as the user vertically scrolls the report.

lovValues.helpText: Report header is not fixed.

Fixes the report header to the top of the current region. As the user vertically scrolls within the region, the report header will remain fixed at the top of the region. Region level fixed headings could be useful for a page containing multiple regions, for example a dashboard page.

Fixes the report header to the top of the page. As the user vertically scrolls the page, the report header will remain fixed at the top of the page. Page level fixed headings are useful for when the report is the main content on the page.

762.name: FIXED_HEADER_MAX_HEIGHT
762.helpText: Enter the maximum height for the report in pixels.

763.name: GRID_COLUMN_CSS_CLASSES
763.helpText:
Enter CSS classes you want to apply to the layout column that contains this region. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

This property can be used to provide fine grain control over the responsiveness and layout of the region's layout column as the viewport size is changed. For Universal Theme applications, there are a number of CSS modifiers you may use to extend your page components. Review the Reference section of the Universal Theme Sample Application to learn more.

766.name: JS_COND_VALUE
766.helpText: Enter the value for this condition.

767.name: JS_COND_LIST
767.helpText: Enter the comma separated list of values for this condition.

768.name: JS_COND_JAVASCRIPT_EXPRESSION
768.helpText:
Specify the JavaScript Expression to be evaluated for this condition. The code has access to the following dynamic action related attributes:

this.triggeringElement
A reference to the DOM object of the element that triggered the dynamic action.
this.browserEvent
The event object that triggered the event. Note: On load this is equal to 'load'.
this.data
Optional additional data that can be passed from the event handler.

769.name: MASTER_REGION
769.helpText:
Select the master region to which this detail region belongs.
This should be set when this region is the detail region in a master-detail relationship with another region on this page.

For the master-detail relationship to work correctly, select the column(s) in this region which are foreign keys to the master region, and specify the Master Column accordingly.

770.name: IS_EDITABLE
770.helpText:
Specify whether end users can edit this interactive grid.

Note - When the Interactive Grid is made editable a process is automatically created to process the records.

771.name: EDIT_OPERATIONS
771.helpText: Check which data manipulation operations are allowed on this interactive grid.

772.name: EDIT_ROW_OPERATIONS_COLUMN
772.helpText:
Select a column where the column value indicates if the row can be updated and/or deleted. The allowable values are:
        <dl>
          <dt>U</dt>
            <dd>Row can be updated</dd>
          <dt>D</dt>
            <dd>Row can be deleted</dd>
          <dt>UD</dt>
            <dd>Row can be updated or deleted</dd>
		</dl>

773.name: ADD_AUTHORIZATION_SCHEME
773.helpText:
Select an authorization scheme to restrict who can add rows.
In order for an end user to add rows, this authorization scheme must evaluate to TRUE for that user.
If no authorization scheme is provided then any user can add rows in this interactive grid.

774.name: UPDATE_AUTHORIZATION_SCHEME
774.helpText:
Select an authorization scheme to restrict who can update rows.
In order for an end user to update rows, this authorization scheme must evaluate to TRUE for that user.
If no authorization scheme is provided then any user can update rows in this interactive grid.

775.name: DELETE_AUTHORIZATION_SCHEME
775.helpText:
Select an authorization scheme to restrict who can delete rows.
		In order for an end user to delete rows, this authorization scheme must evaluate to TRUE for that user.
		If no authorization scheme is provided then any user can delete rows in this interactive grid.

776.name: LOST_UPDATE_CHECK_TYPE
776.helpText:
Select how to protect data against lost updates. Lost updates occur when two or more people try to update the same data, and the last update overwrites updates made by the first user to save changes. To prevent this from happening, updates can check the existing column value(s) in the database with the value(s) retrieved when the record was originally queried.

For example:

  1. User A queries employee (EMP) records.
  2. User B queries the same employee records.
  3. User B updates employee details for EMPNO = 7839 and applies (commits) the changes to the database.
  4. User A updates employee details for EMPNO = 7839 and is attempting to apply the changes to the database.
If User A successfully updates the same record, changes made by User B will be lost.

When User A is attempting to save the employee record, then the data in the database is different from what User A queried originally. In step 1 above, the column value(s) originally queried by User A can be captured. Then in step 4 above, the value(s) can be compared to the current values in the database. This comparison will raise an error for User A, as the database value(s) were updated by User B in step 3. This prevents a user from overwriting changes made by another user to the same row.

Note - Lost Update Type will only be used if the corresponding process, Interactive Grid - Automatic Row Processing (DML), has Prevent Lost Updates enabled.

lovValues.helpText: A checksum value will be calculated for each row, when initially querying the data. The checksum is calculated by concatenating all of the updateable columns into a string and then generating a unique value. When committing the updated record, this checksum will be compared to the checksum value of the current database record. If they are not the same, an error will be raised.

If your database table includes a column which is incremented every time a record is updated, preferably by a database trigger, then this column can be used instead of calculating checksums. This option should not be used if your interactive grid updates data in multiple tables.

Note - The row version column must be included in the SQL Source for the region.

777.name: ROW_VERSION_COLUMN
777.helpText: Select the column which stores the row version number for the table being updated. This column will be used in the lost update check.

778.name: ADD_ROW_IF_EMPTY
778.helpText:
Specify whether to add a new row if the interactive grid currently has no records returned. The No Data Found message will never be displayed as there will always be at least one record displayed.

Note - If no updates are made to the record that was added it will not be inserted when the region is saved.

779.name: SUBMIT_CHECKED_ROWS
779.helpText:
Specify whether to include checked rows in page processing, generally initated by a custom button, such as Mark Completed. These checked rows can then be utilized in a custom process to perform the required action.

Note - The selected rows will be processed even if nothing on the row has been updated. Generally, only rows which have been inserted, updated or deleted are processed.

780.name: LAZY_LOADING
780.helpText:
Specify whether to load the interactive grid region independently of the data for the region.

When lazy loading is specified, the page is rendered immediately, showing an empty interactive grid region, until the data is loaded. Generally, the page is not displayed until all of the page is loaded and ready to be rendered. Therefore, if it takes 5 seconds to load all of the data for an interactive grid region, without lazy loading, the end user would have to wait 5 seconds before the page started to render.

Note - Lazy Loading should only be utilized on data sets that take significant time to load, as this adds unnecessary processing overhead on the database for regions that load quickly.

781.name: REQUIRES_FILTER
781.helpText:
Specify whether to prevent the interactive grid from displaying data, unless at least one filter is defined on one of the report columns. This option is designed to limit the data loaded from a very large data set, by restricting the rows returned based on a filter.

Individual columns can have Column Filter Required enabled, ensuring a filter is required for that column, whereas, this option only requires one filter across any of the columns.

Note - When this option is set and no filters are currently defined, a message will be displayed requesting the users to input a filter.

783.name: IG_PAGINATION_TYPE
783.helpText:
Select the pagination type for this report. Often not all report rows are displayed in the report. In order to display additional rows, the end user can use the pagination provided.

Pagination provides the end user with information about the number of rows displayed, and the current position within the result set.

lovValues.helpText: The first rows will be displayed, based on the number specified in Rows per Page. If there are additional rows, controls will be added to the report footer, allowing end users to navigate forwards and backwards between row sets.

Initially enough rows to fill the height of the Interactive Grid are displayed.
        As the end user scrolls additional rows are displayed, getting more data from the server as needed.

784.name: SHOW_TOTAL_ROW_COUNT
784.helpText:
Specify whether to display the total row count in the report footer.

Note - An additional query is performed to obtain the total row count, which may hinder performance, especially on very large data sets.

785.name: SHOW_TOOLBAR
785.helpText: Specify whether a toolbar is displayed above the report. The toolbar may include search, report type, saved reports, actions, change, and reset functionality.

786.name: TOOLBAR_BUTTONS
786.helpText: Check which additional buttons are to be displayed in the toolbar.

lovValues.helpText: Reset will remove any customizations, such as filters, column width, ordering, and so forth, and reload the the report definition from the server.

Save will only save changes made to this interactive grid, without needing to save the whole page.

The save button will only be displayed when the interactive grid is editable, and the end user has authorization to add, update or delete.

787.name: ADD_BUTTON_LABEL
787.helpText:
Enter an alternative label for the Add button. The default label is Add Row.

For example, enter Add Employee for an interactive grid where employees are maintained.

788.name: ENABLE_SAVE_PUBLIC_REPORT
788.helpText:
Specify whether end users can save their current report definition as a Public report.

Public reports are displayed in a select list of available reports in the Toolbar, and are displayed to everyone.

Note - This option is only available to authenticated users, and is further restricted if you also populate the Save Public Report Authorization.

789.name: PUBLIC_REPORT_AUTH_SCHEME
789.helpText:
Select an authorization scheme to restrict who can save public report definitions. To enable an end user to save a public report, this authorization scheme must evaluate to TRUE for that user.

Note - If no authorization scheme is provided then public reports may be saved by any user.

790.name: ENABLE_SUBSCRIPTIONS
790.helpText: Specify whether end users can define subscription settings for this report.

791.name: ENABLE_DOWNLOAD
791.helpText: Specify whether end users can download the report to one of the download formats specified.

792.name: IG_DOWNLOAD_FORMATS
792.helpText: Check which download formats users can utilize to download the currently displayed columns.

793.name: ENABLE_MAIL_DOWNLOAD
793.helpText:
Specify whether end users can send an email, with the report download included as a HTML attachment.

Email is only available to authenticated users, and requires the SMTP to be configured within Application Express Administration Services application (Administration Services), by an Instance Administrator.

794.name: ICON_VIEW_CUSTOM
794.helpText:
Enter the custom column HTML for the Icon View.

The following substitution strings are available:

  • &COLUMN_NAME. - substitution strings for column names.
  • &APEX$ROW_ID. - the record identifier for the row.
  • &APEX$ROW_INDEX. - the record display sequence number.
  • &APEX$ROW_URL. - reference the specified Link Target.

795.name: ICON_VIEW_ICON_TYPE
795.helpText: Select the column type that holds the icon image source.

796.name: ICON_VIEW_ICON_BLOB_COLUMN
796.helpText: Select the interactive grid column that returns the BLOB for the icon image source.

797.name: ICON_VIEW_ICON_URL_COLUMN
797.helpText: Select the interactive grid column that returns the URL for the icon image source.

798.name: ICON_VIEW_ICON_CSS_COLUMN
798.helpText: Select the interactive grid column that returns the CSS classes for the icon image source.

799.name: ICON_VIEW_ICON_ATTRIBUTES
799.helpText: Enter the icon image attributes used for the HTML IMG tag.

8.name: PAGE_ALIAS
8.helpText:
Enter an alphanumeric alias for this page. You may use this alias to reference the page instead of the page number. For example, if you were working on page 1 of application 100, you could create an alias called home. You could then access this page from other pages using the following f?p syntax: 
f?p=100:home

80.name: EVENT_SCOPE
80.helpText: Select the scope of the event, which determines when the event is evaluated a second or successive time.

lovValues.helpText: Binds the event handler to the triggering element(s) for the lifetime of the current page, but is no longer bound if a triggering element is updated via Partial Page Refresh (PPR).
Binds the event handler to the triggering element(s) for the lifetime of the current page, irrespective of any triggering elements being recreated via Partial Page Refresh (PPR).
Binds the event handler to the triggering element(s) only once. The dynamic action is not triggered again until after the page has been fully refeshed.

800.name: IG_ICON_VIEW_LINK_TARGET
800.helpText: Click the Link Target to invoke a modal dialog. You can enter a custom target to be called when the icon is clicked.

801.name: ICON_VIEW_LINK_ATTRIBUTES
801.helpText: Enter HTML attributes that are associated with the display of each Link Target.

803.name: JAVASCRIPT_CODE
803.examples:
function( options ) {
  options.advancedOption = true;
  return options;
}
803.helpText: Enter a JavaScript function that takes a configuration object for the component, modifies the object, and returns it. This allows advanced customization of the appearance, features, and behavior of the component.

804.name: ALTERNATIVE_LABEL
804.helpText:
Enter the alternative label to use in dialogs and in the Single Row View.
        Use an alternative label when the heading contains extra formatting, such as HTML tags, which do not display properly.

805.name: IG_COLUMN_GROUP
805.helpText:
Select the group for this column. Groups are used to associate columns together in the grid and Single Row View.

Note - Groups are added by expanding the Attributes folder within the Rendering tree, and right-clicking on Column Groups to create a new group.

806.name: IG_USE_GROUP_FOR
806.helpText: Select where the group is used to display this column.

lovValues.helpText: The group will display in both the report heading and in the Single Row view.
The group will only display in the Single Row View.
The group will only display in the report heading.

807.name: ENABLE_FILTER
807.helpText: Specify whether end users can filter this column.

808.name: FILTER_OPERATORS
808.helpText:
Select which filter operators end users can utilize for this column.

Depending on the size of the data set and column indexes, you may choose to disable certain filter operators to avoid performance issues for the end users. Certain operators may cause full table scans instead of using column indexes.

lovValues.helpText:
Filter returns results of column values containing the filter value. Application Express will utilize a column LIKE %filtervalue% in the where clause.

Note - this operator will prevent any column indexes being used, which may result in a full table scan.

Filter returns results of column values starting with the filter value. Application Express will utilize a column LIKE filtervalue% in the where clause.

Note - this operator can utilize available column indexes. {Please review Case Insensitive for exceptions}.

Filter returns results of column values irrespective of differences in the case of the column value and filter value. Application Express will utilize a UPPER(column) operator UPPER(filtervalue) in the where clause.

Note - Generally performing UPPER on both the column and filter value will prevent the use of any column indexes, except for function based column indexes with UPPER(column).

Filter returns results based on the regular expression entered.

Note - using REGEXP operators is complex and generally only used by advanced users. Such operators can result in very bad performance.

809.name: FILTER_TEXT_CASE
809.helpText:
Select which case the text within the column value is stored.

If the column can be specified as always upper case, for example Username, or always lower case, then the performance of retrieving filter results can be improved. If Upper or Lower is selected searches will always perform case sensitive searches.

Note - If Mixed is selected, then end users can specify Case Sensitive in the Search and Filter dialogs.

lovValues.helpText: For when the column value is always stored in upper case. Application Express will utilize a column operator UPPER(filtervalue) in the where clause.
For when the column value is always stored in lower case. Application Express will utilize a column operator LOWER(filtervalue) in the where clause.
For when the column value is stored in mixed case. The setting for the Case Insensitive operator will determine the where clause utilized.

81.name: STATIC_CONTAINER_JQUERY
81.helpText: Enter the static container, of a jQuery Selector, for use by this dynamic action. You can improve the performance of dynamic actions that have an event scope of Dynamic. This must be an element on the page that itself does not get recreated, but contains the triggering elements that are recreated using Partial Page Refresh (PPR). This element reference needs to be defined as a jQuery selector.

811.name: FILTER_LOV_TYPE
811.helpText: Select how to derive the list of values for the filter when a user clicks on the column header or in filter dialogs.

lovValues.helpText:
Disable any values being displayed in the filter.
        This option is appropriate on large columns, generally with most values being over 50 characters, or when a list would not be very usable for selecting a specific record.
        Instead the end user can just type in a partial value and then view the results.
Distinct column values are displayed for VARCHAR2 and NUMBER columns. DATE and TIMESTAMP columns utilize the built-in predefined date ranges.
Values are derived from the SQL query definition.
Values are derived from an exisiting list of values.
Values are derived from a static list of values.

lovValues.d: PL/SQL Function Body returning SQL Query
lovValues.helpText: Values are derived from the PL/SQL function body that returns a SQL Query.
Values are derived from list of values.

812.name: FILTER_EXACT_MATCH
812.helpText:
Specify whether to perform an exact match search when the end user enters text into a column filter. If set to No, the filter will perform a contains search, rather than an equals search.

For example, if a column, such as TAGS, includes values separated by commas, then exact match will only return results if the row contains the single text value entered into the column filter. If Exact Match is set to No, results will return any rows which include the text value entered.

813.name: IG_COLUMN_FILTER_STATIC_VALUES
813.helpText:
Enter a comma delimited list of values for this static list.

Note - the Static Values will always be displayed in the same order they are specified, not alphabetically.

814.name: IG_COLUMN_FILTER_FUNC_BODY_RETURNING_SQL
814.prompt: PL/SQL Function Body returning SQL Query
814.examples:
To return the department name:
begin
    return 'select dname as d from dept order by 1';
end;
814.helpText:
Enter a PL/SQL function body that returns an SQL Query to populate this list of values.

The SQL Query only needs to return one column. If the query returns multiple columns, only the first column is used in the filter search.

815.name: IG_COLUMN_SOURCE_TYPE
815.helpText: Select the source type the value of this column is based on.

lovValues.helpText: Set to the column value entered in Database Column, that is retrieved from the region source SQL Query.
Set to the value returned from the SQL Expression entered.
The column value is not retrieved from any source. For example, the APEX$ROW_SELECTOR and APEX$ROW_ACTION columns have no source.

817.name: SOURCE_SQL_EXPRESSION
817.examples:
To concatenate two columns together:
FIRSTNAME || ' ' || LASTNAME
Include an inner select:
(select count(*) from emp e where e.deptno = DEPTNO)

818.name: DATA_TYPE
818.helpText: Select the data type of the underlying database column.

819.name: IS_QUERY_ONLY
819.helpText:
Specify whether to exclude the column from DML operations.

If set to Yes, Application Express will not utilize the column when executing Intereactive Grid - Automatic Row Processing (DML). For example, you should exclude columns whose definitions include concatenations, inner selects, function calls, or a column in an updateable view which is based on an expression.

All columns which need to be included in any INSERT or UPDATE statements must have this option set to No.

Note: Columns of type Display Only are also included in the Automatic Row Processing unless this option is set to Yes.

82.name: DA_ACTION_TYPE
82.helpText:
Specify which action you want to perform. The following actions are supported:

#NATIVE_PLUGINS#

Depending on your application configuration, you may also have additional dynamic action plug-ins available here. These are displayed as <My Plug-in> [Plug-in]. The following plug-ins are installed within this application's shared components:

#CUSTOM_PLUGINS#

820.name: IS_PRIMARY_KEY
820.helpText: Specify whether the column is one of the primary key values for the underlying table(s).

821.name: MASTER_COLUMN
821.helpText:
If this column is a foreign key column for the master interactive grid region, as specified by Master Region in the region settings, select the corresponding primary key column from the master table.

For example, if the master region was DEPT and this interactive grid was EMP, then you would select the DEPTNO column within the EMP interactive grid and then select the DEPTNO column from the list of DEPT columns for Master Column.

822.name: ENABLE_SORT_GROUP
822.helpText:
Specify whether end users can use this column in sorts, control breaks, and aggregates.

Note - Allowing these operations can lead to performance issues, especially on large data sets or where appropriate column indexes are not available.

823.name: DEFAULT_TYPE
823.helpText: Select how the default value of this column is determined.

lovValues.helpText: Set to the value entered in Static value.
Set to the value returned from the session state for the Item selected.
Set to the value returned from the SQL Query entered.

lovValues.d: SQL Query returning Colon Delimited List
lovValues.helpText:
Set to the colon delimited list of values returned from the SQL Query entered.

Note - colon delimited lists are required when the column is displayed as a checkbox, radio group, or shuttle.
Set to the value returned from the PL/SQL Expression entered.
Set to the value returned from the PL/SQL Function Body entered.
Set to the value returned from the Sequence entered.

824.name: DEFAULT_VALUE_SQL_QUERY
824.helpText: Enter the SQL query which returns the default value for this column.

825.name: DEFAULT_VALUE_SQL_QUERY_COLON
825.helpText: Enter the SQL query which returns the default colon delimited list of values for this column.

826.name: DEFAULT_VALUE_SEQUENCE
826.helpText: Enter the name of the database sequence which returns the default value for this column.

827.name: DUPLICATE_VALUE
827.helpText: Specify whether the column should be defaulted to the existing column value when duplicating the record.

828.name: EXECUTE_READONLY
828.helpText:
Select when this read only condition is executed.

If you refer to Columns in your read only condition, you must specify For Each Row in order for the condition to be evaluated for each row of the Interactive Grid. Otherwise, set to Once to evaluate the condition only one time for the region.

lovValues.helpText: Evaluate the read only condition independently for each row.
Evaluate the read only condition only once for the whole region.

829.name: JET_CHART_TYPE
829.helpText: Select the chart type. The chart type determines the visualization used to render the chart.

lovValues.helpText: Area charts are useful for comparing trends of cumulative values over time, such as breakdowns of sales trends.
Bar charts are useful for comparing values across categories, or over time.

Box plot charts are useful for analyzing the distribution of data, displaying the minimum, quartiles, median, and maximum values of groups of numerical data. Box plots are also called Box and Whisker diagrams.
Bubble charts define data items using x, y, and z values, making them useful for viewing relationships between 3 dimensions. The third dimension is represented by the size of the bubble.
Combination charts allow bar, line, and area series to be displayed on the same chart. The most common use case is lines with bars or lines with stacked bars.
Dial gauges are used to display a metric value in relation to the minimum and maximum possible values for that metric.
Donut charts are a pie chart with a hole in the middle. They are useful for visualizing parts of a whole.
Funnel charts are useful for viewing data for stages of a process, such as the stages of a sales process. The area of a funnel slice is proportional to the value for the corresponding stage.
Gantt charts are useful for displaying project schedules, displaying bars that indicate the start and end date of tasks.
Line charts are useful for visualizing trends in a set of values over time and comparing these values across series.
Line with Area charts are the same as line charts, with the area below each line filled in.
Pie charts are useful for visualizing parts of a whole.
Polar charts have a radial y-axis and a tangential x-axis. Polar charts can be rendered as bar, line, area, combination, scatter, or bubble chart series types.

Pyramid charts are useful for visualizing hierarchical, proportional and foundation-based relationships, process steps, organizational layers or topics interconnections. The area of a pyramid slice is proportional to its value for the corresponding stage.
Radar charts are polar charts with a polygonal grid shape, rather than a circle surround. They are supported for line and area chart series types.
Range charts display maximum and minimum (high / low) values for each entry, using either bars or area.
Scatter charts define data items using x and y values, making them useful for viewing relationships between 2 dimensions.

Stock charts are useful for displaying information about a stock on a time axis. Unique to stock charts is the candlestick Stock Render As property, which allows for displaying open, close, high, low information for the stock price.

83.name: FIRE_WHEN_EVENT_RESULT_IS
83.helpText:
Specify whether this action fires when the triggering element condition is met by selecting True (True Action), or when it is not met by selecting False (False Action).

Note: if there is no condition specified, only True actions fire.

830.name: ORIENTATION
830.helpText: Select the orientation of this chart.

lovValues.helpText: Displays the data items of the chart vertically.  For example, the bars on a Bar chart will display vertically.
Displays the data items of the chart horizontally.  For example, the bars on a Bar chart will display horizontally.

831.name: VALUE_TEXT_TYPE
831.helpText: Specify how the tick labels should be displayed on the chart, either as a number or a percentage of the total value.

lovValues.helpText:
The tick labels will display as values between the minimum and maximum values defined on the chart.

Note: the Format Type attribute should only be used to apply custom decimal or currency formatting to the tick labels and metric label displayed on the chart.

The tick labels will display as values between 0% and 100%.

Note: When Format Type is set to Percent, the values on the chart are multiplied by 100 to format as a percent. If you wish to use the Format Type attribute, ensure that Tick Label Type is set to number.

833.name: STACK
833.helpText: Specify whether the data items are stacked.

836.name: ANIMATION_ON_DISPLAY
836.helpText:
Select the type of animation used when initially displaying the chart.

The options Alpha Fade and Zoom do not apply to Dial charts.

lovValues.helpText: Apply the Oracle JET defined default animation settings for the chart.
Fade in the chart when initially displayed. This setting does not apply to Gantt charts.
Zoom in to the chart when initially displayed. This setting does not apply to Gantt charts.
No animation applied to the chart when initially displayed.

837.name: ANIMATION_ON_DATA_CHANGE
837.helpText:
Select whether animation is shown when data is changed on the chart. A data change can occur if the chart gets automatically refreshed, if hide and show behavior is performed when clicking on a legend item, or when chart data is programmatically updated via some custom JavaScript code or a Dynamic Action.

The options Slide to Left and Slide to Right do not apply to Dial charts

.

lovValues.helpText: Apply the Oracle JET defined default animation settings for the chart.
The data elements slide to the left when data is changed. This setting does not apply to Gantt charts.
The data elements slide to the right when data is changed. This setting does not apply to Gantt charts.
No animation is applied to the chart when data is changed.

838.name: JET_DIAL_INDICATOR
838.helpText: Select the needle indicator to be displayed on the dial gauge chart.

839.name: JET_DIAL_BACKGROUND
839.helpText: Select the background to be displayed on the dial gauge chart.

84.name: FIRE_ON_PAGE_LOAD
84.helpText:
Specify if the action fires on initialization.

Initialization has a slightly different meaning depending on how the Dynamic Action is defined. For Dynamic Actions defined to fire on Interactive Grid columns, this specifies if the action fires when the Interactive Grid row is activated for editing. For all other Dynamic Actions, this specifies if the action fires when the page loads.

840.name: JET_DATA_CURSOR
840.helpText:
Select whether the data cursor is enabled on the chart. Data cursor is a useful alternative to tooltips when the data items are difficult to navigate to, especially on touch devices.

If set to Automatic, the data cursor is shown only for line or area charts on touch devices.

Note - The data cursor is not shown when the tooltip is null, and it is not supported on polar charts.

lovValues.helpText: Apply the Oracle JET defined default data cursor display for the chart.
The data cursor is always displayed.
The data cursor is not displayed.

841.name: JET_DATA_CURSOR_BEHAVIOR
841.helpText: Select the behavior of the data cursor on the chart.

lovValues.helpText: Apply the Oracle JET defined default data cursor behavior for the chart.

The data cursor follows the mouse/touch movement smoothly, displaying the tooltip whenever the data cursor is hovering over any part of a data element, and not just specific data points. An indicator identifies the currently selected data element.

Note - Set Cursor to Yes for this visualization to work fully.

The data cursor snaps (jumps) to a data element when a mouse/touch movement occurs over the chart, displaying the tooltip whenever the data cursor is hovering over a data element. An indicator identifies the currently selected data element.

Note - Set Cursor to Yes for this visualization to work fully.

842.name: JET_HOVER_BEHAVIOR
842.helpText:
Select the behavior to be applied when hovering over data items on the chart.

Select Yes to dim all data items when not currently hovered over, and highlight only the current data item hovered over.

843.name: JET_TIME_AXIS_TYPE
843.helpText: Select the type of time axis to display on the chart. This setting will automatically render the chart data in chronological order, and should not be used if you require your data to be rendered in reverse chronological order.

lovValues.helpText: Apply the Oracle JET defined default time axis setting for the chart, based on the data being rendered.
Apply no time axis type setting to the chart.
Apply a time axis type setting to the chart.
The time values displayed on the chart axis in mixed frequency. This setting will only work for Scatter and Bubble charts, and stacking is not supported.
The time values displayed on the chart axis will be rendered at a regular interval regardless of any time gaps that may exist in the data.

844.name: JET_ZOOM_AND_SCROLL
844.helpText:
Specify the zoom and scroll behavior of the chart.
        Zoom and scroll allows the end user to use gestures, such as dragging on the plot area, using the mouse wheel, or two-finger pinches, to resize the values displayed and navigate within the chart to display different chart values.

lovValues.helpText: Zoom and scroll are disabled for the chart.
