The change to the data display will wait until the zoom/scroll action is done.
The change to the data display will wait until the scroll action is done.
Live behavior means that the chart will be updated continuously as it is being manipulated. For large data sets or slow client environments, it is recommended to select Delayed.
Live Scroll Only behavior means that the chart will be updated continuously as it is being scrolled. For large data sets or slow client environments, consider selecting Delayed Scroll Only.

845.name: PIE_OTHER_THRESHOLD
845.helpText:
Enter the fraction of the whole pie chart, below which the slices are aggregaged into an "Other" slice. Valid values range from 0 (default) to 1

For example, a value of 0.15 would cause all slices which are less than 15% of the pie to be aggregated into the "Other" slice.

846.name: VALUE_MIN
846.helpText: Specify a minimum value for the chart.

847.name: VALUE_FORMAT_TYPE
847.helpText: Select a numeric, date and/or time type of formatting to be applied to the value on the chart. For date and/or time formatting, ensure the chart attribute Time Axis Type is set to one of the following values, depending on your chart data: Enabled, Mixed Frequency, or Skip Gaps.

lovValues.helpText: When a date is formatted as short, the formatted date will contain year, numeric-month (MM/M), day. For example, 1/6/16.

When a date is formatted as medium, the formatted date will contain year, abbreviated-month (MMM), day. For example, Jan 6, 2016.
        For some languages, abbreviated months are not used; in that case, the medium format will contain the numeric month (MM/M).
When a date is formatted as long, the formatted date will contain year, long-month, day. For example, January 6, 2016.

When a date is formatted as full, the formatted date will contain long-weekday (EEEE), year (y), long-month (MMMM), day (d). For example, Wednesday, January 6, 2016.
        For some languages, long months are not used; for example, in Japanese the numeric month is used in patterns.

When a time is formatted as short, the formatted time will contain hour, minute. For example, 7:30 AM.
        The hour format depends on whether the application language uses 12-hour time or not.

When a time is formatted as medium, the formatted time will contain hour, minute, second. For example, 7:30:21 AM.
        The hour format depends on whether the application language uses 12-hour time or not.

When a time is formatted as long, the formatted time will contain hour, minute, second, and zone (z). For example, 7:30:21 AM.
        The hour format depends on whether the application language uses 12-hour time or not.

When a time is formatted as full, the formatted time will contain hour (h/H), minute (mm), second (ss), and zone (zzzz). For example, 7 h 30 min 21 s.
        The hour format depends on whether the application language uses 12-hour time or not.

When a date-time is formatted as short, the formatted date-time will contain year, numeric-month (MM/M), day, hour, minute. For example, 1/6/16 7:30 AM.
        The hour format depends on whether the application language uses 12-hour time or not.

When a date-time is formatted as medium, the formatted date-time will contain year, abbreviated-month (MMM), day, hour, minute, second, and zone (z). For example, Jan 6, 2016 7:30:21 AM.
        The hour format depends on whether the application language uses 12-hour time or not.

When a date-time is formatted as long, the formatted date-time will contain year, long-month, day, hour, minute, second, and zone (z). For example, Jan 6, 2016 7:30:21 AM.
        The hour format depends on whether the application language uses 12-hour time or not.

When a date-time is formatted as full, the formatted date-time will contain long-weekday (EEEE), year (y), long-month (MMMM), day (d), hour (h/H), minute (mm), second (ss), and zone (zzzz). For example, Wednesday, January 6, 2016 7 h 30 min 21 s.
        The hour format depends on whether the application language uses 12-hour time or not.

When a number is formatted as a decimal, the decimal character is replaced with the most appropriate symbol for the locale. In English this is a decimal point ("."), while in many locales it is a decimal comma (",").
When a number is formatted as currency, the Currency property is required to be set to specify the currency that will be used when formatting the number.
When a number is formatted as a percent, the values on the chart are multiplied by 100 to format as a percent.

848.name: VALUE_CURRENCY
848.helpText: Enter the currency that will be used when formatting the value on the chart. The value should be a ISO 4217 alphabetic currency code. If the format type is set to currency, and no currency is defined in the Currency property, the currency will be automatically derived from the application language when the chart is rendered.

849.name: VALUE_NUMERIC_PATTERN
849.examples:
Numeric Pattern to represent temperatures in farenheit, for example 15°F:
#°F
Numeric pattern to represent numbers in specific format, for example, 12,30,00:
##,##,##
Numeric pattern to represent numbers in millimeters:
# mm
Date pattern to represent date as Month Year, for example, Jul 2016:
MMM yyyy
Date pattern to represent date as Month, for example, July:
MMMM
849.helpText:
Enter an optional localized numeric or date pattern, where the characters used in the pattern conform to Unicode CLDR for date time formats.
        When present, this will override the Format Type selected.

85.name: AFFECTED_TYPE
85.helpText: Select how to define the page components to be affected when this action is executed.

lovValues.helpText: The action affects the one or more page items you enter.
The action affects the button you select.
The action affects the region you select.
The action affects the one or more columns you enter.
The action affects the page element idenitifed by the DOM Object or DOM ID you enter.
The action affects the page element(s) returned using the jQuery selector syntax you enter.
The action affects the page element(s) returned using the JavaScript Expression you enter.
The action affects the page element or component that triggered the dynamic action.

The action affects the page element where the event originated, which could be different to the "Triggering Element" in some cases.

In this advanced configuration, the triggering element specified is generally a container element (such as a region) which handles events raised by all of it's sub-elements (such as page items in that region). This selection type can then be used to act upon the sub-element that triggered the event, rather than the container element. For example, if you have a dynamic action that defines a 'Change' event on a region on your page, the action affects the actual item in the region that has changed.

Utilizing 'Event Source' can be a more efficient way of defining common behaviors that affect many page elements. The ability of container elements to catch events raised by sub-elements is determined by the event type. The following event types support this:

  • After Refresh (apexafterrefresh)
  • Before Refresh (apexbeforerefresh)
  • Change (change)
  • Click (click)
  • Double Click (dblclick)
  • Get Focus (focus)
  • Key Down (keydown)
  • Key Press (keypress)
  • Key Release (keyup)
  • Lose Focus (blur)
  • Mouse Button Press (mousedown)
  • Mouse Button Release (mouseup)
  • Mouse Move (mousemove)

850.name: VALUE_FORMAT_SCALING
850.helpText: Select the scaling behavior of the value on the chart.

851.name: JET_SHOW_TOOLTIP
851.helpText: Specify whether a tooltip should be rendered on the chart.

852.name: SHOW_SERIES_NAME
852.helpText: Specify whether the series name should be displayed in the tooltip rendered on the chart.

853.name: SHOW_GROUP_NAME
853.helpText: Specify whether the group name should be displayed in the tooltip rendered on the chart.

854.name: JET_SHOW_VALUE
854.helpText: Specify whether to display values in the tooltip on your chart. Values are derived from your chart query and display next to your chart data.

855.name: JET_SHOW_LABEL
855.helpText: Specify whether to display labels in the tooltip on your chart. Labels are derived from your chart query and display along a chart axis.

856.name: CUSTOM_TOOLTIP
856.helpText: Enter an optional custom tooltip to be rendered on the chart.

857.name: LEGEND_RENDERED
857.helpText: Specify whether a legend should be rendered on the chart.

858.name: LEGEND_POSITION
858.helpText: Select the position of a legend on the chart.

859.name: HIDE_AND_SHOW_BEHAVIOR
859.helpText:
Select the hide and show behavior that is performed when clicking on a legend item.
        For example, deselecting a legend item will hide its associated data series on the chart.

lovValues.helpText: The chart will not enable the hide and show behavior.
The chart axes will rescale as the minimum and maximum values of the visible data increase or decrease. This is useful for series with largely varying values.
The chart axes will not rescale. This is useful to keep the user in context.

86.name: AFFECTED_REGION
86.helpText: Select the region to be affected by this action.

860.name: OVERVIEW_RENDERED
860.helpText:
Specify whether an overview scrollbar should be rendered on the chart. Currently this option is only supported for vertical bar, line, area, stock, and combination charts.

Note - The Zoom and Scroll option must be enabled for the overview scrollbar to be displayed.

861.name: OVERVIEW_HEIGHT
861.helpText: Enter the height of the overview scrollbar, in pixels (for example 50px) or percent (for example 15%), to be rendered on the chart.

862.name: CHART_MAX_WIDTH
862.helpText:
Enter the maximum width of the chart in pixels. The maximum width defines a fixed width for your chart region. Alternatively, to enable automatic resizing of the chart width, leave this item empty. The width is then automatically set to 100% of the region.

By default, a chart created on a page using the jQuery Mobile Smartphone user interface has no value set for width and correctly resizes to fit the device it is being rendered on.

863.name: JET_ZOOM_DIRECTION
863.helpText: Select the zoom direction of the chart.

lovValues.helpText: Zooms in both x and y axes direction.
Zooms only in the x-axis direction.
Zooms only in the y-axis direction.

864.name: JET_SERIES_TYPE_COMBO
864.helpText: Select the chart series type. You can also create a chart combining different types of series on the same data plot.

869.name: ITEMS_Z_COLUMN_NAME
869.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the z value on this chart.  The z value defines the bubble radius for a bubble chart, the width of a box plot item, and the bar width for a bar or combination chart.

87.name: AFFECTED_BUTTON
87.helpText: Select the button to be affected by this action.

870.name: LINK_TARGET_TYPE
870.helpText: Select the action to be performed when the chart is clicked.

lovValues.d: Redirect to Page in this Application
lovValues.helpText: Redirect to a page in the current application, with optional additional attributes for resetting pagination, setting the request value, clearing cache and setting item values, on the target page.

lovValues.d: Redirect to Page in a different Application
lovValues.helpText:
Redirect to a page in a different application, with optional additional attributes for resetting pagination, setting the request value, clearing cache and setting item values, on the target page.

Note: Redirecting to a page in different application relies on deep linking being enabled in the target application. To enable deep linking, go to the application's Security attributes and enable Deep Linking.
Redirect to the target URL you specify.

lovValues.d: Redirect to URL returned by First Column [Deprecated]
lovValues.helpText: Redirect to the target URL returned by the first column of the SQL query.

871.name: ITEMS_MIN_VALUE
871.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the minimum value on this chart.

872.name: JET_INITIAL_ZOOMING
872.helpText: Select the initial zooming of the chart.

lovValues.helpText: Initially zoom to the first data points that can fit in the chart plot area.
Initially zoom to the last data points that can fit in the chart plot area.
To disable initial zooming.

873.name: JET_SORT_ORDER
873.helpText: Select the chart sort order of the data on a multi-series chart, based on either the value or label of the chart.

lovValues.helpText: Set to order the chart based on the values in ascending order (1, 2, 3, ...). This setting should only be used for pie charts, bar/line/area charts with one series, or stacked bar/area charts. Sorting will not apply when using a hierarchical group axis.

Set to order the chart based on the values in descending order (10, 9, 8, ...). This setting should only be used for pie charts, bar/line/area charts with one series, or stacked bar/area charts. Sorting will not apply when using a hierarchical group axis.
Set to order the chart based on the x-axis labels in ascending order. This is the default sort order.
Set to order the chart based on the x-axis labels in descending order.

88.name: AFFECTED_ITEMS
88.helpText:
Enter one or more page items to be affected by this action. For multiple items, separate each item name with a comma.

You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items. If you pick from the list and there is already text entered, then a comma is placed at the end of the existing text, followed by the item name returned from the list.

886.name: SERIES_NAME_COLUMN_NAME
886.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining your multi-series dynamic query.

887.name: AGGREGATE_FUNCTION
887.helpText: Select how to aggregate the associated chart values column.

lovValues.helpText: Returns the number of records.
Returns the total of the value column.
Returns the average of the value column.
Returns the the middle number, ignoring nulls. This aggregation is best suited to a continuous distribution model as it returns the number in the center.
Returns the minimum value.
Returns the maximum value.
Returns the exact number of distinct values.
Returns the approximate number of distinct values. This aggregation is significantly faster than Count Distinct when processing large amounts of data.

888.name: ITEMS_LOW_COLUMN_NAME
888.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the low value on this chart.

889.name: ITEMS_HIGH_COLUMN_NAME
889.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the high value on this chart.

89.name: AFFECTED_DOM_OBJECT
89.helpText:
Enter either a DOM object (document, window) or the id of a DOM object (myElementID) as the element to be affected by this action.

Note: DOM Object is deprecated and should be replaced by JavaScript Expression or jQuery Selector.

890.name: ITEMS_OPEN_COLUMN_NAME
890.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the opening value on this chart.

891.name: ITEMS_CLOSE_COLUMN_NAME
891.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the closing value on this chart.

892.name: ITEMS_VOLUME_COLUMN_NAME
892.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the volume value on this chart. When values are provided, the volume is displayed on the y2 axis.

893.name: ITEMS_X_COLUMN_NAME
893.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the x value on this chart.

894.name: ITEMS_Y_COLUMN_NAME
894.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the y value on this chart.

895.name: ITEMS_TARGET_VALUE
895.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the target value on this chart. When set, the value attribute defines the filled area within the slice and this represents the value of the whole slice.

896.name: ITEMS_MAX_VALUE
896.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the maximum value on this chart.

897.name: GROUP_NAME_COLUMN_NAME
897.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining a short descriptive custom tooltip on the series name(s) on the chart legend. For a Box Plot chart, the column should not match the selected Value column mapping. Selection of a column that matches the Value column mapping will result in no legend tooltip being rendered on the chart.

898.name: GROUP_SHORT_DESC_COLUMN_NAME
898.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining a short descriptive custom tooltip on the x axis label(s) of the chart. For a Box Plot chart, the column should not match the selected Value column mapping. Selection of a column that matches the Value column mapping will result in no label tooltip being rendered on the chart.

899.name: ITEMS_LABEL_COLUMN_NAME
899.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the label(s) of the x-axis on the chart. For a Stock chart, the column should be of data type Date/Timestamp, to represent the stock information on a time axis.

9.name: PAGE_GROUP
9.helpText:
Specify the page group to associate with this page.
Page groups do not affect functionality, but help developers manage the pages within an application.

90.name: AFFECTED_JQUERY_SELECTOR
90.examples:
To select a page element with an DOM id of my_id
#my_id
To select all the page elements with a class of my_class
.my_class
To select all the page elements that are inputs
input
90.helpText:
Enter jQuery Selector syntax to return one or more page elements to be affected by this action. The jQuery library offers a very powerful selector syntax which provides a way to easily access one or more elements from a page.

Please see the official documentation available from the jQuery homepage for further information about the selector syntax.

900.name: ITEMS_SHORT_DESC_COLUMN_NAME
900.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining a short descriptive custom tooltip on the data points of the chart. To render a tooltip on chart data points, ensure the chart tooltip attribute Show is set to Yes. For a Box Plot chart, the column should not match the selected Value column mapping. Selection of a column that matches the Value column mapping will result in no custom tooltip being rendered on the chart.

901.name: JET_SERIES_COLOR
901.examples:
Examples of major HTML color codes include -
  •   Black   #000000 RGB(0,0,0)
  •   Red   #FF0000 RGB(255,0,0)
  •   Yellow   #FFFF00 RGB(255,255,0)
  •   Lime   #00FF00 RGB(0,255,0)
  •   Green   #008000 RGB(0,128,0)
  •   Aqua   #00FFFF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Blue   #0000FF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Navy   #000080 RGB(0,0,128)
  •   White   #FFFFFF RGB(255,255,255)
901.helpText:
Enter the color to be displayed for the data items associated with this chart series. You can utilize &COLUMN_VALUE. substitutions.

The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names. Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

902.name: LINE_STYLE
902.helpText: Specify the style of the line to be rendered on the chart.

903.name: LINE_WIDTH
903.helpText: Specify the width of the line to be rendered on the chart.

904.name: LINE_TYPE
904.helpText: Specify the type of line to be rendered on the chart.

905.name: MARKER_RENDERED
905.helpText: Specify whether a marker should be rendered on the data items of the chart.

906.name: MARKER_SHAPE
906.helpText: Select the shape of the marker to be rendered on the data items of the chart. Only auto is supported for range series.

907.name: ASSIGNED_TO_Y2
907.helpText: Specify whether the current series is assigned to the Y2 axis rendered on the chart.

908.name: ITEMS_LABEL_RENDERED
908.helpText: Specify whether the label(s) should be rendered on the chart. This setting applies to the visibility of the metric value on a Dial chart.

909.name: ITEMS_LABEL_POSITION
909.helpText: Select the position of the label(s) to be rendered on the chart.

91.name: STOP_EXECUTION_ON_ERROR
91.helpText:
Specify whether processing of all other pending actions is stopped when an error occurs while executing the current action.

Note: The order of execution of specific actions is determined by the sequence specified for each action. To ensure that actions are run in the same order, Oracle recommends that the sequence numbers be unique for all True Actions and all False Actions.

910.name: ITEMS_LABEL_CSS_CLASSES
910.helpText: Enter a CSS style string defining the style of the labels on this chart.

912.name: JET_SHOW_AXIS
912.helpText: Specify whether the axis is rendered on the chart.

913.name: AXIS_MIN
913.helpText: Enter the minimum value of the axis. Defaults to null for automatic calculation based on the data.

914.name: AXIS_MAX
914.helpText: Enter the maximum value of the axis. Defaults to null for automatic calculation based on the data.

915.name: RELOAD_ON_SUBMIT
915.helpText: Select when the page should be reloaded following a page submission.

lovValues.helpText: Always reload the page to display errors and the success message.
Show errors dynamically without reloading page, but reload it after a successful processing.

916.name: PAGE_WARN_ON_UNSAVED_CHANGES
916.helpText: Specify if the user is warned when trying to navigate away from the page, where the page contains unsaved changes. Page Items and Buttons also offer more granular control over when this check is performed, and what is included in it. For Buttons, you can specify if clicking the button will perform the check. For Page Items, you can specify if changes to the item are included, or ignored by the check (see the Warn on Unsaved Changes attribute for both).

917.name: VALUE_BASELINE_SCALING
917.helpText: Select whether the axis baseline starts at the minimum value of the data or at zero. Only applies to numerical data axes.

918.name: AXIS_STEP
918.helpText: Enter the increment between major tick marks. Defaults to null for automatic calculation based on the data. Only applies to time and numerical axes.

919.name: AXIS_POSITION
919.helpText: Select the position of the label(s) to be rendered on the chart.

92.name: WAIT_FOR_RESULT
92.helpText:
Specify whether all pending actions wait for the result of the current action. Set this attribute to Yes if pending actions are dependent on the result of this action, or to No if there is no dependency and they can execute asynchronously, without waiting.

Note: The order of execution of specific actions is determined by the sequence specified for each action. To ensure that actions are run in the same order, Oracle recommends that the sequence numbers be unique for all True Actions and all False Actions.

920.name: MAJOR_TICK_RENDERED
920.helpText: Select whether the major tick marks are rendered.

921.name: MIN_STEP
921.helpText: Enter the minimum increment between major tick marks. This is typically used to prevent fractional axis values for discrete measures.

922.name: MINOR_TICK_RENDERED
922.helpText: Select whether the minor tick marks are rendered.

923.name: MINOR_STEP
923.helpText: Enter the increment between minor tick marks. Defaults to null for automatic calculation based on the data. Only applies to numerical axes.

924.name: TICK_LABEL_RENDERED
924.helpText: Specify whether the tick labels are rendered.

925.name: TICK_LABEL_ROTATION
925.helpText:
Specify whether the chart will automatically rotate the labels by 90 degrees in order to fit more labels on the axis.
        The rotation will only be applied to categorical labels for a horizontal axis.

926.name: TICK_LABEL_POSITION
926.helpText: Select the position of the tick labels relative to the plot area.

927.name: SPLIT_DUAL_Y
927.helpText: Specify whether the plot area is split into two sections, so that sets of data assigned to the different Y-axes appear in different parts of the plot area. Stock charts do not support No.

928.name: SPLITTER_POSITION
928.helpText: In a split dual-Y chart, specify the fraction of the space that is given to the Y-axis subchart. Valid values are numbers from 0 to 1.

929.name: PIE_SELECTION_EFFECT
929.helpText: Select the effect applied when a pie segment is selected.

93.name: ITEM_TYPE
93.helpText:
Specify how this item is rendered. The following item types are supported:

#NATIVE_PLUGINS#

Depending on your application configuration, you may also have additional item type plug-ins available here. These display as <My Plug-in> [Plug-in]. The following plug-ins install into this application's shared components:

#CUSTOM_PLUGINS#

930.name: STOCK_RENDER_AS
930.helpText: Select the series type to be applied to the rendered stock chart.

931.name: REFRESH_INTERVAL
931.helpText: Enter the interval in seconds between chart updates. Very small updates intervals, such as 2 seconds, are discouraged since they may cause serious database performance issues.

935.name: CUSTOM_COLUMN_NAME
935.helpText: Specify the custom column name, which can be used for definining a custom tooltip, or database-based colors to be used for the chart elements. For a Box Plot chart, the column should not match the selected Value column mapping. Selection of a column that matches the Value column mapping will result in no custom column being used for the chart.

939.name: AXIS_SCALING
939.helpText: Select the axis scale. Only applies to numerical axes.

94.name: REGION_TYPE
94.helpText:
Specify how this region is rendered. The following region types are supported:

#NATIVE_PLUGINS#

Depending on your application configuration, you may also have additional region type plug-ins available here. These display as <My Plug-in> [Plug-in]. The following plug-ins are installed within this application's shared components:

#CUSTOM_PLUGINS#

940.name: ITEM_WARN_ON_UNSAVED_CHANGES
940.helpText: Specify if the page item is included in the unsaved changes check, which warns the user when they try to navigate away from the page, and where the page contains unsaved changes. Some items may not need to be checked (for example they are not based on a database column, like a search item), so can be set to be ignored.

lovValues.helpText: Changes to the item are ignored by the unsaved changes check.

941.name: BUTTON_WARN_ON_UNSAVED_CHANGES
941.helpText: Specify if the user is warned when they try to navigate away from the page by clicking the button, and where the page contains unsaved changes.

lovValues.helpText: The unsaved changes check will not be performed when the button is clicked. This setting should be used for Cancel, Delete and Apply Changes buttons.

942.name: INLINE_HELP_TEXT
942.helpText: Enter inline help text for this item. The help text is being displayed immediately with the item and may be used to provide field level context sensitive help.

943.name: PLUGIN_INIT_JAVASCRIPT_CODE
943.helpText: Enter JavaScript code which allows a developer to configure ???.

944.name: WHEN_COLUMNS
944.helpText:
Enter column, or columns to trigger the dynamic action.
For multiple columns, separate each item name with a comma.
You can type in the name or pick from the list of available columns.
If you pick from the list and there is already text entered, a comma is placed at the end of the existing text, followed by the column name returned from the list.

945.name: JS_CONDITION_ELEMENT_TYPE
945.helpText: Select whether an Item or Column is used in this condition.

946.name: JS_CONDITION_ITEM_WHEN_IG
946.helpText: Enter the page item used in this condition. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items.

947.name: JS_CONDITION_COLUMN_WHEN_IG
947.helpText:
Select the column used in this condition.

Note: In the majority of cases this should be the column specified above, in the When Column(s), and is therefore defaulted to this. However you may want to base the condition on a different column, for example with an Interactive Grid based on the EMP table, if you want to fire a dynamic action whenever SAL changes but only if the JOB equals SALESMAN, then you would change this attribute to JOB.

948.name: AFFECTED_COLUMNS
948.helpText:
Enter one or more columns to be affected by this action. For multiple columns, separate each column name with a comma.

You can type in the name or pick from the list of available columns. If you pick from the list and there is already text entered, then a comma is placed at the end of the existing text, followed by the column name returned from the list.

95.name: PAGE_PROCESS_TYPE
95.helpText:
Specify which process type is executed. The following process types are supported:

#NATIVE_PLUGINS#

Depending on your application configuration, you may also have additional process type plug-ins available here. These display as <My Plug-in> [Plug-in]. The following plug-ins are installed within this application's shared components:

#CUSTOM_PLUGINS#

950.name: JS_CONDITION_ITEM
950.helpText:
Enter the page item used in this condition. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items.

Note: In the majority of cases this should be the item specified above, in the When Item(s), and is therefore defaulted to this. However you may want to base the condition on a different page item, for example with a form based on the EMP table, if you want to fire a dynamic action whenever P2_SAL changes but only if the P2_JOB equals SALESMAN, then you would change this attribute to P2_JOB.

951.name: JS_CONDITION_WHEN_IG
951.helpText:
Specify a client-side condition to control whether True or False actions fire. If the condition
                                  evaluates to True, then True actions fire, if the condition evaluates to False, then False actions fire.
                                  If no condition is specified, only True actions fire.

lovValues.helpText: Checks if the value of the selected Item or Column is equal to the Value specified.
Checks if the value of the selected Item or Column is not equal to the Value specified.
Checks if the value of the selected Item or Column is greater than the Value specified.
Checks if the value of the selected Item or Column is greater than or equal to the Value specified.
Checks if the value of the selected Item or Column is less than the Value specified.
Checks if the value of the selected Item or Column is less than or equal to the Value specified.
Checks if the selected Item or Column is empty.
Checks if the selected Item or Column is not empty.
Checks if the value of the selected Item or Column is in the List specified.

lovValues.d: Item / Column is not in list
lovValues.helpText: Checks if the value of the selected Item or Column is not in the List specified.
Evaluates the JavaScript Expression specified.

952.name: JS_COND_VALUE_WHEN_IG
952.helpText: Enter the value for the condition to test.

953.name: JS_COND_LIST_WHEN_IG
953.helpText: Enter the comma separated list of values for the condition to test.

954.name: JS_COND_JS_EXPRESSION_WHEN_IG
954.helpText:
Specify the JavaScript Expression to be evaluated for this condition. The code has access to the following dynamic action related attributes:

this.triggeringElement
A reference to the DOM object of the element that triggered the dynamic action.
this.browserEvent
The event object that triggered the event. Note: On load this is equal to 'load'.
this.data
Optional additional data that can be passed from the event handler.

955.name: ORACLE_TEXT_INDEX_COLUMN
955.helpText:
Select a column where the column is indexed by an Oracle Text index.

Row Search returns results based on the Oracle Text operator entered, providing the corresponding Oracle Text index has been created for the column. This option should only be enabled if the necessary index exist, and the end users have been trained in how to utilize the Oracle Text search operators. To simplify Oracle Text syntax for end users, you can specify a function for the Oracle Text PL/SQL Function Name Component Setting of Interactive Grids in Shared Components.
See Oracle Text Application Developers Guide.

Note - When end users correctly enter the Oracle Text operators, then performance of the search should be far more performant.

956.name: CASCADING_LOV_PARENT_COLUMNS
956.helpText:
Enter columns that trigger the refresh of this list of values. For multiple columns, separate each column name with a comma. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available columns. If you pick from the list, and there is already text entered, then a comma is placed at the end of the existing text, followed by the column name returned from the list.

This list of values is refreshed whenever the value of any of the specified columns are changed on this page.

You should use the column(s) specified in this attribute within the where clause of this list of values SQL Query to restrict the values returned.

For example, if you have columns for Car Make and Model, you could specify Car Make as the Cascading LOV Parent Column within the List of Values definition for Model, and use Car Make within the where clause for that list of values. Then whenever Car Make is changed, the LOV for Model is refreshed, and the list only displays values for the currently selected Car Make.

957.name: SOURCE_LOCATION
957.helpText: Select the location of the data.

lovValues.helpText: Data is sourced from the local database.
Data is sourced from a remote database, where the connection is defined using REST Enabled SQL.
Data is sourced from a RESTful web service defined using Web Source Modules.

959.name: SOURCE_QUERY_TYPE
959.helpText: Select how the data is queried.

lovValues.helpText: The data is retrieved based on a table or view.
The data is retrieved based on a SQL Query.

lovValues.d: PL/SQL Function Body returning SQL Query
lovValues.helpText: The data is retrieved based on the SQL Query returned by executing a PL/SQL Function Body.

96.name: ITEM_NAME
96.helpText: Enter the name of this item. Item names must be valid Oracle identifiers. It is recommended that item names be no longer then 30 bytes so they can be used as bind variables in SQL Queries.

960.name: SOURCE_QUERY_OWNER
960.helpText: Select the schema that owns the table.

961.name: SOURCE_QUERY_TABLE
961.helpText: Enter the case-sensitive table or view name. You can type in the name or pick from the list.

962.name: SOURCE_QUERY_WHERE
962.examples:
Only include those employees which have a manager or have a job of salesman.
( MGR is not null or JOB = 'SALESMAN' )
962.helpText: Enter a valid SQL where condition, used to limit the records retrieved.

963.name: SOURCE_QUERY_ORDER_BY
963.examples:
To show the newest hires first and those which have not been hired yet last. If the date is equal, sort them by department number.
HIREDATE DESC NULLS LAST, DEPTNO
963.helpText:
Enter one or more comma separated column names, including directives, to define the order in which records are retrieved.

Directives include:

  • ASC - Return column in ascending order
  • DESC - Return column in descending order
  • NULLS FIRST - Return column with no value before those with values
  • NULLS LAST - Return column with values before those with no value

964.name: SOURCE_SQL_QUERY
964.helpText: Enter the SQL source for this component.

965.name: REMOTE_SQL_CACHING
965.helpText:
Select how the Application Express engine can cache data in the local database.
        If caching can be used, the component will be rendered based on cached results, instead of fetching from the remote database.
        Cached results will greatly improve performance, especially if there is latency between the local and remote database.

lovValues.helpText: Result is cached and utilized by all users.
Result is cached specifically for each user, across sessions.
Result is cached specifically for each user session.

966.name: REMOTE_SQL_INVALIDATE_WHEN
966.examples:
Expire the data 15 minutes after it has been cached
15
Expire the data at the top of the hour
FREQ=HOURLY;BYMINUTE=0;BYSECOND=0
Expire the data at midnight
FREQ=DAILY;BYHOUR=0;BYMINUTE=0;BYSECOND=0
966.helpText:
Enter when cached data is to be invalidated. Provide either the amount of minutes or a DBMS_SCHEDULER Calendar String.

For DBMS_SCHEDULER Calendar String, you can define that cached data is invalidated at the top of the hour, at midnight, or another specific recurring point in time. See the documentation on DBMS_SCHEDULER.EVALUATE_CALENDAR_STRING for more details.

967.name: SOURCE_WEB_SRC_QUERY
967.helpText: Select the Web Source Module which supports fetching a collection.

968.name: SOURCE_QUERY_PLSQL_FUNCTION_BODY
968.prompt: PL/SQL Function Body returning SQL Query
968.helpText: Enter a PL/SQL Function that returns a SQL query that is used as the basis for this region.

97.name: DISPLAY_SEQUENCE
97.helpText:
Enter the display sequence for this item. The sequence and other layout settings determine where this item is displayed in relation to other items within the region.

Note: If two items, within the same region, have the same sequence value then they may be displayed in a different order when the application is exported and imported into another environment, such as a test or production environment. To ensure consistency, Oracle recommends you specify unique sequence numbers for every item, or at least for those within the same region.

970.name: ICON_VIEW_LABEL_REGION_COLUMN
970.examples:
Examine the ENAME column
select empno,
       ename,
       job,
       '#IMAGE_PREFIX#menu/user_red_64.gif' as image
  from emp
970.helpText: Select the report column that returns the image label.

971.name: ITEMS_BOX_LOW_COLUMN_NAME
971.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the low value on this chart. Where no column is selected, the lowest value of the Box Plot chart will be based upon the data set.

972.name: ITEMS_BOX_HIGH_COLUMN_NAME
972.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the high value on this chart. . Where no column is selected, the hightest value of the Box Plot chart will be based upon the data set.

974.name: JET_CONNECT_NULLS
974.helpText: Specify whether null data points on a multi-series line chart should render as a continuous or broken line. When set to Yes, null data points are handled as zero, to render a continuous line. When set to No, the series will be rendered as a broken line, with gaps representing null data points. This setting will be applied to multi-series chart types that support rendering as a line, such as Line, Line with Area, Combination, Area, Polar, Radar and Scatter. The default is Yes.

975.name: OPTIMIZER_HINT
975.examples:
When accessing the table employee try to use the index emp_department_ix
INDEX (employees emp_department_ix)
Enable the use of the WITH plsql_declarations clause within the SQL query
WITH_PLSQL
975.helpText:
Enter the Oracle Optimizer hint which is added to the top-level statement when executing the SQL query. A hint is an instruction to the Optimizer. When writing SQL, you may know information about the data unknown to the Optimizer. Hints enable you to make decisions normally made by the Optimizer, sometimes causing the Optimizer to select a plan that it sees as higher cost.

For example, you might know that a certain index is more selective for certain queries. Based on this information, you might be able to choose a more efficient execution plan than the Optimizer. In such a case, use hints to force the Optimizer to use the optimal execution plan.

976.name: JET_SERIES_Q2_COLOR
976.examples:
Examples of major HTML color codes include -
  •   Black   #000000 RGB(0,0,0)
  •   Red   #FF0000 RGB(255,0,0)
  •   Yellow   #FFFF00 RGB(255,255,0)
  •   Lime   #00FF00 RGB(0,255,0)
  •   Green   #008000 RGB(0,128,0)
  •   Aqua   #00FFFF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Blue   #0000FF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Navy   #000080 RGB(0,0,128)
  •   White   #FFFFFF RGB(255,255,255)
976.helpText:
Enter the color to be displayed for the q2 segment of the Box Plot chart series. You can utilize &COLUMN_VALUE. substitutions.

The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names. Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

977.name: JET_SERIES_Q3_COLOR
977.examples:
Examples of major HTML color codes include -
  •   Black   #000000 RGB(0,0,0)
  •   Red   #FF0000 RGB(255,0,0)
  •   Yellow   #FFFF00 RGB(255,255,0)
  •   Lime   #00FF00 RGB(0,255,0)
  •   Green   #008000 RGB(0,128,0)
  •   Aqua   #00FFFF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Blue   #0000FF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Navy   #000080 RGB(0,0,128)
  •   White   #FFFFFF RGB(255,255,255)
977.helpText:
Enter the color to be displayed for the q3 segment of the Box Plot chart series. You can utilize &COLUMN_VALUE. substitutions.

The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names. Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

978.name: INCLUDE_ROWID_COLUMN
978.helpText: Specify whether the pseudo column ROWID should be selected.

979.name: JET_HORIZONTAL_GRID
979.helpText: Select whether to display horizontal gridlines on the chart.

98.name: REGION
98.helpText: Select the region in which this item is associated. If the item is displayed then it is displayed within the specified region and relative to other items within this region.

980.name: JET_VERTICAL_GRID
980.helpText: Select whether to display vertical gridlines on the chart.

981.name: JET_ROW_AXIS
981.helpText: Select whether to render the row labels on the chart.

982.name: JET_AXIS_POSITION
982.helpText: Select the position of the major and minor axes on the chart.

983.name: JET_AXIS_SCALE
983.helpText: Select the time scale to be used for the axis on the chart. This is required in order for the Gantt to properly render. The selected time scale will be used for zooming, when no Zoom Scale options have been selected.

984.name: JET_ZOOM_ORDER_SECONDS
984.helpText: Select whether to allow zooming to a scale of seconds on the chart.

985.name: JET_ZOOM_ORDER_MINUTES
985.helpText: Select whether to allow zooming to a scale of minutes on the chart.

986.name: JET_ZOOM_ORDER_HOURS
986.helpText: Select whether to allow zooming to a scale of hours on the chart.

987.name: JET_ZOOM_ORDER_DAYS
987.helpText: Select whether to allow zooming to a scale of days on the chart.

988.name: JET_ZOOM_ORDER_WEEKS
988.helpText: Select whether to allow zooming to a scale of weeks on the chart.

989.name: JET_ZOOM_ORDER_MONTHS
989.helpText: Select whether to allow zooming to a scale of months on the chart.

99.name: LABEL
99.helpText:
Enter the field label for the page item. The label displays on the page only if the item displays. Depending on the label alignment and the display, the label displays either in its own HTML table cell or in the same cell.

Item labels can include shortcuts using "SHORTCUT_NAME" syntax.

990.name: JET_ZOOM_ORDER_QUARTERS
990.helpText: Select whether to allow zooming to a scale of quarters on the chart.

991.name: JET_ZOOM_ORDER_YEARS
991.helpText: Select whether to allow zooming to a scale of years on the chart.

992.name: JET_GANTT_START_DATE_SOURCE
992.helpText: Select the source to be used for defining the start date of the Gantt chart. A start date is required in order to render the chart.

lovValues.helpText: Set to the column value entered in Start Date Column.
Set to the value held in session state for the Start Date Item selected.

993.name: JET_GANTT_START_DATE_COLUMN
993.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the start date of the Gantt chart.

994.name: JET_GANTT_START_DATE_ITEM
994.helpText: Select the page or application item to be used for defining the start date of the Gantt chart.

995.name: JET_GANTT_END_DATE_SOURCE
995.helpText: Select the source to be used for defining the end date of the Gantt chart. An end date is required in order to render the chart.

lovValues.helpText: Set to the column value entered in End Date Column.
Set to the value held in session state for the End Date Item selected.

996.name: JET_GANTT_END_DATE_COLUMN
996.helpText: Select the column name to be used for defining the end date of the Gantt chart.

997.name: JET_GANTT_END_DATE_ITEM
997.helpText: Select the page or application item to be used for defining the end date of the Gantt chart.

998.name: DIRECTION
998.helpText: Select the direction of the parameter.

1.helpText: Enter a short descriptive name for this theme.
Enter a descriptive name for this specific page template.
Enter a name for this item template.
Enter a name for this button template.
Enter a descriptive name for this region template.
Enter a name for this list template.
Enter a name for this breadcrumb template.
Enter a name for this calendar template.
Enter a descriptive name for this specific report template.
Enter the name of the application process for easy identification by developers.
Enter a name for this build option. Build options are predefined settings that determine whether or not components within an application are enabled.
Enter the name used by application developers to reference this authentication scheme.
Enter a unique name that identifies this authorization scheme.
Enter a name for this user interface. The name displays in wizards, such as the Create Theme Wizard.
Enter the name of this page group.
Enter the name of the current page. This name is used in numerous Application Express pages and reports, along with the page number and title.

13.helpText: Enter a title to display in the title bar of the browser window. The Application Express engine uses the title you specify here in place of the #TITLE# substitution string used in the page template. This title is inserted between the HTML tags <TITLE> and </TITLE>.

24.helpText:
Select an authorization scheme applied to the page. Authorization schemes are defined at the application-level and can be applied to many elements within the application.

An authorization scheme is evaluated either once for each application session (at session creation), or once for each page view. If the selected authorization scheme evaluates to TRUE, then the page displays and is subject to other defined conditions. If it evaluates to FALSE, then the page does not display and an error message displays.

256.nullText: Do not show Navigation Menu List

26.nullHelpText: Uses the setting defined in the application security attributes.

33.nullHelpText: Uses the setting defined in the application security attributes.

42.nullHelpText: Uses the setting defined within the theme defaults.

43.nullHelpText: Uses the setting defined within the theme defaults.

736.nullHelpText: Inherits the setting defined against the application.

740.helpText: Enter classes to add to this component. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

129.helpText: Enter the value substituted into region attributes. Region templates that contain the substitution string #REGION_ATTRIBUTES# are substituted with this value.

13.helpText: Enter a region title. The region title only displays when it is defined in the region template.

180.helpText:
Enter the static ID for this region. If defined, this is used as the ID for the region, using the substitution string #REGION_STATIC_ID#, which can be useful if developing custom JavaScript behavior for the region. If this is not defined, the region generates an internal ID.

Note: The template must include the #REGION_STATIC_ID# substitution string, in order for the region to utilize the static ID entered.

198.helpText: Enter the PL/SQL code to generate the HTML output.

21.helpText: Enter HTML text displayed at the top of the region, before the #BODY# content.

23.helpText:
Enter a region footer that displays directly after the body content, after #BODY# in the region template. You may use shortcuts, as well as the substitution string #TIMING#, to display the time consumed to render the region.

For report regions you can use the following pagination substitution strings:

#ROWS_FETCHED#
Shows the number of rows fetched by the reporting engine (the page size). Use these substitution strings to display customized messages to the user.
#TOTAL_ROWS#
Displays the total number of rows that satisfy a SQL query used for a report. For example, Z in rows X - Y of Z
#FIRST_ROW_FETCHED#
The X in rows X - Y of Z
#LAST_ROW_FETCHED#
The Y in rows X - Y of Z

5000.helpText: Select a condition type that must be met for the region to be cached.

5050.helpText:
Select a condition type that must be met in order for this region to render page items as read-only. Not selecting a condition causes the page items to render normally.

Note: If you want a page item in this region (for example a search field) to always render as an enterable page item, independent of how this condition evaluates, then you should set the read only condition of that page item to "Never" to overwrite the region setting.

740.helpText: Enter classes to add to this component. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

965.nullHelpText: Result is not cached. Data is fetched from the remote database for each request.

128.helpText: Enter classes to add to this component. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

129.helpText: Enter additional attributes to be included in the form element HTML tag. The size and id HTML attributes are generated and therefore should not be supplied. For the class HTML attribute it is better to use the dedicated CSS Classes attribute instead.

40.helpText: Enter help text for this item. The help text may be used to provide field level context sensitive help.

5050.helpText:
Select a condition type that must be met in order for this component to render as read-only. Not selecting a condition causes the item to render normally. A read-only item is rendered with the same settings as a Display Only item.

Note: Set the condition type to Never to always render the item as an enterable field. This setting overwrites any read-only condition setting on the region or page level.

739.helpText:
Enter the classes for the icon you want to add to the component. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

If your theme uses Font APEX then review the Universal Theme Sample Application to view available icons and modifiers.

Note: This icon will be displayed inside of the item, not as part of the label.

740.helpText:
Enter classes to add to this item. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

This property can be used to make style modifications to the item, beyond template options, or to provide a simpler way of selecting this item via JavaScript.

Note: To apply CSS classes to the HTML form element tag, please see the CSS Classes property under the Advanced group.

940.nullHelpText: Include item in the unsaved changes check, if the check is enabled at page level.

98.helpText: Select the region in which the item displays. All items should be specified in a region.

129.helpText:
Enter HTML text to include for this button:
  • For buttons of type HTML Button, this text is added to the HTML element definition.
  • For buttons based on templates, your template must include the #BUTTON_ATTRIBUTES# substitution string.

You can use this attribute to control tab stops

176.helpText: Enter the name used to reference the button being clicked. When this page is submitted, the value of REQUEST is set to this button name.

180.helpText:
Enter the static ID for the button. If defined, the static ID is used as the ID for the button. The static ID can be useful when developing custom JavaScript behavior for the button. If the static ID is not defined, the button generates an internal ID.

Note: The template must include the #BUTTON_ID# substitution string, in order for the button to utilize the static ID entered.

740.helpText: Enter classes to add to this component. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

941.nullHelpText: Check for unsaved changes when the button is clicked, if the check is enabled at page level.

98.helpText: Select the region in which the button displays. All buttons should be in a region.

1.helpText: Enter the name of the dynamic action.

5100.helpText: Select a condition type to be met in order for this dynamic action to be active.

1.helpText: Enter the name for the validation. This name should be descriptive so that developers can easily identify conditions being checked.

6.helpText:
Enter an error message that displays if this computation fails. Use #SQLERRM# as a substitution string for the SQL error message resulting from a failed computation.

Computations are designed to always succeed, and only fail due to unanticipated errors. It is not advisable to implement a computation that regularly fails and acts as a psuedo-validation utilizing this error message.

1.helpText: Enter the name of the page process for easy identification by developers.

198.helpText: Enter the PL/SQL code to be executed.

368.helpText:
Enter the success message for this process. If the process runs and does not generate an error, then this process success message displays in the notification section of the resulting page displayed. If you are branching to another page via a URL redirect, you may need to check the preserve success message attribute.

',

For multi row processes, the following substitution string can be used to get the number of records processed:

  • Insert: #MRI_COUNT#
  • Update: #MRU_COUNT#
  • Delete: #MRD_COUNT#

For the Send E-Mail process type the substitution string #TO# can be used to get the addressees of the e-mail.

Plug-ins can have other substitution strings as well. See Plug-in documentation for details.

6.helpText:
Enter the error message for this process. This message displays if an unhandled exception is raised. After any error processing stops, a rollback is issued and an error message displays.

Note: the SQL error message (sqlerrm) displays by default if On Error Page is defined as the error display location, there is no need to add #SQLERRM# to your error text.

Error messages can include the following substitution strings:

#SQLERRM_TEXT#
Text of error message without the error number.
#SQLERRM#
Complete error message.

1.helpText: Enter the name of the branch for easy identification by developers.

740.helpText: Enter classes to add to this component. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

438.helpText: Enter the text message that displays when more rows are returned from the query than the maximum row count entered.

50.helpText: Enter a description for this Interactive Report.

1.helpText: Enter the name of the column group.  This name displays as a region header in the detailed view.

50.helpText: Enter a description for the column group. This description never displays to end users.

97.helpText: Enter the display sequence for this column group. The sequence determines the order in which the column groups display in the detail view.

180.helpText: Enter the static ID for the column. If defined, the static ID is used as the ID for the corresponding table header (TH) cell, and as the HEADERS value for corresponding table data (TD) cells. The static ID can be useful when developing custom JavaScript behavior, or custom style for the column. If the static ID is not defined, the table generates an internal ID for these attribute values.

380.helpText: Enter a title to display at the top of this map.

540.helpText: Enter a value for the size of the blank space displayed above the map.

541.helpText: Enter a value for the size of the blank space displayed below the map.

542.helpText: Enter a value for the size of the blank space displayed on the left side of the map.

543.helpText: Enter a value for the size of the blank space displayed on the right side of the map.

544.helpText: Enter a fixed width for your map region in pixels. Alternatively, to support the automatic resizing of the map width, leave this item empty. The width is then automatically set to 100% of the map region.

545.helpText: Enter a fixed height for your map region in pixels. Alternatively, to support the automatic resizing of the map height, leave this item empty. The height is then based upon the height of the browser.

550.helpText: The chart displays without any animations.

551.helpText: The marker is a circle on the chart.

617.helpText: Specify whether to display values on the map. Values are derived from your chart query and display on the map data point.

215.helpText: Enter a comma separated list of page items on the current page to be set into session state when the map data gets read with a separate request.

129.helpText: The report template substitution string #REPORT_ATTRIBUTES# is replaced with this value. The #REPORT_ATTRIBUTES# substitution string is only replaced in the before rows attribute of the report template.

311.helpText: Specify a name for the CSV download file. If no name is specified, the region name is used followed by the extension .csv.

740.helpText: Enter additional space delimited CSS classes you want to add to your report. Your report template must include the #COMPONENT_CSS_CLASSES# substitution string.

101.helpText: Choose the field template to be used when rendering the tabular form field. When no template is selected, the field is rendered using the default accessibility compliant label.

111.helpText:
Enter the format mask to apply to this column. You can type in the format mask or pick from the predefined list, based on a sample representation of how that format mask is displayed.

It is important that number format masks are only applied to columns that contain numbers and date format masks are only applied to columns that contain dates. Otherwise, a runtime error is raised when any record contains a value that can not be converted using the specified format mask.

366.helpText:
Report regions can be printed using the standard print link, shown below the report region, or using a button. If you want to use a button, remove the link label and create a button on your page, using the URL shown in Print URL as the button target.

Using buttons to print report regions enables you to set session state. This is useful if you are planning to support printing to several different output formats (Word, Excel, PDF, and so on) and want to display a button, link, or image for each option. For this implementation, use the output format derived from item option and include the item name and value in your Print URL.

129.helpText: The report template substitution string #REPORT_ATTRIBUTES# is replaced with this value. The #REPORT_ATTRIBUTES# substitution string is only replaced in the before rows attribute of the report template.

311.helpText: Specify a name for the CSV download file. If no name is specified, the region name is used followed by the extension .csv.

740.helpText: Enter additional space delimited CSS classes you want to add to your report. Your report template must include the #COMPONENT_CSS_CLASSES# substitution string.

101.helpText: Choose the field template to be used when rendering the tabular form field. When no template is selected, the field is rendered using the default accessibility compliant label.

111.helpText:
Enter the format mask to apply to this column. You can type in the format mask or pick from the predefined list, based on a sample representation of how that format mask is displayed.

It is important that number format masks are only applied to columns that contain numbers and date format masks are only applied to columns that contain dates. Otherwise, a runtime error is raised when any record contains a value that can not be converted using the specified format mask.

366.helpText:
Report regions can be printed using the standard print link, shown below the report region, or using a button. If you want to use a button, remove the link label and create a button on your page, using the URL shown in Print URL as the button target.

Using buttons to print report regions enables you to set session state. This is useful if you are planning to support printing to several different output formats (Word, Excel, PDF, and so on) and want to display a button, link, or image for each option. For this implementation, use the output format derived from item option and include the item name and value in your Print URL.

215.helpText: Enter a comma separated list of page items on the current page to be set into session state when the chart data gets read with a separate request.

297.helpText: Enter a text message to display if the chart query does not return any rows. When left empty, Oracle JET will automatically use the default message "No data to display".

588.helpText: Specify the number of decimal places to be applied to the numeric value on the chart.

803.examples:
function( options ){
    // Setup a callback function which gets called when data is retrieved, it allows to manipulate the series
    options.dataFilter = function( data ) {
        data.series[ 0 ].color = "#00FF00";
        return data;
    };
    // Set chart initialization options
    options.type = "line";
    return options;
}
803.helpText: Enter JavaScript code to customise the chart.

844.helpText: Specify the zoom and scroll behavior of the chart. Live behavior means that the chart will be updated continuously as it is being manipulated, while Delayed means that the update will wait until the zoom/scroll action is done. While Live zoom and scroll provides the best end user experience, no guarantees are made about the rendering performance or usability for large data sets or slow client environments. If performance is an issue, Delayed zoom and scroll should be used instead.

847.helpText: Specify the type of formatting to be applied to the value on the chart. The format types Decimal,Percent or Currency only apply to numeric values. The Date,Time and DateTime format types will only apply to values of that data type on the chart.

849.helpText: Specify the numeric pattern to be applied to the numeric value on the chart.

180.helpText: Enter the static ID for the chart series. The static ID can be useful when developing custom JavaScript behavior for the chart series.

215.helpText: Enter a comma separated list of page items on the current page to be set into session state when the chart data gets read with a separate request.

909.helpText: For range series, if an array of two values are provided, the first and second value will apply to the low and high point respectively. The Outside Slice value only applies to pie charts. The Above Marker, Below Marker, Before Marker, and After Marker values only apply to line, area, scatter, and bubble series. The Inside Bar Edge and Outside Bar Edge values only apply to non-polar bar series. Stacked bars do not support Outside Bar Edge. The chart does not currently adjust layout to fit labels within the plot area or deal with any overlaps between labels.

965.nullHelpText: Data is not cached and requested each time.

13.helpText: Enter a title for the axis. This title describes the information being represented on the axis of your chart.

180.helpText: Enter the static ID for the chart axis. The static ID can be useful when developing custom JavaScript behavior for the chart axis.

324.helpText: Specify whether the Icon View is enabled. Selecting Yes adds a View Icons icon to the Search bar for interactive reports, or to the interactive grid View button, enabling users to access this view.

334.helpText: Specify whether the Detail View is enabled. Selecting Yes adds a View Details icon to the Search bar for interactive reports, or to the interactive grid View button, enabling users to access this view.

336.helpText:
Enter the body for report rows in the Detail View.

The following substitution strings are available:

  • &COLUMN_NAME. - substitution strings for column labels and names.
  • &APEX$ROW_ID. - the record identifier for the row.
  • &APEX$ROW_INDEX. - the record display sequence number.

40.helpText: Use this attribute to enter help text for the interactive grid. The entered help text will display along with the default help content under Actions Menu help.

438.helpText: Enter the text message that displays when the Maximum Rows to Process limit is exceeded. The default message instructs end users to add additional filters to limit the number of records to be processed.

803.examples:
function( options ) {
    options.toolbar = false;
    return options;
}
803.helpText: Enter a JavaScript function that takes a configuration object for the Interactive Grid, modifies the object, and returns it. This allows advanced customization of the Interactive Grid appearance, features, and behavior including toolbar, menus, and actions.

1047.nullHelpText: The column will use the Stretch Report Setting set by the End User to define if the column should stretch or not.

128.helpText: Enter classes to add to this component. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

129.helpText: Enter additional attributes to be included in the form element HTML tag. The size and id HTML attributes are generated and therefore should not be supplied. For the class HTML attribute it is better to use the dedicated CSS Classes attribute instead.

180.helpText: Enter the static ID for the column. The static ID can be useful when developing custom JavaScript behavior, or custom style for the column item. If the static ID is not defined, an internal ID is used for the column item ID.

40.helpText: Enter help text for this column.

5050.helpText:
Select a condition type that must be met in order for this component to render as read-only. Not selecting a condition causes the item to render normally. A read-only item is rendered with the same settings as a Display Only item.

Note: Set the condition type to Never to always render the item as an enterable field. This setting overwrites any read-only condition setting on the region or page level.

739.helpText:
Enter the classes for the icon you want to add to the component. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

If your theme uses Font APEX then review the Universal Theme Sample Application to view available icons and modifiers.

Note: This icon will be displayed inside of the item, not as part of the label.

740.helpText: Enter classes to add to this component. You may add multiple classes by separating them with spaces.

803.examples:
function( options ) {
    options.features = options.features || {};
    options.features.sort = false;
    return options;
}
803.helpText: Enter a JavaScript function that takes a configuration object for the column, modifies the object, and returns it. This allows advanced customization of the column appearance, features, and behavior.

93.helpText:
Select how this column is rendered. The following column types are supported:

#NATIVE_PLUGINS#

Depending on your application configuration, you may also have additional column type plug-ins available here. These display as <My Plug-in> [Plug-in]. The following plug-ins are installed in this application's shared components:

#CUSTOM_PLUGINS#

97.helpText:
Enter the display sequence for this column. The sequence setting determines where this column is displayed in relation to other columns within the region.

Note: If two columns, within the same region, have the same sequence value then they may be displayed in a different order when the application is exported and imported into another environment, such as a test or production environment. To ensure consistency, Oracle recommends you specify unique sequence numbers for every item, or at least for those within the same region.

5110.name: NATIVE_BREADCRUMB
5110.title: Breadcrumb
5110.helpText: Display the breadcrumb trail for the current page.

5110.name: NATIVE_CALENDAR
5110.title: Calendar [Legacy]
5110.helpText:
Display date based entries on a variety of calendar views.

You should use Calendar rather than this region type when creating new regions. Classic Calendar regions are generally those created in Application Express Release 4.2 or earlier.

5110.name: NATIVE_CSS_CALENDAR
5110.title: Calendar
5110.helpText: Display date based entries on a variety of calendar views. With the inclusion of an end date, the calendar can display duration based events. Calendars can also update records directly if "Drag and Drop" is enabled.

attributes.helpText:
Enter the maximum number of events displayed for each day within the Month view.

If there are more than the specified number of events on a specific day, that day will include More .... Clicking on this item will display a pop-up window with all of the events for that specific day.

attributes.examples:
Styling the calendar based on project status

select ID,
       START_DATE,
       END_DATE,
       TASK_NAME,
       case STATUS
           when 'Open'    then 'apex-cal-green'
           when 'Pending' then 'apex-cal-yellow'
           when 'Closed'  then 'apex-cal-red'
           when 'On-Hold' then 'apex-cal-black'
       end as css_class,
       ASSIGNED_TO as supplemental_info
  from PROJECTS
attributes.helpText:
Select the column which holds the CSS Class to style the events displayed on this calendar.
There are a number of default classes available:
  • apex-cal-red
  • apex-cal-cyan
  • apex-cal-blue
  • apex-cal-bluesky
  • apex-cal-darkblue
  • apex-cal-green
  • apex-cal-yellow
  • apex-cal-silver
  • apex-cal-brown
  • apex-cal-lime
  • apex-cal-white
  • apex-cal-gray
  • apex-cal-black
  • apex-cal-orange
See documentation on adding additional CSS classes.

Select Yes to have events display over multiple lines, based on the length of the Display Column text.

Select No if you only want each event being displayed on a single line, and truncating text that does not fit in the display. The full text will be displayed in the tooltip.

Note: The multiple line events setting is only used within Month view. For Weekly and Daily views the duration of the event determines the height of the event displayed.

Enter the URL for a RESTful Web Service feed to display on this calendar. The calendar can render JSON data retrieved from external sources, for example Oracle REST Data Services. These Web services must either be public, or available to all end users of this calendar.

The JSON feed should be formatted to include:

  1. The list of events array containing - items
  2. Each event object containing - { id, title, start, allday, end, description }
    The title and start attributes are mandatory.

Enter additional HTML which is displayed in the List View and Tooltip. Use &COLUMN. syntax to show column values in HTML.

Note: Show Tooltip must be set to Yes in order for this supplemental information to be displayed in the Month, Week and Day views.
Select whether Saturday and Sunday are displayed for this calendar.

lovValues.helpText: Utilizes the application timestamp format, entered under Globalization. If this attribute is not populated it will use the database NLS setting.

Displays time using the 12 hour clock including a.m. (from the Latin ante meridiem, meaning "before midday") and p.m. (post meridiem, "after midday"), such as 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.

The actual display format for a.m./p.m., such as capitalization and periods, is derived from the Timestamp Format.
Displays time using the 24 hour clock, such as 08:00 and 16:00.

attributes.helpText: Select the time format used to display the time portion of an event for this calendar.

Select whether a tooltip is displayed when users hover over an event in this calendar.

The drop down dialog will display the event name, supplemental information, and date details.
Enter an integer between 0 and 23 to specify the first hour displayed on the Week and Day calendars.
Select the column which holds the start date for events displayed on this calendar.
Select the column which holds the end date for events displayed on this calendar. If this attribute is specified, then the calendar displays duration based events.
Select the column which holds the text displayed for events on this calendar.

Select the column which holds the primary key value for calendar events. If the table has a multi-part primary key, then select ROWID.

The value of this column is returned in the APEX$PK_VALUE substitution variable. Utilize this variable in the Drag and Drop Code attribute to identify the record to be updated, following the drag and drop operation on the calendar.
Enter a target page to be called when the user clicks an existing entry.

Enter a target page to be called when the user clicks an empty cell, or outside of an existing calendar entry.

You need to use the special calendar substitution variables 

&APEX$NEW_START_DATE.
and 
&APEX$NEW_END_DATE.
to pass the selected dates from the calendar to the target page.

Specify whether drag and drop operations are permitted on this calendar.

Note: If drag and drop is enabled, then any end users who have rights to view this calendar, also have rights to update calendar entries.

attributes.examples:
Example with Start Date only (for non-duration based events)
begin
    update emp
       set hiredate = to_date(:APEX$NEW_START_DATE, 'YYYYMMDDHH24MISS')
     where empno = :APEX$PK_VALUE;
end;
Example with Start and End dates. (for duration based events)
begin
    update projects
       set start_date = to_date(:APEX$NEW_START_DATE, 'YYYYMMDDHH24MISS'),
           end_date = to_date(:APEX$NEW_END_DATE, 'YYYYMMDDHH24MISS')
     where id = :APEX$PK_VALUE;
end;
attributes.helpText:
Enter the PL/SQL code to update the underlying tables or updateable views when a calendar entry is updated using drag and drop.

If this calendar shows duration-based events (by selecting a column for End Date), then the PL/SQL code also needs to update this value. If the whole event is dragged, then the End Date maintains the current duration. If the end of the event is dragged, the duration of the event is updated. In such cases the start date will be unchanged, but the end date is updated to reflect the revised duration.

The calendar substitution variables include:

APEX$NEW_START_DATE
Returns the revised start date. The date format is 'YYYYMMDDHH24MISS' even if the Show Time for this calendar is No.
APEX$NEW_END_DATE
Returns the revised end date for duration based events. The date format is 'YYYYMMDDHH24MISS' even if the Show Time for this calendar is No.
APEX$PK_VALUE
Returns the value of the column specified in the Primary Key Column.

Select which additional calendar views to display. The month view is always displayed.

Note: the Weekly and Daily views are not available if Show Time is specified as No.

Choose which export links are provided at the bottom of the calendar.

Note: This exports all of the calendar entries currently displayed, not a single calendar entry.
Select which calendar views to display. At least one of Day, Week or Month must be selected. If not, the calendar will automatically display the month view.

Enter the Google Calendar ID for the calendar data feed you would like to display on this calendar.

Given Google Calendars security restrictions, these calendars must either be public calendars, or available to all end users of this calendar.

Note: The Google Calendar API Key must be entered for Google calendars to work correctly. Go to Shared Components > Component Settings > Calendar to set the key for the application.

Select whether the time portion of the date should be displayed.

The Week and Day views will only be displayed when Show Time is set to Yes. If the start date or end date columns do not include time components they will be shown as 12:00 am.

INIT_JAVASCRIPT_CODE.examples:
function ( pOptions) {
    pOptions.titleFormat      = "[Conference Schedule]";                  // custom title
    pOptions.minTime          = "07:00:00";                               // hide slots before minTime
    pOptions.maxTime          = "18:00:00";                               // hide slots after maxTime
    pOptions.columnFormat     = {month: '', week: 'dddd', day: 'dddd'};   // week view column headings
    pOptions.slotDuration     = "00:15:00";                               // custom slot duration
    pOptions.weekNumbers      = true;                                     // show week numbers
    pOptions.weekNumberTitle  = "CW";                                    
    return pOptions;
}
INIT_JAVASCRIPT_CODE.helpText: Enter a JavaScript function to override the standard jQuery FullCalendar initialization attributes. The function must return an Object containing the calendar initialization attributes as parameters.

SOURCE_LOCATION.examples:
Styling the calendar based on project status

, 
select ID,
       START_DATE,
       END_DATE,
       TASK_NAME,
       case STATUS
           when 'Open'    then 'apex-cal-green'
           when 'Pending' then 'apex-cal-yellow'
           when 'Closed'  then 'apex-cal-red'
           when 'On-Hold' then 'apex-cal-black'
       end as css_class,
       ASSIGNED_TO as supplemental_info
  from PROJECTS
SOURCE_LOCATION.helpText:
Select the column which holds the CSS Class to style the events displayed on this calendar. There are a number of default classes available:

  • apex-cal-red
  • apex-cal-cyan
  • apex-cal-blue
  • apex-cal-bluesky
  • apex-cal-darkblue
  • apex-cal-green
  • apex-cal-yellow
  • apex-cal-silver
  • apex-cal-brown
  • apex-cal-lime
  • apex-cal-white
  • apex-cal-gray
  • apex-cal-black
  • apex-cal-orange

See documentation on adding additional CSS classes.

5110.name: NATIVE_DATA_UPLOAD_COLUMN_MAPPING
5110.title: Data Upload Column Mapping
5110.helpText: Map uploaded spreadsheet columns to table columns. This region type is generated by the Create Page Wizard for Data Loading.

attributes.helpText: Select the Data Load Definition defined in the Data Loading process.

5110.name: NATIVE_DISPLAY_SELECTOR
5110.title: Region Display Selector
5110.helpText: Display region names in a horizontal list, enabling end users to select one region to display and hide other regions. Only page regions with Region Display Selector set to Yes will be displayed in this region.

lovValues.helpText: Show regions as tabs. Selecting a tab will make the corresponding region visible and hide the other selections.
Always display all the regions on the page. Selecting a tab will scroll your window to the corresponding region.

attributes.helpText: Select how regions with Region Display Selector set to Yes will be displayed on the page.
Prepend a "Show All" tab which, when selected, displays all regions on the page .
On page load, the region that you last selected will be displayed.
