5110.name: NATIVE_FLASH_CHART5
5110.title: Chart - AnyChart [Legacy]
5110.helpText: Display data using various built-in chart types.

5110.name: NATIVE_FLASH_MAP
5110.title: Map Chart
5110.helpText: Display a map chart region. A map chart is a map with data overlays, as opposed to using a web mapping service, such as Google Maps, which plots specific locations.

5110.name: NATIVE_HELP_TEXT
5110.title: Help Text
5110.helpText: Displays a special Help region utilized on the dedicated Help page.

5110.name: NATIVE_IG
5110.title: Interactive Grid
5110.helpText:
Comprehensive online, multi-row region based on a SQL Query that provides end users with numerous features for customization at run-time. The region can be defined as either editable or read-only.

You can define a single Interactive Grid and have end users manipulate the data displayed to meet their specific requirements, rather than you needing to develop several, similar regions with different criteria to meet those same requirements.

SOURCE_SQL.examples:
select empno,
       ename,
       job,
       sal
  from emp
 where deptno = :P1_DEPTNO

5110.name: NATIVE_IR
5110.title: Interactive Report
5110.helpText:
Comprehensive online report based on a SQL Query that provides end users with numerous features for customizing the report layout at run-time. You can control end-user capabilities by enabling or disabling the various report customization options.

You can define a single Interactive Report and have end users manipulate the data displayed to meet their specific reporting requirements, rather than you needing to develop several, similar reports with different criteria to meet those same requirements.

SOURCE_LOCATION.examples:
select empno,
       ename,
       job,
       sal
  from emp
 where deptno = :P1_DEPTNO

5110.name: NATIVE_JET_CHART
5110.title: Chart
5110.helpText: Display data using various built-in chart types.

5110.name: NATIVE_JQM_COLUMN_TOGGLE
5110.title: Column Toggle Report
5110.helpText: Display a report where end users can select the columns to display at runtime. End users can then change the columns based on the width and orientation of the screen they are using to display the report.

attributes.helpText: This is the label to use for the button that opens the column selection popup. If no text is given a default label is used.
Enter the HTML text to be shown as a link. Use an image tag to display images, or pick from the list of default images.
Enter additional space delimited CSS classes to be included in the component.
Enter additional attributes to be included in the table HTML tag. The class HTML attribute is generated and therefore should not be supplied, use the dedicated CSS Classes attribute instead.
Specify additional column link attributes to be included in the <a href=...> tag, including link target, classes or styles.

attributes.examples:
Examples of major HTML color codes include -
  •   Black   #000000 RGB(0,0,0)
  •   Red   #FF0000 RGB(255,0,0)
  •   Yellow   #FFFF00 RGB(255,255,0)
  •   Lime   #00FF00 RGB(0,255,0)
  •   Green   #008000 RGB(0,128,0)
  •   Aqua   #00FFFF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Blue   #0000FF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Navy   #000080 RGB(0,0,128)
  •   White   #FFFFFF RGB(255,255,255)
attributes.helpText:
Enter the color used for the background of this graph. The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names.

Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

attributes.examples:
Examples of major HTML color codes include -
  •   Black   #000000 RGB(0,0,0)
  •   Red   #FF0000 RGB(255,0,0)
  •   Yellow   #FFFF00 RGB(255,255,0)
  •   Lime   #00FF00 RGB(0,255,0)
  •   Green   #008000 RGB(0,128,0)
  •   Aqua   #00FFFF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Blue   #0000FF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Navy   #000080 RGB(0,0,128)
  •   White   #FFFFFF RGB(255,255,255)
attributes.helpText:
Enter the color used for the foreground of this graph. The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names.

Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.
Enter the width in pixels for this bar chart.
This is used for accessibility to identify the column that best represents the content of  the row.

lovValues.helpText: Add alternating row stripes on each row.
Add horizontal lines between each row.

attributes.helpText: Check additional report layout options.

lovValues.helpText: Displays the column value.
Displays the column as a link.
Displays the column as a percentage graph. The value retrieved must be between 0 and 100.

attributes.helpText: Select the basis for this report column.
Enter a target page to be called when the user clicks an existing entry.

The report works by hiding and showing columns based on two inputs: available screen width or by the user checking and unchecking which columns to display in a column picker menu. Select a priority value for each columns you want to display responsively. Any column given a priority will be available in the column picker menu.

To make a column persistent, so it is never hidden, select Always Displayed, which also removes the column from the column picker menu.

SOURCE_LOCATION.examples:
Display all employees ordered by name
SELECT * FROM emp ORDER by ename
Dispaly all employees of the current department ordered by name
SELECT * FROM emp 
WHERE deptno = :P3_DEPTNO 
ORDER by 1

When using bind variables to reference page items, specify them as Page Items To Submit.

5110.name: NATIVE_JQM_LIST_VIEW
5110.title: List View
5110.helpText: Display data in an easy to navigate list. You can also incorporate numerous features to enhance the list view.

attributes.helpText: Select an alternative database column used for the search. If nothing is specified, then the Text Column is used.

attributes.examples:
Set list entry link icon to delete.
data-icon="delete"
attributes.helpText: Enter additional attributes to set on list item element. See the examples for some attributes that affect the list view.

attributes.examples:
The client creates dividers based on the list item text
data-autodividers=true
Change the icon
data-icon="fa-gear"
Change the split button icon
data-split-icon="fa-gear"
attributes.helpText: Enter additional attributes to be set on the list element. See the examples for some attributes that affect the list view.

lovValues.helpText: To perform a browser-based search, all list view entries have to be loaded into the browser (note that the "Number of Fetched Rows" attribute is ignored in this case). Only use this search option for a small number of list entries to avoid unnecessarily long page loads.
Search uses LIKE [search value]% to query the result.
Search uses LIKE UPPER( [search value] )% to query the result. Existing indexes on the column will not be used, unless it is a function-based index using an UPPER expression.
Search uses LIKE %[search value]% to query the result. This will prevent the use of an existing index on that column.
Search uses LIKE %UPPER( [search value] )% to query the result. This will prevent the use of an existing index on that column.

attributes.helpText:
Select how the search is performed.

A client-side search is performed immediately as soon as the user starts to type. For all server-based searches, the user has to press Enter to show the search results. Only server-based searches take into account Character Value Comparison globalization attributes defined for the application.

attributes.examples:
Display department name and the number of employees as a badge
&DNAME. <span class="t-MediaList-badge">&EMP_COUNT.</span>
attributes.helpText:
Enter the HTML markup to render the divider of a list view.

To reference column values of your list view SQL statement use substitution syntax.
Select the database column that contains the URL to the icon/image.
Select a second primary key column or a unique database column that is used to lookup the image.
Select the features that are enabled for this list view.
Select the database column that contains the main content for the list view entry.

attributes.examples:
Display name and below the hire date of an employee
<h3>&ENAME.</h3>
<p>Hire date: &HIREDATE.</p>
attributes.helpText:
Enter the HTML markup to render the main content for a list view entry.

To reference column values of your list view SQL statement, use substitution syntax.
Enter a target page to be called when the user clicks a list entry.
Select the database column that contains the value to display in the count bubble.
Select the database column that contains supplemental information for the list view entry.
Select the database column of data type BLOB that contains the image.
Select the database column that contains the divider. Every time the divider value changes, a new divider displays between the list view entries.
Select the database column containing the hierarchy level of a nested query. If you use a CONNECT BY query use the pseudo column LEVEL.
Enter a target page to be called when the user clicks a list entry.
Enter the text that is displayed in the search box. If no value is specified, the value of the system message APEX.REGION.JQM_LIST_VIEW.SEARCH is used.

Enter the HTML markup to render supplemental information for a list view entry.

To reference column values of your list view SQL statement use substitution syntax.

Select what kind of image displays and where it is read from. The displayed image can be an icon with a size of 16x16 or a thumbnail with a size of 80x80. The source for the image can be a database BLOB column or a URL to a static file.
Select the primary key column or a unique database column that is used to lookup the image.

SOURCE_LOCATION.examples:
Display all employees ordered by name
SELECT * FROM emp ORDER by ename
Dispaly all employees of the current department ordered by name
SELECT * FROM emp 
WHERE deptno = :P3_DEPTNO 
ORDER by 1

When using bind variables to reference page items, specify them as Page Items To Submit.

Use ROWID as primary key column
SELECT a.rowid as pk_rowid, 
       a.* 
  FROM emp a 
ORDER BY a.ename

When using ROWID, a column alias is required.

Nested query returning all employees
 select ename,
        level
   from emp
connect by prior empno = mgr
  start with mgr is null
 order siblings by ename

5110.name: NATIVE_JQM_REFLOW
5110.title: Reflow Report
5110.helpText: Display a responsive report which transforms from columns to rows to display reports on smaller browser (screen) sizes.

attributes.helpText: This is used for accessibility to identify the column that best represents the content of  the row.
Enter the HTML text to be shown as a link. Use an image tag to display images, or pick from the list of default images.
Enter additional space delimited CSS classes to be included in the component.
Enter additional attributes to be included in the table HTML tag. The class HTML attribute is generated and therefore should not be supplied, use the dedicated CSS Classes attribute instead.
Specify additional column link attributes to be included in the <a href=...> tag, including link target, classes or styles.

attributes.examples:
Examples of major HTML color codes include -
  •   Black   #000000 RGB(0,0,0)
  •   Red   #FF0000 RGB(255,0,0)
  •   Yellow   #FFFF00 RGB(255,255,0)
  •   Lime   #00FF00 RGB(0,255,0)
  •   Green   #008000 RGB(0,128,0)
  •   Aqua   #00FFFF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Blue   #0000FF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Navy   #000080 RGB(0,0,128)
  •   White   #FFFFFF RGB(255,255,255)
attributes.helpText:
Enter the color used for the background of this graph. The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names.

Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

attributes.examples:
Examples of major HTML color codes include -
  •   Black   #000000 RGB(0,0,0)
  •   Red   #FF0000 RGB(255,0,0)
  •   Yellow   #FFFF00 RGB(255,255,0)
  •   Lime   #00FF00 RGB(0,255,0)
  •   Green   #008000 RGB(0,128,0)
  •   Aqua   #00FFFF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Blue   #0000FF RGB(0,255,255)
  •   Navy   #000080 RGB(0,0,128)
  •   White   #FFFFFF RGB(255,255,255)
attributes.helpText:
Enter the color used for the foreground of this graph. The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names.

Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.
Enter the width in pixels for this bar chart.

lovValues.helpText: Add alternating row stripes on each row.
Add horizontal lines between each row.

attributes.helpText: Check additional report layout options.

lovValues.helpText: Displays the column value.
Displays the column as a link.
Displays the column as a percentage graph. The value retrieved must be between 0 and 100.

attributes.helpText: Select the basis for this report column.
Enter a target page to be called when the user clicks an existing entry.

SOURCE_LOCATION.examples:
Display all employees ordered by name
SELECT * FROM emp ORDER by ename
Dispaly all employees of the current department ordered by name
SELECT * FROM emp 
WHERE deptno = :P3_DEPTNO 
ORDER by 1

When using bind variables to reference page items, specify them as Page Items To Submit.

5110.name: NATIVE_JSTREE
5110.title: Tree
5110.helpText: Display data in a hierarchical structure, based on parent-child relationships between records.

attributes.helpText:
A CSS class used to specify the type of icons used for all nodes. This class is used in CSS rules to specify properties for all icons of that type. The icon type along with the value of the icon column of the region source determines the icon CSS classes used for each node.

Typical values are:

  • a-Icon This allows using a small number of built-in APEX icons such as icon-circle or icon-tree-folder.
  • fa This allows using Font APEX or Font Awesome icons. The Universal Theme makes one of these icon libraries available.

If no value is given there is no icon type. The icon type CSS class, if needed, can be included in the icon column. For example the icon column value could be "fa fa-user". For a tree with no icons set the Icon Type, and Default Icon attributes to empty and in the SQL Query source the icon column should be null. Custom or third party themes may have their own font or CSS sprite icon library and use a different icon type/prefix class that you can specify here.

attributes.examples: If the Icon Type is fa for Font APEX you can use values such as: fa-user-circle-o, fa-file-o, or fa-arrow-circle-right. See the Universal Theme app for a list of all the icons.
attributes.helpText: The default icon to use when the SQL Query icon column is null. The value is a CSS class name that specifies what icon will be seen. The possible values depend on the Icon Type.

Select the action required to activate node links on your tree. A tree may be used primarily for selection/display or navigation. If used for both selection and navigation it is recommended to set this to Double Click so that a single click will just select the node.

Select the page or application item that you wish to hold the selected node value. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items.

This item is used to save tree state, by holding the value of the last selected node. The value of the selected node can be saved to the selected item via the node link attribute, or via a page process. When the page is reloaded, the tree is opened to the selected node value.

lovValues.helpText: No tooltip will be displayed.
Use a static tooltip value with the following data source column substitutions: #VALUE#, #TITLE#, #LINK# and #TOOLTIP#
Provide an HTML Expression to use as tooltip. Substitutions are being performed.
Use the value of the Tooltip Column.

attributes.helpText: Select whether tooltips are displayed, and the source for the tooltip. If a tooltip is defined, it is displayed when the end user focuses or hovers over a tree node label.
Enter the text displayed when an end user hovers over a tree element.

An optional unique identifier for the tree.

It is better to give the region a Static ID and use the apex.region("static-id").widget() API to access the tree element.
Select the data source column containing the value for the node label. The value cannot contain markup.

lovValues.helpText: The hierarchy is computed using the SQL START WITH CONNECT BY clause. Providing a Parent Key Column is required. Use this option only if your SQL query does not already contain a START WITH CONNECT BY clause.

All hierarchy information is already contained in the data. Mapping the Node Level and Node Status columns is required for this option. The Node Level must contain the hierarchy level as a numeric value; the Node Status must contain 0 for a leaf node and 1 for a non-leaf node.

attributes.helpText: Indicate whether Application Express should compute the tree hierarchy from the data or whether the data already contains all hierarchy information.
Select the data source column containing the value for the hierarchy level of the node. Required when the Hierarchy attribute is set to Not Computed.
Select the data source column containing the value for the icon CSS class to be applied to the node.
Select the data source column containing the ID for a node. This is required when the hierarchy is being computed by Application Express. Typically, a primary key column is chosen here.
Select the data source column containing the value for the parent key of a node. Required when Application Express computes the hierarchy.

Select the data source column containing the value for the node status. Required when the Hierarchy attribute is set to Not Computed. The column must contain 0 for leaf nodes and 1 for nodes with children.

lovValues.helpText: Use an item value to start the tree.
Use the value returned by a SQL query to start the tree.
Use a static value to start the tree.
Use SQL NULL to start the tree.

attributes.helpText: This attribute determines how the root of the tree is computed. Nodes, for which the Parent Key column contains the value defined here will be considered as root nodes. Multiple roots are possible.
Choose the item containing the value to start the tree with.
Specify the SQL Query to determine the value to start the tree with. The SQL Query is always being executed in the local database and must return exactly one column.
Static value to start the tree with.
Specify the link to be executed when a node is clicked.
Select the data source column containing the value for the node tooltip.
Select the data source column containing the value for the link to be executed when a node is clicked.
Select the data source column to use for ordering children within a parent node.
Select the data source column containing the value for the node "value". This value is not displayed but added to the tree adapter node id property that can be accessed using JavaScript.

INIT_JAVASCRIPT_CODE.examples:
function( options ) {
    options.multiple = true;
    return options;
}
INIT_JAVASCRIPT_CODE.helpText:
Enter a JavaScript function that takes an options object for the Tree, modifies the object, and returns it. This allows advanced customization of the Tree during initialization of the treeView widget. See the treeView widget JavaScript API documentation for the available options.

Additional options defined by the tree region:

  • makeNodeAdapter Used to define a custom nodeAdapter. It is a function that takes the same arguments as makeDefaultNodeAdapter and must return a treeNodeAdapter interface.
  • initialSelectedNodeId The value of a node to select. This is set according to the Selected Node Page Item attribute.
  • nodeHasTooltip This is set according to the Tooltip attribute. It is true if the node has a tooltip and false otherwise.
  • regionStaticId This is the element id used for this region.

SOURCE_LOCATION.examples:
When the Hierarchy attribute is set to Computed with SQL
 select ename, empno, mgr from emp

Specify EMPNO for Node ID Column, MGR as Parent Key Column attributes

When the Hierarchy attribute is set to Not Computed
 select case when connect_by_isleaf = 1 then 0 when level = 1 then 1 else -1 end as status,
        level,
        ename as title,
        'icon-tree-folder' as icon,
        empno as value,
        ename as tooltip,
        null  as link
   from emp
  start with mgr is null
connect by prior empno = mgr
  order siblings by ename

Specify STATUS for Node Status Column, LEVEL for Hierarchy Level Column attributes.

5110.name: NATIVE_LIST
5110.title: List
5110.helpText: Displays values based on either a static or dynamic list. Generally these are used for navigating to pages in the application.

5110.name: NATIVE_PLSQL
5110.title: PL/SQL Dynamic Content
5110.helpText: Displays the HTML output from the PL/SQL code.

5110.name: NATIVE_SIMPLE_CHART
5110.title: Simple Chart [Deprecated]
5110.helpText: Display data in a HTML chart. This region type has been deprecated. Please use Chart region type for new chart regions. Oracle recommends that you use Upgrade Application to update these regions to the equivalent Chart region.

5110.name: NATIVE_SQL_REPORT
5110.title: Classic Report
5110.helpText: Simplified report based on a SQL Query. Classic Reports are similar to Interactive Reports, but do not include the numerous end-user customization options available with Interactive Reports.

SOURCE_LOCATION.examples:
select empno,
       ename,
       job,
       sal
  from emp
 where deptno = :P1_DEPTNO

5110.name: NATIVE_STATIC
5110.title: Static Content
5110.helpText: Display text content or a region container for page items. To output HTML markup and not have the content escaped, set Output As to HTML.

attributes.helpText: Specify whether Application Express expands Shortcuts in the HTML body.

lovValues.helpText: Application Express escapes special HTML characters, such as "<", ">", "&", when emitting the region source.
Application Express includes HTML markup when emitting the region source. This may make the region vulnerable to cross-site scripting.

attributes.helpText: Select how text content is output.
Specify whether line breaks in the region source cause line breaks in the region output.

5110.name: NATIVE_SVG_CHART
5110.title: SVG Chart [Deprecated]
5110.helpText: Display data in a SVG Chart. This region type has been deprecated. Please use Chart region type for new chart regions. Oracle recommends that you use Upgrade Application to update these regions to the equivalent Chart region.

5110.name: NATIVE_TABFORM
5110.title: Tabular Form [Legacy]
5110.helpText: Display multiple rows of data in a grid layout, where end users can update values directly within a grid element.

5110.name: NATIVE_TREE
5110.title: Classic Tree [Deprecated]
5110.helpText:
Display data in a hierarchical structure, based on parent-child relationships between records.

You should use Tree rather than this region type when creating new regions.

5110.name: NATIVE_URL
5110.title: URL
5110.helpText: Display remote content sourced from a URL.

attributes.helpText: Enter an URL for the remote content.

lovValues.helpText: Embed remote content as an iframe.
Read remote content at page rendering time and embed it, but escape special HTML characters to prevent cross-site scripting.

Read remote content at page rendering time and embed it. This option should only be selected if the remote content can be fully trusted, as no HTML escaping is done. This may make the region vulnerable to cross-site scripting.

attributes.helpText: Select how the remote content from the URL is included in the page.
Enter additional HTML element attributes for the iframe tag.
Use this attribute when clipping a section of HTML out of a larger document. Enter a string which identifies the beginning of the targeted section, or the point until which HTML is discarded.

Use this attribute to clip a section of HTML out of a larger HTML document. Enter a string which identifies the end of the targeted section, or the point from which the remaining HTML is discarded. This string which identifies the end of the targeted section is not included in the returned text.

5120.name: NATIVE_AUTO_COMPLETE
5120.title: Text Field with autocomplete
5120.helpText: Displays a text field that displays a list of possible values, based on the text already entered by the end user, inline with the text item. The list is further refined as the end user types in more text.

attributes.helpText:
Select how the search against the entered value is performed. When using Lazy Loading this setting can have an impact on query performance.

Note: Selecting Contains & Case Sensitive or Contains & Ignore Case prevents the use of column indexes.

Specify whether matching values are retrieved from the database using Lazy Loading techniques. Lazy loading retrieves matching records from the database each time the user types a character. Otherwise, all of the list values are loaded on page load.

Oracle recommends using Lazy Loading when you have a large select list, as loading a large number of records may impact the time to initially load the page.

Enter the maximum number of items to display in the select box.

This value can help avoid performance problems by returning too many rows, and also prevent a very large return set when only a few letters have been entered.
Specify whether search results are cached, when using Lazy Loading to retrieve matching records.

LOV.examples:
Display and store same value in page item
select ename
  from emp
 order by 1
Display employees of a specific department by using a bind variable
select ename
  from emp
 where deptno = :P3_DEPTNO
 order by 1

Note: Set Cascading LOV Parent Item(s) attribute to P3_DEPTNO if P3_DEPTNO is a modifiable page item on the same page.

5120.name: NATIVE_CHECKBOX
5120.title: Checkbox
5120.helpText: Displays multiple values as check boxes, enabling the end user to select multiple values. A list of values is required for items displayed as check boxes. The values corresponding to the checked boxes are stored in a single colon-delimited string.

attributes.helpText: Select how check boxes are rendered.
Enter the number of layout columns used to display the check boxes. For example, a value of 2 would display two columns of check boxes. By default, all values display in one column.

LOV.examples:
List of values based on SQL query
select ename as d, 
       empno as r
  from emp 
 order by 1
List of values with same display and return value
select ename d,
       ename r 
  from emp 
 order by 1

Note: When selecting the same column for both the display and return values use a column alias.

List of values with bind variable
select ename,
       empno 
  from emp 
 where deptno = :P3_DEPTNO 
 order by 1

Note: Set Cascading LOV Parent Item(s) attribute to P3_DEPTNO if P3_DEPTNO is a modifiable page item on the same page.

5120.name: NATIVE_COLOR_PICKER
5120.title: Color Picker
5120.helpText: Displays a text field with a color picker icon. End users can either enter a HTML color code directly, or click the icon to display a color palette popup. The end user can click a color from the palette which returns the corresponding HTML color code for the selected color.

5120.name: NATIVE_DATE_PICKER
5120.title: Date Picker
5120.helpText:
Displays a text field with a calendar icon. End users can either enter the date directly into the text item, or click on the calendar icon to select a date, and optionally a time, from the calendar popup.

Time is only displayed in the calendar popup if the Format Mask for this item includes time components.

attributes.helpText:
Enter the minimum date that can be input or selected.

The date value can be an absolute value in 'YYYY-MM-DDTHH24:MI:SS' or 'YYYYMMDDHH24MI' format or a relative value with respect to today's date, such as +7d, or a dynamic value using substitution syntax, providing the substitution returns the correct date format or relative value.

Relative date values include:

y
+ / - years from today's date
m
+ / - months from today's date
w
+ / - weeks from today's date
d
+ / - days from today's date

Enter the maximum date that can be input or selected.

The date value can be an absolute value in 'YYYY-MM-DDTHH24:MI:SS' or 'YYYYMMDDHH24MI' format or a relative value with respect to today's date, such as +7d, or a dynamic value using substitution syntax, providing the substitution returns the correct date format or relative value.

Relative date values include:

y
+ / - years from today's date
m
+ / - months from today's date
w
+ / - weeks from today's date
d
+ / - days from today's date

Enter a default date value to be highlighted when the calendar pop-up is invoked. If not specified, the calendar highlights the current date and time.

The value can be an absolute value in 'YYYYMMDDHH24MI' format or a relative value with respect to today's date, such as +7d, or a dynamic value using substitution syntax, providing the substitution returns the correct date format or relative value.

Relative date values include:

y
+ / - years from today's date
m
+ / - months from today's date
w
+ / - weeks from today's date
d
+ / - days from today's date

lovValues.helpText: The calendar pop-up displays as soon as the item receives focus.
The calendar pop-up displays when the icon is clicked.
The calendar pop-up displays as soon as the item receives focus and subsequently when the icon is clicked.
The calendar always displays inline on the page. No text field is displayed and the current date selection is shown highlighted in the calendar.

attributes.helpText: Select when the date picker pop-up calendar displays.

Specify whether the leading dates from the previous month and the trailing dates for the next month are displayed. The leading and trailing dates fully populate the first and last lines of the calendar. For example, if the first day of the week is Sunday, and the first of the current month displayed falls on a Wednesday, then the Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday show the last three days of the previous month.

attributes.examples:
<dl>
  <dt>2000:2010</dt>
    <dd>Uses absolute years to restrict permitted years to be between 2000 and 2010, inclusive.</dd>
  <dt>-05:+05</dt>
    <dd>Uses relative dates to limit permitted years to +/- five years from the current year.</dd>
  <dt>+01:+03</dt>
    <dd>Uses relative dates to limit permitted years to next year for a further two years.</dd>
</dl>
attributes.helpText:
Enter a range of permitted years shown in the Year select list within the calendar pop-up.

The year value can be an absolute value in 'YYYY:YYYY' format or relative values, using '-nn:+nn' format, where nn are integer values.

attributes.examples:
<dl>
  <dt>3</dt>
    <dd>Displays three months horizontally.</dd>
  <dt>[2,3]</dt>
    <dd>Displays six months, two rows by three columns.</dd>
  <dt>[4,3]</dt>
    <dd>Displays twelve months, four rows by three columns.</dd>
</dl>
attributes.helpText:
Enter how many months to show in the calendar pop-up.

You can enter an integer value or a two-dimensional array using [row,column], to define the number of rows and columns to display

Note: Months after the Highlighted Date are displayed.
Select whether select lists are provided within the calendar pop-up for Month and/or Year.

5120.name: NATIVE_DATE_PICKER_CLASSIC
5120.title: Date Picker (Classic) [Deprecated]
5120.helpText:
Displays a text field with a calendar icon. End users can either enter the date directly into the text item, or click on the calendar icon to select a date, and optionally a time, from the calendar popup.

You should use Date Picker rather than this item type when creating new items. Date Picker (Classic) items are generally those created in Application Express Release 4.1 or earlier.

5120.name: NATIVE_DATE_PICKER_HTML5
5120.title: Date Picker (HTML5)
5120.helpText: Displays a display-only field with a built-in mobile calendar. When the end user navigates to this item the built-in calendar popup displays. End users can enter the date and optionally the time using the popup.

attributes.helpText:
Enter the minimum date that can be selected.

The date value can be an absolute value in YYYY-MM-DDTHH24:MI:SS or YYYYMMDDHH24MI format or a relative value with respect to today's date, such as +7d, or a dynamic value using substitution syntax, providing the substitution returns the correct date format or relative value.

Relative date values include:

y
+ / - years from today's date
m
+ / - months from today's date
w
+ / - weeks from today's date
d
+ / - days from today's date

Enter the maximum date that can be selected.

The date value can be an absolute value in YYYY-MM-DDTHH24:MI:SS or YYYYMMDDHH24MI format or a relative value with respect to today's date, such as +7d, or a dynamic value using substitution syntax, providing the substitution returns the correct date format or relative value.

Relative date values include:

y
+ / - years from today's date
m
+ / - months from today's date
w
+ / - weeks from today's date
d
+ / - days from today's date

attributes.examples:
Processing with Date Type
to_date(:P1_BIRTHDAY, 'YYYY-MM-DD') <= trunc(sysdate)
Processing with Date and Time Type
to_date(:P1_ACTIVATION_TIME, 'YYYY-MM-DD"T"HH24:MI:SS') > sysdate
attributes.helpText:
Select whether this date picker also supports time to be entered.

The following date formats are returned:

Date Type
YYYY-MM-DD
Date and Time Type
YYYY-MM-DDTHH24:MI:SS

5120.name: NATIVE_DISPLAY_IMAGE
5120.title: Display Image
5120.helpText: Displays an image stored in a database BLOB columns, or based on an image URL.

lovValues.d: Image URL stored in Page Item Value
lovValues.helpText: The image URL is read from the value stored in session state for the page item specified.

lovValues.d: BLOB Column specified in Item Source
lovValues.helpText: Reads the image from the BLOB column specified in the Item Source attribute.

lovValues.d: BLOB Column returned by SQL statement
lovValues.helpText: Displays the image based on the BLOB column which is returned by the SQL statement specified.

attributes.helpText: Select where to retrieve the image from.
Enter the uppercase page or application item name that holds the filename column value associated with the BLOB column.

Enter the uppercase page or application item name that holds the date column value when the associated BLOB was last updated.

This value is used for browser caching and to identify if the image has been changed since the last request from the browser. If the image is not updated then the image is retrieved from the browser cache, if available.
Enter text which is read by screen readers when an end user navigates to this item.
Enter the uppercase page or application item name which holds the alternative text for this image. This text is read by screen readers when an end user navigates to this item.

attributes.examples:
select product_image,
       product_name as alt_text,
       filename,
       image_last_update
  from demo_product_info
 where product_id = :P6_PRODUCT_ID
attributes.helpText: Enter the SQL statement to return the BLOB column containing the image.

5120.name: NATIVE_DISPLAY_ONLY
5120.title: Display Only
5120.helpText: Displays a non-enterable text item.

attributes.helpText:
Specify whether line breaks are preserved in the output.

Because the display is rendered as HTML, when set to Yes line breaks in the display value are converted to HTML line breaks, so they display correctly.

lovValues.helpText: The current value of the page item displays.

lovValues.d: Display Value of List of Values
lovValues.helpText: The current value of the page item gets mapped to a different display value using a List of Values.
The specified PL/SQL code emits the output displayed.

attributes.helpText: Select how to determine the value displayed.

Enter the PL/SQL code using sys.htp.p or sys.htp.prn to emit HTML code.

Oracle recommends using sys.htf.escape_sc to escape data retrieved from the database to ensure that HTML tags are escaped.
Specify whether the current value is saved into session state when the page is submitted.

LOV.examples:
Example 1: List of values based on SQL query. 

SELECT dname, deptno from dept

Example 2: Static list examples

  • STATIC:Yes;Y,No;N (show Yes / No, instead of Y and N)

Example 3: List of values with additional restriction using bind variable 

SELECT dname, deptno from dept where location=:P3_LOCATION

5120.name: NATIVE_FILE
5120.title: File Browse...
5120.helpText: Displays a text field with a Browse... button. The Browse button enables the user to locate and upload a file from a local file system.

attributes.helpText:
Specify whether multiple files can be uploaded at once.

Note - Multiple file names will be stored as a colon delimited list in the page item.

attributes.examples:
Indicate that only image files should be accepted
image/*
Indicate that only image and video files should be accepted
image/*,video/*
Indicate that only PNG image files should be accepted
image/png
attributes.helpText: Specify a comma delimited list of file types which might be used by the browser to restrict which files can be uploaded.

lovValues.helpText: Delete the file at the end of the current Application Express session.
Delete the file at the end of the current HTTP request.

attributes.helpText: Define when Application Express should remove the temporary file.

Enter the uppercase page or application item name used to store the mime type of the uploaded file. The mime type is used by the browser to identify which application is used to display the content of the BLOB when the file is downloaded.
Enter the page or application item used to store the filename of the uploaded file.

Enter the uppercase page or application item name used to store the character set of the uploaded file. The character set of the BLOB is not automatically set on upload. End users should set the character set for the document they are uploading.
Enter the uppercase page or application item name used to store the current timestamp when a file is uploaded. This date value is used for browser caching.

Select how the browser handles the content when downloading.

Note: Not all content can be displayed inline. Support for displaying content inline depends on whether the specific mime type is supported by the browser.
Enter the text to displayed as part of the download link. If not specified, the text stored in the Text Message for APEX.FILE_BROWSE.DOWNLOAD_LINK_TEXT, within Shared Components, displays.

lovValues.d: BLOB column specified in Item Source attribute
lovValues.helpText: Stores the uploaded file in the table used by the Automatic Row Processing (DML) process and the column specified in the item source attribute. The column has to be of data type BLOB. If the file gets downloaded, the table name of the Automatic Row Fetch process is used.

Stores the uploaded file(s) in a temporary location that you can access with the view APEX_APPLICATION_TEMP_FILES. Application Express will automatically delete the file(s) at the end of the session or at the end of the upload request, depending on what you choose for Purge File At.

To access a file if Allow Multiple Files is set to No:

select *
  from apex_application_temp_files
 where name = :page item name;

To access files if Allow Multiple Files is set to Yes:

declare
    l_file_names apex_t_varchar2;
    l_file       apex_application_temp_files%rowtype;
begin
    l_file_names := apex_string.split (
                        p_str => :page item name,
                        p_sep => ':' );
    for i in 1 .. l_file_names.count loop
        select *
          into l_file
          from apex_application_temp_files
         where name = l_file_names(i);
        -- add code here to store the uploaded file in your own table
    end loop;
end;

Stores the uploaded file in the Application Express table WWV_FLOW_FILES.

To access the file use:

select *
  from wwv_flow_files
 where name = :page item name;

attributes.helpText: Select the database table where the uploaded file is stored.
Specify whether the download link displays when there is a non-empty BLOB associated with this item.

5120.name: NATIVE_HIDDEN
5120.title: Hidden
5120.helpText: Items that are included within the page source but are not rendered. Hidden item values are saved in session state. They are generally used to store values required by page processing or other page items, but should not be displayed to the end user.

attributes.helpText: Specifying whether the item is protected, preventing the value from being manipulated when the page is posted.

5120.name: NATIVE_HTML_EXPRESSION
5120.title: HTML Expression
5120.helpText: Displays a non-enterable item based on a HTML expression.

attributes.examples:
Change the background and text colors
<span style="background-color:yellow; color:red;">&EMPLOYEE_STATUS.</span>
Use Heading 2
<h2>&EMPLOYEE_NAME.</h2>
Use a dynamic class from the SQL query
<span class="&COLUMN_CLASS!ATTR.">&EMPLOYEE_STATUS.</span>

The &COLUMN_CLASS!ATTR. and &EMPLOYEE_STATUS. substitutions in this example are columns selected in the SQL query.
Show an image, and a tooltip on hover
<img src="&IMAGE_NAME!ATTR." title="&EMPLOYEE_NAME!ATTR.">
attributes.helpText: Enter HTML expressions to be shown in this column. Use &COLUMN. syntax to show column values in HTML.

5120.name: NATIVE_LINK
5120.title: Link
5120.helpText: Displays a non-enterable item as a link.

5120.name: NATIVE_LIST_MANAGER
5120.title: List Manager
5120.helpText:
Displays a text item with a popup list of values icon, Add and Remove buttons, and a list of selected values.

You can type in the value or pick from the list of available items. You can then utilize the buttons to manage the values selected. The selected values are stored in a single colon-delimited string.

attributes.helpText: Specify whether the value remains as entered, or is converted to uppercase.

lovValues.d: Fetch First Rowset and Filter Current Value

attributes.helpText: Select how data is displayed when the Popup LOV is opened.

LOV.examples:
List of values based on SQL query
select ename as d, 
       empno as r
  from emp 
 order by 1
List of values with same display and return value
select ename d,
       ename r 
  from emp 
 order by 1

Note: When selecting the same column for both the display and return values use a column alias.

List of values with bind variable
select ename,
       empno 
  from emp 
 where deptno = :P3_DEPTNO 
 order by 1

Note: Set Cascading LOV Parent Item(s) attribute to P3_DEPTNO if P3_DEPTNO is a modifiable page item on the same page.

5120.name: NATIVE_NUMBER_FIELD
5120.title: Number Field
5120.helpText: Displays a number field. This item type automatically validates that the value is a number.

attributes.helpText: Enter the minimum value permitted. The value can be a static value or a dynamic value using substitution syntax.
Enter the maximum value permitted. The value can be a static value or a dynamic value using substitution syntax.
Select how to align the number that displays. This setting does not apply when the item is rendered as Read Only or where HTML Form Element Attributes are specified.

5120.name: NATIVE_PASSWORD
5120.title: Password
5120.helpText: Displays an HTML password form element. As the end user enters text a black dot is displayed for that character, instead of the actual character entered.

attributes.helpText: Specify whether pressing the Enter key while in this field automatically submits the page.

Specify whether the password is saved in session state.

Oracle strongly recommends that you do not write the password into session state, for security reasons. The value can potentially be read from browser cache and Application Express session tables. If you do set this attribute to No, consider setting Store value encrypted in session state to Yes.

5120.name: NATIVE_PCT_GRAPH
5120.title: Percent Graph
5120.helpText: Displays the value as a percentage graph. The value retrieved must be between 0 and 100.

attributes.helpText: Specify whether the percent value is visible.

Enter the color used for the text of this graph. The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names.

Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

Enter the color used for the background of this graph. The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names.

Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.

Enter the color used for the foreground of this graph. The color is specified using hexadecimal (hex) notation, RGB color codes, or HTML color names.

Hex notation is defined as #xxyyzz (a # followed by 3 double digit hex numbers), where xx, yy, and zz represent the two character hex values for red, green and blue respectively. RGB codes are defined as RGB(xxx,xxx,xxx), where xxx is a number between 0 and 255 each representing the single 8-bit byte value for red, green, and blue respectively.

Search the internet for 'HTML Color Codes' to find the equivalent hex code or RGB code for the color you wish to utilize.
Enter the width in pixels for this bar chart.

5120.name: NATIVE_POPUP_LOV
5120.title: Popup LOV
5120.helpText:
Displays a text item with a popup list of values icon. When the end user clicks the icon, a popup window appears with a search field, and a list of supported values.

Popup LOV is best suited for large lists since end users can enter search criteria to reduce the available values displayed. For relatively small lists Select List is often better suited.

lovValues.d: Fetch First Rowset and Filter Current Value

attributes.helpText: Select how data is initially fetched for the list of values.

lovValues.d: Enterable, Show and Store Return Value
Not Enterable, Show Display Value and Store Return Value

attributes.helpText: Select whether the item is enterable.
Specify whether multiple values or only a single value can be selected from the list of values. Multiple values are returned as a comma-separated list.

LOV.examples:
List of values based on SQL query
select ename as d, 
       empno as r
  from emp 
 order by 1
List of values with same display and return value
select ename d,
       ename r 
  from emp 
 order by 1

Note: When selecting the same column for both the display and return values use a column alias.

List of values with bind variable
select ename,
       empno 
  from emp 
 where deptno = :P3_DEPTNO 
 order by 1

Note: Set Cascading LOV Parent Item(s) attribute to P3_DEPTNO if P3_DEPTNO is a modifiable page item on the same page.

5120.name: NATIVE_RADIOGROUP
5120.title: Radio Group
5120.helpText: Displays multiple values as radio group options, enabling the end user to select a single value.

attributes.helpText: Select the orientation for displaying radio group values.
Enter the number of radio group columns to display. For example, a value of 2 would display two columns, so if there were five values then it would display over three rows.

lovValues.helpText: No immediate action is taken when the value is changed.
The page is submitted with the page REQUEST set to the page item name.
The browser redirects to the current page and session state for the current item is set to the selected value.

attributes.helpText: Select what action is taken when a radio group value is selected.
Specify whether validations are performed when the page is submitted, due to page action setting Submit Page.

LOV.examples:
List of values based on SQL query
select ename as d, 
       empno as r
  from emp 
 order by 1
List of values with same display and return value
select ename d,
       ename r 
  from emp 
 order by 1

Note: When selecting the same column for both the display and return values use a column alias.

List of values with bind variable
select ename,
       empno 
  from emp 
 where deptno = :P3_DEPTNO 
 order by 1

Note: Set Cascading LOV Parent Item(s) attribute to P3_DEPTNO if P3_DEPTNO is a modifiable page item on the same page.

5120.name: NATIVE_RICH_TEXT_EDITOR
5120.title: Rich Text Editor
5120.helpText: Displays a text area with comprehensive text formatting options. End users can enhance the content displayed in a similar fashion to using a word processor, such as Microsoft Word. End users can also cut and paste documents, that are in rich text format (RTF) file format, into this item.

attributes.helpText: Specify where in the text area the editor displays.
Select the number of text formatting options available within the editor.
Specify whether the editor is initially expanded within the text area.
Select the editor skin used to style the editor.

INIT_JAVASCRIPT_CODE.examples:
function ( pOptions) {
    // Lines will be broken with <br> elements instead of generating a <p> section:
    pOptions.enterMode        = 2;

    // set another base color for editor UI:
    pOptions.uiColor          = "#AADC6E";
    return pOptions;
}
INIT_JAVASCRIPT_CODE.helpText: Enter a JavaScript function to override standard CKEditor initialization. The function must return a javascript object containing the configuration for CKEditor. See CKEditor documentation for a list of available attributes.

5120.name: NATIVE_ROW_ACTION
5120.title: Actions Menu
5120.helpText:
Displays the actions icon (hamburger) on each row of an Interactive Grid. The actions menu includes options such as Single Row View, Add Row, Delete Row, and Refresh Row, and so forth, depending on the grid attributes and end user authorizations. These menu options allow end users to perform specific actions on the current row in the grid.

By default the APEX$ROW_ACTION column is set to a type of Actions Menu. This column is automatically added when the Interactive Grid is made editable.

5120.name: NATIVE_ROW_SELECTOR
5120.title: Row Selector
5120.helpText:
Displays a check box on each row of an Interactive Grid, allowing selection of specific row(s) for row manipulation.

By default the APEX$ROW_SELECTOR column is set to a type of Row Selector. This column is automatically added when the Interactive Grid is made editable.

attributes.helpText: Allow multiple rows to be selected.
Allow the user to select all rows using Ctrl+A or if Hide Controls is No using a checkbox in the column header.
Hide the checkbox or radio-control displayed on each row.

5120.name: NATIVE_SELECT_LIST
5120.title: Select List
5120.helpText:
Displays an item with a built-in list of values selector. When the end user clicks the item, the list of supported values displays directly inline with the current item.

Select List is best suited for relatively small, discrete lists. End-Users can very quickly select a value from the list without needing to change focus to a popup dialog. For large lists Popup LOV is often better suited.

lovValues.helpText: No immediate action is taken when the value is changed.
The page is submitted with the page REQUEST set to the page item name.
The browser is redirected to the current page and session state for the current item is set to the selected value.
The browser is redirected to the page contained in the selected value. The return values in the list must include valid page numbers or page aliases.
The browser is redirected to the URL contained in the selected value. The return values in the list must include valid URLs.

attributes.helpText: Select what action is taken when a list value is selected.
Specify whether validations are performed when the page is submitted, based on the page action setting of Submit Page.
Specify whether multiple values or only a single value can be selected from the list of values. Multiple values are returned as a comma-separated list.

LOV.examples:
List of values based on SQL query
select ename as d, 
       empno as r
  from emp 
 order by 1
List of values with same display and return value
select ename d,
       ename r 
  from emp 
 order by 1

Note: When selecting the same column for both the display and return values use a column alias.

List of values with bind variable
select ename,
       empno 
  from emp 
 where deptno = :P3_DEPTNO 
 order by 1

Note: Set Cascading LOV Parent Item(s) attribute to P3_DEPTNO if P3_DEPTNO is a modifiable page item on the same page.

5120.name: NATIVE_SHUTTLE
5120.title: Shuttle
5120.helpText:
Displays as a multiple select list that includes two boxes containing lists. The left list displays the source list of values that have not been selected and the right list shows the currently selected values. End users can select one or more values in a list then use the shuttle controls to move the selected values or all values.

The current values are stored in a single colon-delimited string.

attributes.helpText: Select what data movement controls displays in the middle of the shuttle.

LOV.examples:
List of values based on SQL query
select ename as d, 
       empno as r
  from emp 
 order by 1
List of values with same display and return value
select ename d,
       ename r 
  from emp 
 order by 1

Note: When selecting the same column for both the display and return values use a column alias.

List of values with bind variable
select ename,
       empno 
  from emp 
 where deptno = :P3_DEPTNO 
 order by 1

Note: Set Cascading LOV Parent Item(s) attribute to P3_DEPTNO if P3_DEPTNO is a modifiable page item on the same page.

5120.name: NATIVE_SLIDER
5120.title: Slider
5120.helpText: Displays a slider item type, which enables users to update the item value by sliding the control left or right.

attributes.helpText: Specify whether the slider highlights the track up to the current slider handle position.
Enter the minimum value permitted. The value can be a static value or a dynamic value using substitution syntax.
Enter the maximum value permitted. The value can be a static value or a dynamic value using substitution syntax.
Enter a value to force the slider to snap to a specific increment. The value can be a static value or a dynamic value using substitution syntax.

5120.name: NATIVE_STOP_AND_START_HTML_TABLE
5120.title: Stop and Start Grid Layout [Deprecated]
5120.helpText:
Legacy item Used to stop the previous HTML table and start a new HTML table. Before Grid Layout was introduced in Application Express Release xx, this item type was used extensively to tailor the display of page items.

Oracle recommends deleting these legacy item types and updating the Start New Grid to Yes for the next page item displayed in that region. This is functionally equivalent to using a Stop and Start Grid Layout item.

5120.name: NATIVE_TEXTAREA
5120.title: Textarea
5120.helpText: Displays a multiple-row text area.

attributes.helpText: Select how the item value is trimmed after submitting the page. This setting trims spaces, tabs, and new lines from the text entered.
Specify whether the text area resizing using the mouse is enabled.
Specify whether the height of the text area varies based on the amount of text displayed. Use this option to scale the text area to the amount of data.
Specify whether a counter is displayed below the text area. The counter displays the number of characters entered in the field and the total characters permitted, such as 123 of 4000.

5120.name: NATIVE_TEXT_FIELD
5120.title: Text Field
5120.helpText: Displays a text field.

attributes.helpText: Specify whether pressing the Enter key while in this field automatically submits the page.

Specify whether this item is disabled, which prevents end users from changing the value.

A disabled text item still displays with the same HTML formatting, unlike an item type of Display Only, which removes the HTML formatting. Disabled text items are part of page source, which enables their session state to be evaluated. Conversely, display only items are not stored in session state.
Specify whether the current item value is stored in session state when the page is submitted.

Select the HTML5 text subtype. This enables devices with on-screen keyboards to show an optimized keyboard layout specific to the subtype, for easier data input. The subtype selection is also used to render an appropriate link with the value of the page item, if it is rendered read only. This attribute does not change the text item, or data entry, when using a physical keyboard.

Note: This HTML5 feature only works in modern browsers. Older, non HTML5-compliant, browsers ignore this attribute and render the page item as a normal text field.
Select how the item value is trimmed after submitting the page. This setting trims spaces, tabs, and new lines from the text entered.

5120.name: NATIVE_TEXT_WITH_CALCULATOR
5120.title: Text Field with Calculator Popup [Deprecated]
5120.helpText: Displays a text field with a calculator icon. When clicked, the icon displays a small window containing a calculator. Calculations are placed back in the text field.

5120.name: NATIVE_YES_NO
5120.title: Switch
5120.helpText: Displays as a flip toggle switch.

attributes.helpText: Select whether application level component settings are used, or if custom settings are used for this item.
Enter the value stored in the page item if the user picks the On option. The value can be up to 255 characters long.
Enter the text displayed for the On option.

Enter the value stored in the page item if the user picks the Off option. This attribute can also be left blank if you want to store NULL when the Off option is selected. The value can be up to 255 characters long.

Note: This value is used if the page item is populated with a value which does not match either the On Value or Off Value.
Enter the text displayed for the Off option.

5150.name: NATIVE_ADD_CLASS
5150.title: Add Class
5150.helpText: Adds one or more CSS classes to the affected elements.

attributes.examples:
Add the CSS classes articlenumber and highlight to the HTML tag of the affected elements: 
articlenumber highlight
attributes.helpText: Specify one or more classes to be applied to the affected elements. If specifying more than one, separate class names with a space.

5150.name: NATIVE_ALERT
5150.title: Alert
5150.helpText: Displays an alert message, with a single Ok button. Use to display information that must be responded to, by pressing the button, but continues executing the event.

attributes.helpText: Enter the text to display in the alert dialog.

5150.name: NATIVE_CANCEL_EVENT
5150.title: Cancel Event
5150.helpText: Cancels the current event.

5150.name: NATIVE_CLEAR
5150.title: Clear
5150.helpText: Clears the affected elements.

5150.name: NATIVE_CONFIRM
5150.title: Confirm
5150.helpText: Displays a confirmation dialog, with Cancel and Ok buttons. If the user chooses Cancel then the proceeding actions are not executed and the current event is canceled.

attributes.helpText: Enter the text to be displayed in the confirmation dialog.

5150.name: NATIVE_DIALOG_CANCEL
5150.title: Cancel Dialog
5150.helpText: Cancels the current dialog page.

5150.name: NATIVE_DIALOG_CLOSE
5150.title: Close Dialog
5150.helpText: Closes the current dialog page.

attributes.helpText:
Enter the name of one or more page items to be returned by the dialog. For multiple items separate each item name with a comma.

You can access the returned item values by defining a Dynamic Action to fire on the Dialog Closed event on the element that opens the dialog, with an action of Set Value and a Set Type of Dialog Return Item.

5150.name: NATIVE_DISABLE
5150.title: Disable
5150.helpText: Disables the affected elements. Disabling makes these elements non-editable so that they do not retain item values when the page is submitted.

5150.name: NATIVE_ENABLE
5150.title: Enable
5150.helpText: Enables the affected elements.

5150.name: NATIVE_EXECUTE_PLSQL_CODE
5150.title: Execute PL/SQL Code
5150.helpText: Executes PL/SQL code on the server.

attributes.helpText: Specify whether the change event is suppressed on the items specified in Page Items to Return. This prevents subsequent Change based Dynamic Actions from firing, for these items.

attributes.examples:
begin
    setCommission(:P1_SAL, :P1_JOB);
end;

In this example, you need to enter P1_SAL,P1_JOB in Page Items to Submit.
attributes.helpText:
Specify an execution only PL/SQL anonymous block, that is executed on the server.

You can reference other page or application items from within your application using bind syntax (for example :P1_MY_ITEM). Any items referenced also need to be included in Page Items to Submit.

Enter the uppercase page items submitted to the server, and therefore, available for use within your PL/SQL Code.

You can type in the item name or pick from the list of available items. If you pick from the list and there is already text entered then a comma is placed at the end of the existing text, followed by the item name returned from the list.

attributes.examples:
apex_util.set_session_state('P1_MY_ITEM', 'New Value');

In this example, enter P1_MY_ITEM in this attribute in order for 'New Value' to be displayed in that item on your page.
attributes.helpText:
Enter the uppercase page items set when the call to the server returns, based on their current value in session state. If your PL/SQL Code sets one or more page item values in session state you need to define those items in this attribute.

You can type in the item name or pick from the list of available items. If you pick from the list and there is already text entered then a comma is placed at the end of the existing text, followed by the item name returned from the list.

5150.name: NATIVE_HIDE
5150.title: Hide
5150.helpText: Hides the affected elements.

attributes.prompt: Hide all page items on the same line
attributes.helpText:
Specify whether all the page items and labels on the same line as the affected elements are hidden.

Note: This attribute does not work for items on pages that do not use a table grid to display form items. This includes any page using a mobile page template.

5150.name: NATIVE_JAVASCRIPT_CODE
5150.title: Execute JavaScript Code
5150.helpText: Enables you to define or call custom, page specific JavaScript code to use within the dynamic action framework. If you are defining JavaScript code that is specific to just one page, you can use the page-level attribute Function and Global Variable Declaration to define this. Functions and variables defined there can then be referenced from this action.

attributes.examples:
This code has access to the following dynamic action related attributes:

this.triggeringElement
A reference to the DOM object of the element that triggered the dynamic action.
this.affectedElements
A jQuery object containing all the affected elements.
this.action
The action object containing details such as the action name and additional attribute values.
this.browserEvent
The event object of event that triggered the event. Note: On load this equals 'load'.
this.data
Optional additional data that can be passed from the event handler.
attributes.helpText: Enter any custom JavaScript that is specific to the page or dynamic action.

5150.name: NATIVE_REFRESH
5150.title: Refresh
5150.helpText: Triggers a refresh of the affected elements. Not all elements support a refresh action. You can use this action to refresh content in Interactive Reports, Classic Reports, and all item types with cascading LOV support.

5150.name: NATIVE_REMOVE_CLASS
5150.title: Remove Class
5150.helpText: Removes one or more CSS classes from the affected elements.

attributes.helpText: Specify one or more class names that to be removed from the affected elements. If specifying more than one, separate class names with a space. Leave blank to remove all class names from the affected elements.

5150.name: NATIVE_SET_CSS
5150.title: Set Style
5150.helpText: Sets a style (CSS) property to the affected elements.

attributes.helpText: Enter the name of the style (CSS) property you want to set for the affected elements.
Enter the value to set the style property to for the affected elements. Leave blank to remove the style property from the affected elements.

5150.name: NATIVE_SET_FOCUS
5150.title: Set Focus
5150.helpText: Sets the focus to the affected elements. This will default to the 1st of the affected elements if there are multiple. This can be especially useful when used in conjunction with the Show and Enable actions to take the user straight to the appropriate item.

5150.name: NATIVE_SET_VALUE
5150.title: Set Value
5150.helpText: Sets the value of the affected elements.

attributes.helpText: Enter the name of a page item returned by the dialog used to set the value.
Enter a static value.

lovValues.helpText: Set a single static value.
Set one or more values, derived or calculated from JavaScript.
Set one or more values, based on the result of a SQL query.
Set a single value, based on the result of a PL/SQL expression.
Set a single value, based on the result of a PL/SQL function body.
Set a single value, based on the return item of a dialog. Note: This type only works if the dynamic action fires for the Dialog Closed event.

attributes.helpText: Select how to derive the value(s) to set.

attributes.examples:
select loc,
       dname
  from dept 
 where deptno = :P1_DEPTNO

In this example, enter P1_DEPTNO in Page Items to Submit. You should also select two Affected Elements, for the loc and dname columns respectively, for example P1_LOC and P1_DNAME.
attributes.helpText:
Enter a SQL statement that returns between 1 and 100 columns. The columns you select with the SQL statement needs to correspond, by position, to the Page Items you select in Affected Elements.

You can reference page or application items using bind syntax, providing you include them in Page Items to Submit

Note: If the SQL statement returns only a single row, this is set as the values. If it returns multiple row, the value set is a comma separated string of all the rows, for each value.

Enter page or application items to submit when executing this action. For multiple items, separate each item name with a comma. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items. If you pick from the list and there is already text entered then a comma is placed at the end of the existing text, followed by the item name returned from the list.

Enter a JavaScript expression used to set the value. This expression can either result in a single value, or an array of values (where the item being set supports multiple values, for example a Shuttle).
Specify whether the change event is suppressed on the items specified in Page Items to Return. This prevents subsequent Change based Dynamic Actions from firing, for these items.

attributes.examples:
nvl(:P1_SAL, 0)

In this example, enter P1_SAL in Page Items to Submit.
attributes.helpText:
Enter a PL/SQL expression used to set the value.

You can reference page or application items, providing you include them in Page Items to Submit.

attributes.examples:
return getCommission(:P1_SAL, :P1_JOB);

In this example, enter P1_SAL and P1_JOB in Page Items to Submit.
attributes.helpText:
Enter a PL/SQL function body used to set the value.

You can reference page or application items, providing you do include them in Page Items to Submit.
Specify whether HTML special characters are escaped. Oracle strongly recommends setting this attribute to Yes, to prevent Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks.

5150.name: NATIVE_SHOW
5150.title: Show
5150.helpText: Shows the affected elements.

attributes.prompt: Show all on the same line
attributes.helpText:
Specify whether all the page items and labels on the same line as the affected elements are shown.

Note: This attribute does not work for items on pages that do not use a table grid to display form items. This includes any page using a mobile page template.

5150.name: NATIVE_SUBMIT_PAGE
5150.title: Submit Page
5150.helpText: Submits the page.

attributes.helpText: Specify whether the current page is grayed-out and a 'processing' style animation is displayed during page submission. This can be useful to prevent end user action during long running operations, such as the end user attempting to re-click on the search button when the report is slow to refresh.

Enter the request value used to submit the page. Set this to the button name, if a button triggers the Dynamic Action. This ensures the button's Execute Validations attribute is respected during page processing.

5150.name: NATIVE_TREE_COLLAPSE
5150.title: Collapse Tree
5150.helpText: Collapse the current node in a tree region.

5150.name: NATIVE_TREE_EXPAND
5150.title: Expand Tree
5150.helpText: Expand the current node in a tree region.

5530.name: NATIVE_CLOSE_WINDOW
5530.title: Close Dialog
5530.helpText: Process to close the current modal or non-modal dialog page.

attributes.helpText:
Enter the name of one or more page items to be returned by the dialog. For multiple items separate each item name with a comma.

You can access the returned item values by defining a Dynamic Action to fire on the Dialog Closed event on the element that opens the dialog, with an action of Set Value and a Set Type of Dialog Return Item.

5530.name: NATIVE_FORM_FETCH
5530.title: Automatic Row Fetch
5530.helpText: Process to retrieve records from a single database table or view. This process is used to populate form items with a source of Type Database Column.

attributes.helpText: Select the table owner (schema) name.
Enter the case-sensitive table or view name. You can type in the name or pick from the list.
Enter the page or application item to hold the primary key column value. You can type in the name or pick from the list.
Select the column containing the primary key value. For tables with more than two-part primary keys, select ROWID.
Enter the page or application item to hold the second primary key column value. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items.
Select the column containing the second primary key value. This attribute should only be populated if your primary key is composed of two columns.

This option exists for backwards compatibility only. New applications should always leave this setting empty. The option "Set Memory Cache on Display" is deprecated and is not utilized in processes generated with this release of Application Express.

When an Automated Row Fetch process selects a row, the corresponding page items are set to the fetched column values. The DML Fetch Mode setting determines when that happens. The default mode updates the in-memory session state immediately when the row is fetched. The mode 'Set Memory Cache on Display' updates this session state only when (and if) the item is rendered. If you need to reference the fetched value of the item using bind variable or v('ITEM_NAME') syntax between the time of the row fetch and the time of the item rendering, you must use the default fetch mode. When you create a new Automatic Row Fetch process, its fetch mode is set to this default mode. Unless your page's logic depends on the 'On Display' behavior, we suggest that you update this process to use default behavior, to give you maximum flexibility to reference fetched column values during page rendering.
Enter the SQL WHERE clause to append to the generated SELECT statement. Use this attribute to limit the records used within automatically generated SQL calls.

Select the column that identifies the version of the row, this column does not need to be present on the page. Leave this attribute blank to use the built-in checksum.

Opportunistic locking uses lost update detection to ensure data integrity in applications where data can be accessed concurrently. Application Express can use a built in checksum to perform lost update detection and determine the version of the row. The checksum is a hash function of all the column values for the specific table row. It is retrieved when the record is queried from the database, and then compared against the hash of the current record in the database as part of Automatic Row Processing. If the two values are the same then the update proceeds, otherwise an error is raised by Automatic Row Processing.

This attribute enables you to specify a single column which holds the row version, as an alternative to using the built-in checksum processing. This column should be updated whenever a record in the database is updated. Oracle recommends implementing a 'Before Update' database trigger on the table to increment or otherwise update the row version column. NUMBER columns are presumed to contain a sequence number for the row. However, DATE and TIMESTAMP columns can also be used. The advantage of using a single column is that the Application Express engine does not need to perform the hash of the complete row, instead it can just compare a single column value.

5530.name: NATIVE_FORM_PAGINATION
5530.title: Form Pagination
5530.helpText:
Process to retrieve the previous or next record from a database table or view. This process can be used to provide pagination on Form pages, so that end users can retrieve the previous or next record without navigating back to a report.

Note: If the form allows data to be updated then you should generally ensure that the appropriate form processing is performed prior to this pagination process executing. Otherwise, any updates made by the end user will be lost when they navigate to another record.

attributes.helpText: Select the table owner (schema) name.
Enter the case-sensitive table or view name. You can type in the name or pick from the list.
Enter the page or application item that holds the primary key column value. You can type in the name or pick from the list.
Select the column containing the primary key value. For tables with more than two-part primary keys, select <strong>ROWID>/strong>.
Enter the page or application item that holds the second primary key column value. You can type in the name or pick from the list.
Select the column containing the second primary key value. This attribute should only be populated if your primary key is composed of two columns.

Select the column containing the navigation order value.

This column is used to determine the previous and next rows. Therefore, a column such as DISPLAY_SEQ is an ideal column to use. If you want to order records in the sequence they were created you could use a column such as CREATED or ID, when populated from a sequence or based on an Oracle Database 12c Identity column. However, you have the flexibility to order records on any two columns, for example JOB and DEPTNO

Note: The navigation order columns should match the default columns used to order the report end users navigated from to get to this form. Alternatively, you should ensure end users understand how the previous and next rows are determined, for example by using button labels or help text.
Select the column containing the second navigation order value. This attribute should only be populated if your navigation key is composed of two columns.
Enter the page or application item that holds the primary key column value for the next record. You can type in the name or pick from the list.
Enter the page or application item that holds the primary key column value for the previous record. You can type in the name or pick from the list.
Enter the page or application item that holds the second primary key column value for the next record. You can type in the name or pick from the list.
Enter the page or application item that holds the second primary key column value for the previous record. You can type in the name or pick from the list.

Enter the page or application item to hold the total record count value. You can type in the name or pick from the list.

If your result set contains more than 10,000 rows, defining this item may slow down the performance.
Enter a SQL statement to restrict the records returned by the query.

5530.name: NATIVE_FORM_PROCESS
5530.title: Automatic Row Processing (DML)
5530.helpText: Process to insert, update, or delete records into a single database table or updateable view. This process is used to process form items with a source of Type Database Column. Attributes entered for this process should correlate with the attributes entered in the Automatic Row Fetch process.

attributes.helpText: Select whether each row to be updated or deleted is locked in the underlying table before processing the row.

Enter the page or application item item to hold the primary key column value returned from a SQL INSERT statement. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items.

Specify this column to get back the primary key fields populated by sequences or database triggers. This value is set into session state by the process.
Enter the page or application item to hold the second primary key column value returned from a SQL INSERT statement. You can type in the name or pick from the list of available items.

lovValues.helpText: Triggered by Request Values: INSERT, CREATE, CREATE_AGAIN, CREATEAGAIN
Triggered by Request Values: SAVE, APPLY CHANGES, UPDATE, UPDATE ROW, CHANGE, APPLY, APPLY%CHANGES%, GET_NEXT%, GET_PREV%
Triggered by Request Values: DELETE, REMOVE, DELETE ROW, DROP
